questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was on a diet consisting predominantly of packaged and reheated meals presents with iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations. Which of the following antioxidant deficiency can lead to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Dietary deficiency of Vitamin C can lead to scurvy which can manifest as microcytic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. It is mainly required for the hydroxylation of prolyl and lysyl residues of collagen reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. It also facilitates the absorption of iron by reducing it from a ferric to a ferrous state.

Hence, vitamin C deficiency leads to defective collagen synthesis, fragile blood vessels, and iron deficiency anemia. Other clinical features of scurvy include spongy gums, loose teeth, swollen joints, subcutaneous hemorrhage, and bone fractures.

Other options:

Option A- Glutathione, an antioxidant, is present in glutathione peroxidase. It helps in the destruction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides.

Option B- β-carotene is provitamin A, found in plants. It helps in the formation of retinaldehyde which is utilized in vision. It also regulates gene expression and cell differentiation.

Option D- Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes like carboxypeptidases, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, the cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, etc. Chronic zinc deficiency causes stunting and increases the risk of respiratory and diarrheal diseases. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder that causes abnormalities in zinc absorption.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of dizziness on lying down for the past one week.  She feels better on sitting up or turning to the side.  What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of supine hypotension syndrome due to inferior vena caval compression. 

During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava (IVC) when the patient is in the supine position. To compensate, there will be an opening up of the collaterals of paravertebral and azygous veins.

When collaterals fail to open, venous return of the heart is reduced leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about dapagliflozin?

choices.text: It is indicated in heart failure
It will increase the risk of fractures

questions.solution:
Dapagliflozin does not cause weight gain. It results in weight loss.

It acts by inhibiting the SGLT2 (sodium glucose-2) transporter, which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a decrease in blood glucose level. It is effective orally.

The common adverse effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine and also the high risk of fractures.

Other SGLT2 inhibitors include empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and ertugliflozin.

Note: Empagliflozin has been found to decrease the risk of mortality from cardiovascular causes in diabetic patients. Dapagliflozin has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction(HFrEF) in both diabetic and non-diabetic patients.

questions.text: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is caesarean section.

There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.

Forceps can be applied only when the cervix is fully dilated and the head is low down.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who developed severe tachycardia was rushed to the emergency room. The resident begins to massage the carotid region of his neck to bring down the heart rate. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this phenomenon?

choices.text: Increased activity of rostral ventrolateral medulla

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the doctor has performed a carotid sinus massage to slow the heart rate. This stimulates the baroreceptor reflex leading to an increased afferent nerve/ glossopharyngeal nerve firing to the nucleus tractus solitarius. 

Carotid sinus massage

Procedure- It is performed with the patient supine and the head turned slightly away from the side being stimulated. Before performing massage the doctor should always auscultate to check for the presence of carotid bruit. If bruit is present, it should not be performed. The area of the carotid sinus, at the artery’s bifurcation, is palpated with two fingers at the angle of the jaw until a good pulse is felt. A minimal amount of pressure is applied over the carotid sinus. If there is no effect, a side-to-side or rotating motion of the fingers over the site is performed for up to 5 seconds. ECG should be performed to assess the response.

Mechanism

Pressure over the carotid sinus stimulates the baroreceptors. These signals are transmitted through small Hering’s nerves to the glossopharyngeal nerves and then to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. These signals release glutamate and activate the CVLM (caudal ventrolateral medulla). This in turn inhibits RVLM (rostral ventrolateral medulla) considered the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic center. The stimulation of the vagus results in a slowing of impulse generation in the SA node and a slowing of conduction velocity in the AV node. This in total combination results in lowering of blood pressure and heart rate.

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. His erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the best management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given abdominal X-ray shows left staghorn renal calculi. The best treatment option for staghorn renal calculi is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Staghorn calculi is also known as triple phosphate stone. It occupies the renal pelvis and calyces.

PCNL: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney by percutaneous technique and stones are fragmented and removed. It is mainly used in treating large stones and stones in the proximal ureter.

Indications of PCNL:

  • Obstructions caused by anatomical abnormalities like pulviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula or ureteric obstruction
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Stones >2.5 cm in size
  • Stone composition - struvite, calcium oxalate monohydrate and cystine stones
  • Multiple stones
  • Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated
  • Stones not responding for ESWL

Other options:

Option A: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. 

Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Contraindications for ESWL include obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Option C: Percutaneous nephrostomy, or nephropyelostomy, is an interventional procedure that is used in the decompression of the renal collecting system.

It is done in grossly unwell patients due to sepsis secondary to an obstructive urinary tract calculi. They drain pus from the kidneys adequately with less manipulation and a lower risk of septicemia than a ureteric stent.

Option D: Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. Ureteric calculi are directly visualized through semi-rigid ureteroscopes. Stones are then fragmented and extracted using a dormia basket.

Ureteroscopic stone removal using dormia basket is depicted in the image below.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: An HIV-positive male patient is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. The consultant adds emtricitabine, a drug with dual antiviral activity, to his treatment card. This drug belongs to which of the following classes of antiviral agents?
questions.solution:
Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It has activity against HIV-1, HIV-2, and hepatitis B viruses (HBV).

Emtricitabine is an FDA-approved drug for treating HIV infection in adults, children, and infants, in combination with other antiretroviral agents. It is also approved for HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (in combination with tenofovir) in adults with a high risk of acquiring the infection.

It has good oral absorption and can be taken without regard to meals. It is excreted unchanged in the urine and the dose should be reduced in patients with poor renal function.

Emtricitabine is one of the least toxic antiviral drugs. Prolonged exposure can cause hyperpigmentation of the skin, especially in sun-exposed areas. It should not be abruptly discontinued in HBV patients as it can lead to a rebound of HBV replication and exacerbation of hepatitis.

Serological Patterns of Hepatitis B Infection:

  HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc
Acute HBV +   - +  -  IgM
Window period  - -  +/- +/- IgM
Chronic HBV(high infectivity) +  -  +   -  IgG
Chronic HBV(low infectivity) + -  -  +  IgG
Immunized (Vaccination)* -  + -  -   
Immunized (Natural infection) -  +  - -  IgG

 

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine, Etravirine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir

 

 

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Legend

TDF - Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 

3TC - Lamivudine 

FTC - Emtricitabine 

DTG - Dolutegravir 

ATV/r - Atazanavir + ritonavir 

DRV/r - Darunavir + ritonavir 

LPV/r - Lopinavir + ritonavir 

RAL - Raltegravir 

AZT - Zidovudine 

ABC - Abacavir

questions.text:
A 35-year-old pregnant female patient complains of hearing loss, which is aggravated during pregnancy. Tympanometry shows As type of graph. Which of the following statements are true regarding the disease condition?
  1. The disease has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance.
  2. Patients commonly present with bilateral sensory neural hearing loss.
  3. Fissula ante fenestrum is the most common site for the start of the lesion in a stapedial disease.
  4. Pure tone audiometry may reveal Carhart's notch.
  5. Medical treatment with sodium fluoride ear drops is generally avoided.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the tympanometry showing As type of graph are suggestive of otosclerosis. The correct statements regarding the disease include 3, 4, 5.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replace part of the normally dense enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule.

It has an autosomal dominant (statement 1) inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss (statement 2). It is known to be initiated or worsened by stress and hormonal variations during pregnancy, trauma, surgery, and menopause. 

The most common type of otosclerosis is stapedial otosclerosis. Here lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fissula ante fenestram (statement 3). The patients will have painless bilateral conductive hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. 

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This is called paracusis willisii.

On examination, the tympanic membrane may appear normal. In some patients, a reddish hue over the promontory may be visible through the tympanic membrane. This is called the Schwartze sign.

Tuning fork tests and audiometry will reveal the presence of conductive hearing loss. The bone conduction curve may show a dip, which is maximum at 2000Hz, known as Carhart’s notch (statement 4). Tympanogram will show the presence of As type of curve. As type of curve indicates that pressure is normal but compliance is reduced which is seen in otosclerosis.

Medical management with sodium fluoride has been tried to hasten the maturity of active focus and arrest further cochlear loss, but controversies exist and this treatment is not recommended generally (statement 5). Stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis is the treatment of choice.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text:
The lipid profile of a 48-year-old hypertensive male patient is given below. Which of the following antihypertensives would have a beneficial effect on his lipid profile?

Total cholesterol - 320 mg/dL

Low-density lipoproteins - 220 mg/dL

High-density lipoproteins- 40 mg/dL

Triglycerides - 299 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient in the given scenario has a deranged lipid profile. Among the given drugs, prazosin would have a beneficial effect on the lipid profile of this patient as it decreases LDL and triglyceride levels as well as increases HDL levels.

Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 antagonist. It acts by blocking the alpha-1 receptors in the arterioles and veins, thereby decreasing peripheral vascular resistance. It has little or no alpha-2 blocking effect.

Uses:

  • Hypertension
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • In vasospastic disorders like Raynaud's disease

Adverse effects: First-dose phenomenon: Within 30-90 minutes of the initial dose of prazosin or when the dosage is increased, there is marked orthostatic hypotension or syncope. This is known as the first-dose phenomenon. After a few initial doses, tolerance develops to this side effect. Initiating low doses at bedtime is recommended to minimize this phenomenon. Orthostatic hypotension can be a problem with long-term therapy. Other side effects are headache, dizziness, and asthenia.

Other options:

Options A and D- Furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are diuretics, and they cause derangement of lipid profile.

Option C- Propranolol, being a non-selective beta-blocker, causes derangement of the lipid profile. The release of free fatty acids from the adipose tissue is attenuated in the presence of a non-selective beta-blocker. Non-selective receptor antagonists raise triglycerides, lower HDL cholesterol, and raise LDL cholesterol.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient is undergoing a clinical assessment for aphasia. He makes errors in word choice frequently and has obvious difficulty in comprehension. The speech is otherwise effortless and melodic. Other neurological examination findings are within normal limits. Which area of brain damage can result in such a type of aphasia?

choices.text: Posterior temporal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Frontal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Posterior parietal and temporal lobes, non-dominant hemisphere
Prefrontal and frontal regions, dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
The patient described above has Wernicke’s aphasia (WA). This usually occurs as a result of damage in the posterior temporal and parietal regions of the dominant hemisphere, which are supplied by the lower division of the middle cerebral artery.

Aphasia is an acquired disorder of language. Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent language output but impaired comprehension. Gestures do not improve communication. The patient may not realize that their language is incomprehensible and may be associated with severe agitation and paranoia.

Many specific aphasic syndromes have been reported. The most common are Broca, Wernicke, conduction, and global aphasias. Other are non-perisylvian aphasias that include anomic, transcortical motor, transcortical sensory, and mixed transcortical.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with lesions as shown in the image below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: There is perifollicular hyperkeratosis and keratotic papules
It is associated with liver cirrhosis and alcohol abuse
It can be seen in patients after bariatric surgery
It is predominantly associated with a deficiency of vitamin D

questions.solution:
The above image shows phrynoderma or toad skin. All the statements except statement 4 are true. Phrynoderma is predominantly associated with a deficiency of Vitamin A.  

Phrynoderma (toad skin) is common in children in the 5 - 15 year age group. Phrynoderma is not specific to vitamin A deficiency, it is also seen in other nutritional deficiencies including B complex, ribofla­vin, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids, and malnutrition.

It is a non-specific finding that can be associated with: 

• Liver cirrhosis.
• Malabsorption syndromes.
• Anorexia nervosa.
• Alcohol abuse.
• Nutritional deficiency following bariatric surgery.

It manifests as groups of papules, with a central keratotic plug. The papules have a follicular distribution and give the skin a rough texture. The elbows and knees are the most commonly affected areas but the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected.

All patients with phrynoderma should have their Vitamin A levels measured. 

Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of multivitamin preparations containing Vitamin A. 
For children above 8 years and adults - 100,000 units daily for 3 days, followed by 50,000 units daily for 2 weeks and then 10,000 units daily for 2 months till liver stores are replenished.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text:
Which of the following are considered as the best indicators of air pollution?
  1. Sulfur dioxide
  2. Lead
  3. Carbon monoxide
  4. Smoke
  5. Suspended particles
questions.solution:
The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles (1, 4, and 5). 

These indicators are monitored daily and their results are reported to a central agency.

Air pollution is the presence of gases and particulate matter in the atmosphere that affect human health and safety. It is also injurious to animals and vegetation. Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide
  • Smoke or soiling index
  • Grit and dust measurement (suspended particles)
  • Co-efficient of haze 
  • Air pollution index 

Air pollution in India is monitored by the national air quality monitoring program (NAMP). This program is sponsored by the central pollution control board (CPCB). 

Under the NAMP, four air pollutants are regularly monitored. They are sulfur dioxide (SO2), oxides of nitrogen such as NO2, respirable suspended particulate matter (RSPM/ PM10), and fine particulate matter (PM2.5). Monitoring of meteorological parameters like wind speed and direction, relative humidity, and temperature have also been included with the monitoring of air quality. This monitoring is carried out twice a week. 

The health effects of air pollution can be immediate or delayed. Immediate effects include acute bronchitis and suffocation. Delayed adverse effects are carcinoma of the lung and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Air pollutants:

Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide Incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulfur dioxide

Colorless gas
Sharp odor
Combustion of sulfur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc
Main components of acid rain.
Lead Usually occupational and environmental sources
Carbon dioxide Increase in a global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely.
Hydrocarbons Cause photochemical smog
Cadmium From volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc
Hydrogen sulfide Waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc
Ozone Ground-level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog.
Oxides of nitrogen Most common form is nitric oxide
From coal burning, road traffic, and electricity generation
Affects the lungs adversely
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc
Carcinogenic and mutagenic
Particulate matter Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter
Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon, and water.
Common indoor air pollutants

From coal or fuel combustion

Include CO, PAHs, nitrogen and sulfur oxides, pesticides, and other biological pollutants


Radon, lead, asbestos are formed from construction materials, paints, and demolition

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide - one of the best indicator of air pollution
  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
  • Grit and dust measurement 
  • The co-efficient of haze - assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air
  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: A child presents with pain and swelling in the right side of his scrotum and testicular torsion is suspected. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.solution:
In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side. After the de-torsion, the adequacy of the blood flow has to be assessed by Doppler.

In testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis. The patient usually presents with acute onset pain and swelling of the scrotum. On examination, the cremasteric reflex is lost, and the scrotum looks asymmetrical. 

Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion. Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis, and it is seen in epididymo-orchitis.

At the time of surgical exploration, contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed to the dartos fascia in order to prevent possible torsion occurring in this testes.

More than 80% of the testis can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 6 hours. If the testis is found to be necrosed on scrotal exploration, orchidectomy of the necrosed testis and orchidopexy of the contralateral testis is done.

questions.text: Which of the following arterial ligation methods is least preferred to control epistaxis?

choices.text: Retromandibular fossa approach to ligate internal carotid artery
Lynch exploration to ligate the anterior ethmoidal artery
Caldwell-Luc approach to ligate maxillary artery
Transnasal endoscopic approach to ligate sphenopalatine artery

questions.solution:
The retromandibular fossa approach to ligate the internal carotid artery is least preferred in this case. The internal carotid artery is not ligated for controlling epistaxis due to the high percentage of cerebral complications and mortality.

Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control :The first preferred method is transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) (option D). If not controlled, internal maxillary artery ligation is preferred. 

The maxillary artery is ligated transantrally via a Caldwell-Luc approach (option C) and the zone of this procedure is shown below :


If bleeding is still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation is performed. In case, the bleeding site is superior to the level of the middle turbinate, the anterior and posterior ethmoidal vessels should be ligated. The ethmoidal artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery, whereas the sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and facial artery are branches of the external carotid artery. Hence, if the bleeding is not controlled by external carotid artery ligation, the subsequent step would be to ligate the ethmoidal artery. Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external ethmoid (Lynch) incision (option B)

Initial steps in the management of epistaxis are:

Pinching the nose with thumb and index finger for about 5 min. This compresses the Little's area and can stop bleeding.

The patient is made to sit, leaning forward over a basin. He is asked to spit blood and breathe quietly through the mouth. This is called Trotter's method. If these measures cannot control the bleeding, then anterior nasal packing (for anterior bleed) or posterior nasal packing (for posterior bleed) are done.

Little's area is the most common site of epistaxis. This is present in the anteroinferior part of the septum. Four arteries anastomose here to form Kiesselbach’s plexus. They are:

  • anterior ethmoidal
  • septal branch of superior labial
  • septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • greater palatine artery.

Woodruff plexus is plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate. It is a site of posterior epistaxis in adults.

questions.text: When can a patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock be discharged?

choices.text: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.solution:
A patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock can be discharged after the return of appetite. 

Criteria for the discharge of patients recovering from dengue:

  • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs
  • Platelet count >50,000/cu.mm
  • Return of appetite
  • Adequate urine output
  • Visible clinical improvement
  • Minimum of 2-3 days after recovery from shock
  • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion or ascites

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about helminths?

choices.text: Nematodes do not have alimentary canal
Cestodes have tape like, segmented body
Head end of trematodes has suckers and hooklets

questions.solution:
Cestodes are multi-segmented, dorsoventrally flattened tape-like worms whose sizes vary from a few millimeters to several meters.

 

Nematodes have a complete alimentary canal from mouth to anus. They have a body cavity known as pseudocele, in which the viscera is suspended.

 

Trematodes are leaf-like unsegmented parasites. They have suckers but no hooklets.

 

Nematodes generally require 1 host, cestodes require 2 hosts, and trematodes require 3 hosts (with some exceptions).

Related Pearl: Difference between cestodes, trematodes, and nematodes

Features

Cestodes

Trematodes

Nematodes

Shape

Tape-like, segmented

Leaf-like unsegmented

Elongated, cylindrical, unsegmented

Head end

Suckers are present, some have attached hooks

Suckers are present but no hooks

Hooks and suckers are absent. Well-developed buccal capsule with teeth or cutting plates are seen in some species

Alimentary canal

Absent

Present but is incomplete, no anus

Complete with anus

Body cavity

Absent, but it is filled with spongy undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, in the midst of which lie the viscera

Same as cestodes

Present and known as pseudocele. Viscera remains suspended in the pseudocele

Sex

Not separate: hermaphrodite (monecious)

Not separate: hermaphrodite except Schistosoma

Separate (diecious)

Life cycle

Requires 2 host except Hymenolepis (1 host) and Diphyllobothrium (3 host)

 Requires 3 host except schistosoma (2 host)

Requires 1 host except filarial worms

questions.text: In a patient who had a sunbath, ideally till what time should this test be delayed?
questions.solution:
The image shows a patch test, which should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing. The patch test is used to confirm the diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis.

Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. Allergic contact dermatitis to cosmetics usually causes erythema and scaling. The extent of symptoms depends on the product used and where it was applied.

The incidence of cosmetic contact dermatitis has reduced due to strict manufacturing regulations. However, the use of fragrances to improve product appeal may still cause dermatitis. The most common causes of cosmetic allergic contact dermatitis are fragrances and preservatives. 

 

The patch test is used to detect delayed (type IV) hypersensitivity to antigens that come in contact with the skin, by applying the suspected antigen under occlusive patches to the skin. Patches are removed after 48 hours (or sooner if there is itching and burning). The patch site is evaluated 1 hour after removal, on day 2 and on day 4 to detect delayed reactions.

Site - Usually the upper back, or lateral aspect of the arm.

Indications for patch testing:

  • Allergic contact dermatitis
  • Eczematous disorders where contact allergy is suspected
  • Eczematous disorders not responding to treatment
  • Chronic hand and foot eczema
  • Varicose eczema

Patch test should be delayed for 4 weeks after sunbathing, and the patches should not be exposed to the sun or any other UV light. Corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive drugs may falsely reduce positive test responses in sensitized patients. They should be stopped before the patch test, if feasible. However, at doses below 15 mg prednisolone, the response is not likely to be affected. 

The image below shows the patch test.

Acute management of the flare can be done with topical corticosteroids, topical calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus). For severe, extensive involvement, systemic corticosteroids can be used. 

Long-term treatment of allergic contact dermatitis involves avoidance of the allergen. Patch testing can confirm the specific allergen involved. The allergen International Nomenclature Cosmetic Ingredient (INCI) name can be provided to the patient as this is the name that will be used on product labels.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male patient presents to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, he has a contaminated wound in his right forearm. He has received the full course of tetanus immunization and the last booster dose was at 15 years of age. Which of the following is advisable for this patient?

TT- Tetanus Toxoid

choices.text: Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
A male patient with a contaminated wound with a full course of tetanus immunization taken 7 years back will come under category B of post-exposure prophylaxis for tetanus. Hence, he must be given proper wound care and one dose of tetanus toxoid.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in eliciting tickle and itch sensations?
questions.solution:
Itch and tickle sensations are elicited by the stimulation of free nerve endings of unmyelinated type C nerve fibers.

The free nerve ends are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors and are present only in the superficial layers of the skin. After these fibers synapse in the spinal cord, the sensations are carried in the contralateral anterolateral spinothalamic tract.

The same type-C fibers are also involved in carrying sensations of slow pain. The itch sensation calls attention to mild surface stimuli such as a flea crawling on the skin or a fly about to bite. These signals later activate the scratch reflex. This way by scratching one gets relieved of the itch. Sometimes, this scratching action can be strong enough to elicit pain. These pain signals suppress the itch signals in the cord by lateral inhibition. 

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: The image shows the microscopic appearance of the lamellar bone. Identify the structure marked as A.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as A in the above image is Volkmann's canal. The Haversian canals communicate with each other by the transverse perforating canals, which are called Volkmann's canals. 

The Haversian system or osteon constitute most part of the compact bone. Each Haversian system contains a central canal within which the small blood vessels, nerves, and endosteum are present. This canal is surrounded by multiple layers or lamellae of the calcified matrix containing type I collagen fibers. These canals communicate with each other by Volkmann's canal.

Successive lamellae are separated from each other by lacunae containing osteocytes. These osteocytes are in communication with each other, the central canal and the periphery of the osteon via the dendritic processes present within the canaliculi. The parallel lamellae present between osteons is called interstitial lamellae and the parallel lamellae present near the periosteum are called the circumferential lamellae.

On microscopy, osteon can be identified by

  • Presence of Haversian canal with concentric lamellae around it
  • Volkmann's canal
  • Osteocytes with canaliculi
  • Interstitial lamellae
  • Circumferential lamellae

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of necroptosis?

choices.text: Begins similar to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis
Causes recruitment of  RIP1 and RIP3 resulting in caspase activation
Terminal events include permeabilization of lysosomal membranes
Occurs during the formation of mammalian growth plate

questions.solution:
The genetic program that drives necroptosis does not result in caspase activation and hence, it is also sometimes referred to as caspase-independent programmed cell death.

Necroptosis:

This form of cell death is a hybrid that shares aspects of both necrosis and apoptosis.

It resembles necrosis morphologically and biochemically. Both are characterized by loss of ATP, swelling of the cell and organelles, generation of ROS, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and ultimately rupture of the plasma membrane.

It is triggered by genetically programmed signal transduction events that culminate in cell death.  In this respect, it resembles programmed cell death which is the hallmark of apoptosis. But in sharp contrast to apoptosis, it doesn't result in caspase activation.

  • Necroptosis begins similar to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis. It starts with the ligation of TNFR1( Binding of TNF to TNFR1). Ligation of Fas can also trigger necroptosis.
  • Ligation of TNFR1 recruits RIP1 and R1P3 (receptor-associated kinases 1 and 3) into a multiprotein complex that also contains caspase 8.
  • Caspases are not activated and as in necrosis, the terminal events include permeabilization of lysosomal membranes, generation of ROS, damage to the mitochondria, and reduction of ATP levels.

Necroptosis is being recognized as an important death pathway both in physiologic and pathologic conditions. It occurs during the formation of the mammalian growth plate. It is also seen in steatohepatitis and pancreatitis.

Note: Necroptosis starts like apoptosis and ends like necrosis.

questions.text: The image shows the inferior surface of the liver. Which lobe of the liver marked below forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen?
questions.solution:
The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe.

The caudate lobe is visible as a prominence on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver.

 Other markings:

1- Quadrate lobe

2- Left Lobe 

4- Right lobe 

Shown below are 2 views of the visceral surface of the liver -

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac):

  • It forms the communication between the lesser sac and the greater sac.
  • The roof is formed by the caudate process of the liver
  • The floor is formed by the superior part of the duodenum
  • The posterior wall is the peritoneum covering the subhepatic part of the inferior vena cava
  • The anterior wall is a free edge of lesser omentum containing a bile duct, portal vein, and hepatic artery.
  • It serves as a site for an internal hernia.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

Relations of epiploic foramen:

Anterior
  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

 

Relations of lesser sac:

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum
  • Stomach
  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed:

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland
  • Commencement of abdominal aorta and coeliac artery
  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Splenic flexure of the colon
  • Transverse mesocolon

Superior
  • Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Inferior
  • Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: Which is the most inferior structure at the hilum of the left lung?
questions.solution:
The inferior pulmonary vein is the most inferior structure at the hilum of the left lung.

The usual vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum is (ABV)

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

 

The usual vertical sequence of right hilar structures is BABV:

  • Superior lobar (eparterial) bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: A child, upon ingestion of shellfish, developed a tingling sensation in the mouth, swelling of the face, lips, and tongue, and also complained of abdominal pain and dizziness. What type of reaction is this?
questions.solution:
This child who developed tingling in the mouth, and swelling of the lips and face after eating shelf life is an example of an IgE mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. 

Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rapidly and affects the whole body. It is characterized by a sudden release of histamines and other chemicals from the immune system in response to an allergen, such as certain foods, medications, insect stings, or latex. The onset of symptoms can occur within minutes to a few hours after exposure to the allergen.The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. 

Clinically, anaphylaxis can present with a combination of symptoms that typically include:

  • Respiratory Symptoms: Patients often experience wheezing and respiratory distress due to bronchoconstriction. Other signs may include shortness of breath, coughing, and a feeling of tightness in the chest.
  • Skin Symptoms: Urticaria (hives) and angioedema (swelling of the skin and mucous membranes) are common. These skin reactions usually develop rapidly, often within minutes to two hours of exposure to the allergen.
  • Cardiovascular Symptoms: Hypotension (low blood pressure) is a key indicator of anaphylaxis. Patients may also experience tachycardia (increased heart rate) and, in severe cases, shock.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and cramps can occur, particularly if the anaphylaxis is triggered by food allergens.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, or loss of consciousness can occur due to the sudden drop in blood pressure and reduced oxygen supply to the brain.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text:
Arrange the following colour codes used in triage in the increasing order of priority starting with the least priority.
  1. Red
  2. Black 
  3. Yellow
  4. Green
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of triage color coding priority is black (least priority) -> Green -> Yellow -> Red(Highest Priority)

Triage means ‘to sort’ and is essential in the management of mass casualties. It aims to identify the patients in whom treatment at the earliest produces the maximum benefit. It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. 

Priority Colour Medical need Clinical status
First (I) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if the treatment given early
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive if the treatment given within hours
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Note: Reverse triage is used in a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more, allowing for faster turnover. It is followed in this situation to discharge existing patients and to increase the surge capacity of the hospital to accommodate for the natural disaster. Here, non-emergent patients currently admitted to the hospital are discharged to allow for the acute increase in incoming patients.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides like gentamicin act by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit. They cause misreading and premature termination of mRNA translation. 

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin. They are bactericidal and the killing is concentration-dependent.

They are used in the treatment of aerobic gram-negative bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, mycobacterial infections, tularemia, respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis, and other pseudomonal infections. Anaerobic bacteria are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides because the transport of aminoglycosides across the cytoplasmic membrane requires oxygen.  

The adverse effects of aminoglycosides include-

  • Ototoxicity is characterized by irreversible high-frequency hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. Streptomycin and gentamicin are the most vestibulotoxic. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin mainly affect auditory functions. 
  • Nephrotoxicity due to damage to proximal tubular cells. Neomycin is the most nephrotoxic. Streptomycin is the least nephrotoxic.
  • Acute neuromuscular blockade and apnea. Neuromuscular blockade may be reversed by intravenous administration of a Ca2+ salt. 

Other options

Options A and B- Chloramphenicol and clindamycin act by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome.

Option D- Vancomycin is a glycopeptide that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It binds to terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan to inhibit cell wall synthesis.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient had to undergo a cesarean section in a hospital due to a complicated delivery. She was discharged on her 5th-day postpartum. How many visits by an ASHA worker is recommended in this case?
questions.solution:
As this case is an institutional delivery through LSCS, the patient would be discharged after 5-6 days from the hospital, therefore 5 visits by the ASHA worker are recommended here.

The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs. 250 if she completes all her visits.

ASHA visits all newborns on proper schedule up to their 42 days of life. The number of home visits will be,

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42).
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1).
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3).

In case a newborn is discharged from SNCU, then ASHA will receive a full incentive after completing the remaining visits. ASHA will do additional follow-up visits every month for low-birth-weight newborns up to two years, and SNCU discharged babies up to one year. For each follow-up visit, ASHA will receive an additional Rs. 50.

If the woman delivers at her maternal house and returns to her husband’s house or vice versa, the visits might have been done by two ASHAs at the two different places. In such cases, if each ASHA completes at least 3 visits, they will receive Rs 125 each. If ASHA completes less than 3 visits, they will not receive any incentive.

In the case of twins/triplets, then ASHA will receive twice (Rs. 500) or thrice (Rs. 750), the regular payment.

The payments are made to ASHA on the 45th day, subject to the following conditions:

  • The birth weight is recorded in the Maternal and Child Protection (MCP) Card.
  • Ensuring that the newborn is immunized with BCG, first doses of OPV and DPT/Pentavalent, and entered into the MCP card.
  • Enabling birth registration.
  • Both mother and newborn are safe until the 42nd day.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about iodine-based contrast media?

choices.text: They do not interfere with the clotting times.
Iohexol is an ionic iodine-based contrast.
They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.
They are used in magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.solution:
Iodine-based contrast media are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media:

Iodine provides the radio-opacity, while the other compounds act as carriers of iodine. They are commonly used in angiography and computed tomography. They interfere with the clotting times. Hence, clotting tests are usually avoided until 6 hours after the administration of contrast media. They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media are classified as ionic and non-ionic, based on the nature of the compound to which the iodine is bound. Ionic media consists of iodine bound to inorganic compounds, while non-ionic media consists of iodine bound to an organic compound. The common examples of ionic and non-ionic iodine-based contrast media are iothalamate and iohexol, respectively.

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a metered-dose inhaler (MDI). The most common side effect of this device is drug deposition in the oropharynx. 

Most material inhaled using this device will be swallowed and absorbed, entering systemic circulation after undergoing the first-pass effect in the liver. Some drug will also be absorbed into the systemic circulation from the lungs.

The use of a large-volume spacer will reduce the amount of drug deposited in the oropharynx, thereby reducing the amount swallowed and absorbed from the GI tract, thus limiting the systemic effects of the drug.

The given image shows the use of spacer with MDI:

 

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of the drug inhaled into the lower airways.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to small children, as young as 3 years of age, who are not able to use a pMDI (pressurized MDI), as seen in the image below:

 

Pressurized metered-dose inhalers: Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and typically deliver 50–200 doses of the drug.

Dry powder inhalers: Drugs may also be delivered as a dry powder using devices that scatter a fine powder dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. Children less than 7 years of age find it difficult to use a DPI. DPIs have been developed to deliver peptides and proteins, such as insulin, systemically but have proved to be problematic because of the consistency of dosing.

The given image shows various types of dry powder inhalers:

 

Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizers are available. Jet nebulizers are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen), whereas ultrasonic nebulizers use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulized drug may be inspired during tidal breathing, and it is possible to deliver much higher doses of the drug as compared to pMDI. Nebulizers are therefore useful in treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD, for delivering drugs when airway obstruction is extreme (e.g., in severe COPD), for delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices, and for giving drugs such as antibiotics when relatively high doses must be delivered.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady with a known case of hypothyroidism presents with pain and burning of the lateral half of the palm. On examination, her palms appear as shown below and Phalen's test is positive. What is the likely structure under which the affected nerve is compressed?
questions.solution:
The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It is due to compression of the median nerve where it passes under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist.

Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the distribution of the median nerve. There may be a weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted.

Tinel's sign will be positive. This sign is elicited by percussing over the median nerve, reproducing symptoms. In Phalen's test,  the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion for 60 seconds.

Carpal tunnel syndrome can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

The following image shows Phalen's test.

Other options 

Option A- Ligament of Struthers connects the medial epicondyle and the humerus. It is associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve and produces similar symptoms as carpal tunnel syndrome. However, Phalen's test is negative.

Option B- Bicipital aponeurosis is the insertion of the biceps in the cubital fossa. It is also associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve. Phalen's test is negative.

Option C- Guyon's canal: The ulnar nerve can get compressed while passing through Guyon's canal. 

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Posterior tibial nerve

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve

questions.text: In the metabolism of xenobiotics, all of the following are phase 1 reactions except?
questions.solution:
Acetylation is a phase 2 reaction.

Metabolizing enzymes in hepatic cells:

  • Microsomal enzymes - present in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum
  • Non-microsomal enzymes - present in mitochondria and cytoplasm

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: For the engineering team project, Mr. X and Mr. Y were paired up. Mr. X, who is generally a lonely person,  requested a change of partner. When the tutor asked for an explanation for requesting this change, Mr. X replied, 'Mr. Y wants to be left alone.' Which of the following defense mechanisms best explains Mr. X's response?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Mr. X's response can be best explained by the defense mechanism of projection. Projection is when you attribute your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings to someone else.

Mr. X is projecting his wishes by stating that Mr. Y wants to be left alone when in reality it is he who wants to be left alone. Mr. X could have probably done this because of severe prejudice against Mr. Y, or because he senses danger or a bad outcome when paired with Mr. Y. 

Other options-

Option (A): Rationalization is making excuses for your behavior. Had that been the answer, he would have made excuses, such as he’s uncomfortable with Mr. Y. 

Option (C): Displacement would have been the correct answer if Mr. X had shouted at Mr. Y for the tutor having paired them together. Displacement is the shifting of emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

Option (D): Repression refers to subconsciously forgetting something. The scenario does not convey this mechanism.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms would not give a similar positive reaction as shown in the image below?
  1. Streptococci
  2. Neisseria
  3. Staphylococci
  4. Vibrio
  5. Enterococci
questions.solution:
The given image shows a slide with a positive catalase test. Streptococci and enterococci are catalase-negative, and hence do not exhibit this reaction. 

Catalase test: When a microbial colony is placed in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the catalase enzyme degrades H2O2 into H2O and O2. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles.

Clinical application:

People with chronic granulomatous disease have recurrent attacks of infection with catalase-positive organisms.

The test is particularly useful in the differentiation of staphylococci (catalase-positive) from streptococci (catalase-negative).

Catalase positive organisms:

  • Staphylococcus
  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio    
  • Nocardia
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella   
  • Enterobacteriaceae   
  • Listeria
  • Neisseria meningitidis   
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • Yersinia

Catalase negative organisms:

  • Streptococci
  • Enterococci
  • Lactobacillus

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral.
  1. Femoral nerve
  2. Sartorius
  3. Femoral vein
  4. Femoral artery
  5. Adductor longus
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of structures of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral is 5-3-4-1-2 i.e. adductor longus - femoral vein - femoral artery - femoral nerve - sartorius. 

The femoral triangle is an intermuscular space present in the anterior, proximal thigh. It is an inverted and depressed triangular space. The boundaries of the triangle include:

  • Base - inguinal ligament
  • Medial border - adductor longus
  • Lateral border - sartorius
  • Apex - confluence of the sartorius and adductor longus. 

Contents of the femoral triangle from medial to lateral are as follows- deep inguinal lymph nodes, femoral vein, femoral artery, and femoral nerve. 

The cadaveric image given below shows the contents of the femoral triangle.

The image given below shows the muscles forming the floor of the femoral triangle.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room after she sustained a fall on the outstretched hand. Examination reveals a supracondylar fracture of the humerus with injury to the structure marked as '?' in the given image. Which of the following muscle actions is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The muscle action most likely to be affected is the abduction of the thumb.

The structure marked as '?' in the given image is the median nerve in the cubital fossa which is very commonly injured in a supracondylar fracture. Injury to the median nerve affects the abduction of the thumb as this action is carried out by the abductor pollicis brevis muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve.

Identification of the median nerve:

  • In the cubital fossa and forearm- the median nerve is found medial to the brachial artery
  • In the hand- it passes through the carpal tunnel underneath the flexor retinaculum to innervate the muscles of the thenar eminence

Adductor pollicis Deep branch of ulnar nerve Thumb adduction
III. Hypothenar eminence    
Abductor digiti minimi Deep branch of ulnar nerve Little finger abduction
Flexor digiti minimi Deep branch of ulnar nerve Little finger flexion
Opponens digiti minimi Deep branch of ulnar nerve Brings 5th metacarpal anteriorly to oppose the thumb

questions.text: Which of the following gene is involved in Cowden syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cowden syndrome occurs due to the mutation of the PTEN gene.

Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN)-10q23 is a tumor suppressor gene and it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. PTEN gene is a negative regulator of PI3K/AKT signaling. PI3K/AKT signaling normally leads to increased glycolysis and accumulation of upstream glycolytic intermediates. These are then utilized in the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins. By inhibiting this pathway, the PTEN gene keeps a check on the carcinomas caused due to the upregulation of this pathway.

Cowden syndrome is characterized by skin appendage tumors and an increased incidence of epithelial cancers, particularly of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid.

Other options:

Option A- CDKN2A- Involved in familial melanoma and sporadic carcinomas of the pancreas, breast, and esophagus.

Option B- VHL- Codes for von Hippel–Lindau protein and is involved in von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (cerebellar hemangioblastoma, retinal angioma, renal cell carcinoma)

Option C- PTCH- Involved in Gorlin syndrome (basal cell carcinoma, medulloblastoma, several benign tumors)
