Related Pearl: Cowden Disease

Autosomal dominant

Mutation of PTEN gene on chromosome 10q23.3

Components:

  • Hamartomas of all three embryonal cell layers
    • Intestinal hamartomatous polyp – usually ectodermal, most common in colon
  • Facial trichilemmomas – most common feature.
  • Cancer of the
    • Breast (30–50%)
    • Thyroid (10% - Mainly FTC, rarely PTC and Hurthle cell tumors)
    • Endometrium
  • CNS – 2nd most commonly involved system
    • Megalencephaly, ataxia, epilepsy, dysplastic gangliocytoma of cerebellum – Lhermitte Duclos syndrome.
  • Developmental anomalies – high arched palate, adenoid facies, prominent forehead, Hypoplastic mandible.
  • Skin disease – acral keratosis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a bluish bulge is noted on parting the labia. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Management:

Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.

Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.

Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. Larger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.

Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.text: A girl was brought by her parents with an itchy rash as shown in the image below. She also complains of difficulty in climbing stairs. A muscle biopsy reveals peri-fascicular atrophy. Immunohistochemistry revealed positive Myxovirus resistance protein A. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of Gottron's papules along with the history suggestive of proximal muscle weakness and the investigation findings are suggestive of dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy. It is characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations.  

The classic cutaneous features in dermatomyositis include:

  • Gottron’s sign - erythematous to violaceous rash that occur symmetrically over the extensor (dorsal) aspects of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP)/ knuckle joints, elbows, knees, and ankles. Raised erythematous rash over the knuckles is pathognomic of dermatomyositis is called Gottron's papules.
  • Heliotrope rash - erythematous discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema
  • Shawl sign- macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • V sign - rash on the neck and chest in a V shaped manner due to sun exposure.
  • Poikiloderma - areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation, atrophy and telangiectasia
  • Nail fold changes
  • Mechanic's hands
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

In dermatomyositis, skeletal muscle weakness involves proximal muscles in a symmetric manner and the muscle biopsy shows peri-fascicular atrophy. However, the Myxovirus resistance protein A immunohistochemistry test is more specific than biopsy. A highly raised creatinine kinase can help in diagnosis as well.

The image below shows heliotrope rash:

The image below shows the shawl sign:

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis
Age of onset Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years  
Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No
Muscle involvement

Symmetric

Symmetric

Asymmetric
Histopathological Findings

Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates 

Perivascular infiltrates  

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles   
Association with connective tissue disease Scleroderma and mixed connective tissue only Yes Yes
Association with other autoimmune diseases Infrequent Frequent  Infrequent
Association with malignancy Yes (breast, ovarian, lung) and ILD  Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis)  No
Immunotherapy  Responsive  Responsive  Resistant

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried girl comes to the gynecology OPD for vaccination against cervical cancer. Gardasil is administered to her. Which of the following statements about Gardasil is false?

It is protective against CIN and cervical cancer
It is protective against anogenital warts

Gardasil is a quadrivalent vaccine against HPV 6, HPV 11, HPV 16, and HPV 18

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes hard black nodules over scalp hair?
questions.solution:
The hard black nodules over the scalp hair are suggestive of black piedra. It is a fungal infection of the hair shafts caused by Piedraia hortae.

The fungus forms hard, dark, gritty, and superficial nodules on the hair shafts. As the fungus grows into the hair shaft, the hair may fracture easily. It produces sexual spores in its parasitic phase.

Treatment:

  • Shaving or cutting hair (prevents recurrence also)
  • Benzoic acid ointment is used.  

Option B: Trichosporon beigelli causes white piedra or trichosporosis nodosa.

Option C: Corynebacterium tenuis causes trichomycosis axillaris.

Option D: Trichophyton tonsurans causes mainly tinea capitis.

The images below show black piedra infected hair mounted in 30% KOH and the appearance of hair strands, respectively. The dark nodules are formed of dematiaceous hyphae cemented together to form a hard mass.

 

The images given below show white piedra. Superficial, soft, white, grey, or brown nodules can be seen.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child brought by his mother has a history of passing hard stools and straining during defecation. On examination, the lower abdomen feels hard on palpation. All of the following can be used in this child, except _______.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests the features of constipation. All the drugs mentioned above can be used for the treatment of constipation except loperamide.

Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal agent. It acts on peripheral μ-opioid receptors and also has mild anticholinergic properties.

It is used in non-infective diarrhea or diarrhea associated with AIDS. It should not be used in acute infective diarrhea because it inhibits the clearance of toxins or infective organisms. 

It is contraindicated in children less than 2-4 years of age because of serious complications of toxic megacolon. It poorly penetrates the CNS and does not have abuse liability.

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fiber: Bran, psyllium/ ispaghula, methylcellulose, calcium polycarbophil
  • Stool softener: Docusate (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: bisacodyl, sodium picosulfate
    • Anthraquinones: senna, cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: prucalopride
    • Fixed oil: castor oil
    • Prostaglandin analog - lubiprostone

    • Sodium salts: sulfate, phosphate

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding digoxin, except:

choices.text: It is one of the cardiac glycosides
It can cause premature ventricular depolarisations
Hypermagnesemia increases the risk of digitalis induced arrhythmia

questions.solution:
Hypomagnesemia increases the risk of digitalis-induced arrhythmia. 

Digoxin is one of the cardiac glycosides which is derived from the digitalis plant and used clinically.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increase intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

Digoxin is 65–80% absorbed after oral administration. An almost two-third of the metabolite is excreted unchanged by kidney with half-life of 36-40 hours.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity include atrioventricular junctional rhythm, premature ventricular depolarizations, ventricular bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and second-degree AV blockade. After cardiovascular system, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea i.e., GIT effects are more pronounced. Altered color perception can also be seen in case of digoxin toxicity.

Factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity are:

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia- It increases the binding of the digoxin to the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. 
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia- Diuretics, amphotericin B, corticosteroids
  • Drugs that decrease digoxin elimination (inhibitors of P-glycoprotein)- Amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, itraconazole, propafenone, and flecainide
  • Renal failure
  • Hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine examination reveals hematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Microscopic analysis of his renal biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following finding?
questions.solution:
The boy in this clinical scenario has characteristic features of Henoch–Schonlein purpura (HSP).

The renal biopsy in this patient will show mesangial proliferation with mesangial deposition of IgA

  • HSP is a common small-vessel vasculitis in childhood.
  • It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain.
  • About half the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.
  • The nephritis associated with HSP usually follows the onset of the rash
  • The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

questions.text: Second gas effect is related to _____________
questions.solution:
Second gas effect is related to concentration effect. It is seen when nitrous oxide is given in high concentration (66%). It refers to the principle that the concentration of inspired anesthetic gas influences:

  • the alveolar concentration that may be attained
  • the rate at which that concentration may be attained.

Second Gas Effect is seen when nitrous oxide is administered with another inhaled anesthetic. 

Uptake of nitrous oxide from the alveoli into the blood results in a gradient which draws in more nitrous oxide from the anesthetic machine (augmented inflow). If another gas is simultaneously administered, nitrous oxide enhances the uptake of that gas as well. 

Second gas effect is seen with nitrous oxide, not ether or oxygen.

Diffusion hypoxia: It occurs during recovery from nitrous oxide anesthesia when nitrous oxide is suddenly cut off. Nitrous oxide diffuses from the blood to the alveoli and replaces the oxygen which reduces alveolar O2 concentration, resulting in relative hypoxemia.

questions.text: An abdominal aortic aneurysm is operated when its size is greater than __________
questions.solution:
An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient should be considered for repair if >5.5 cm  in diameter (measured by ultrasonography). The annual incidence of rupture rises from 1% or less in aneurysms that are <5.5 cm in diameter to a significant level of nearly 25%, in those that are 7 cm  in diameter.

As open elective surgery (transabdominal) carries a 5% mortality rate, the balance is in favor of elective operation once the maximum diameter is >5.5 cm.

6 monthly follow-up ultrasonographic assessment is indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms <5.5cm in diameter.

Related Pearl: Indications for Operative Repair of Aneurysm

Condition Criteria for surgical repair
Symptomatic aneurysm  Any size
Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >5.5 cm
Descending thoracic aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >6 cm
Abdominal aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >5.5 cm
Popliteal artery aneurysm - asymptomatic >2-3 cm
Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm in Marfan’s syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve >4-5 cm

Rapidly growing aneurysms 

>0.5 cm/year for ascending aortic aneurysms

> 1cm/year for descending aortic aneurysms

questions.text: Richner-Hanhart syndrome is associated with a defect in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Richner- Hanhart syndrome (Tyrosinemia type II) is associated with a defect in tyrosine aminotransferase. It is also called oculocutaneous tyrosinemia. Alternate metabolites of tyrosine are excreted in type II Tyrosinemia.

It is an autosomal recessive condition with onset between ages 2 and 4 years when painful circumscribed calluses develop on the pressure points of the palms and soles.

questions.text: The excitation of a particular cranial nerve leads to a decrease in the heart rate. Through which foramen does this nerve cross the base of the skull?
questions.solution:
Excitation of the vagus nerve leads to a decrease in the heart rate. The vagus nerve passes through the jugular foramen which is marked as 4 in the above image. 

Structures passing through the jugular foramen are the Inferior Petrosal sinus that continues as IJV, Cranial nerves IX, X & XI.

questions.text: Identify the organism & the stain seen in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Helicobacter pylori stained using Warthin-Starry stain.

H.pylori is a Gram-negative spiral rod that is motile by a unipolar tuft of lophotrichous flagella. The bacteria are present only in the mucus overlying the gastric mucosa and do not actually invade into the mucosa.

The given image shows Helicobacter pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

questions.text:
Match the following laboratory findings with their respective interpretations.
Laboratory findings Interpretation
1. Anti-HBs only A. Acute HBV infection
2. HBsAg, HBeAg, IgM Anti-HBc 

B. Recovered from HBV
3. HBsAg, Anti-HBe, IgG Anti-HBc C. Vaccinated against HBV
4. Anti-HBs, IgG Anti-HBc, Anti-HBe D. Inactive HBV carrier state
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Laboratory findings Interpretation
1. Anti-HBs only C. Vaccinated against HBV
2. HBsAg, HBeAg, IgM Anti-HBc 

A. Acute HBV infection
3. HBsAg, Anti-HBe, IgG Anti-HBc D. Inactive HBV carrier state 
4. Anti-HBs, IgG Anti-HBc, Anti-HBe B. Recovered from HBV

 

HBsAg. It usually becomes positive by 1-12 weeks following infection. In resolving acute HBV hepatitis, the HBsAg becomes undetectable by 8 weeks following the onset of jaundice. After HBsAg disappears, anti-HBs antibodies appear and remain detectable lifelong. 

There might be a gap of several weeks between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs. During this window period, the diagnosis of acute hepatitis is made by the presence of IgM anti-HBc antibodies. Anti-HBc antibodies are the first antibodies to appear in the serum. They usually appear within 1-2 weeks after HBsAg becomes positive. 6 months after the acute infection, the IgG subtype of the anti-HBc becomes prominent.

HBeAg and HBV DNA are qualitative and quantitative markers of viral replication respectively. During acute infection, there is a disappearance of HBeAg and the appearance of anti-HBe antibodies. In chronic HBV infection, HBsAg remains detectable and anti-HBs are absent. Furthermore, HBeAg may be present if it is active type of chronic hepatitis.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

+

 - + - IgM +++

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

 - +/- +/- IgM +

Acute HBV - recovery phase

-

 + - +/- IgG +/-
Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman was admitted for right knee arthroplasty. On the 7th postoperative day, she developed a fever and cough with purulent, blood-tinged sputum. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would be the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the chest-Xray showing lobar consolidation with bulging fissure sign are suggestive of late-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia most likely caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.

K. pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. The patient characteristically presents with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission. It can further be classified as:

  • Early-onset HAP, which occurs within 4-5 days of admission and is commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, Escherichia coli, etc.
  • Late-onset HAP occurs >5 days after hospital admission and is usually caused by gram-negative bacteria like Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii.

Pneumonia caused by Klebsiella species shows the following classic chest X-ray findings:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor. 

The following image shows a bulging fissure sign.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used for treatment and include third-generation cephalosporins and beta-lactam antibiotics with beta-lactamase inhibitors. Nosocomial infection with Klebsiella is difficult to treat in many situations as they produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamase and are resistant to many antibiotics.

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia.

Option C: Legionella pneumophila causes community-acquired pneumonia and early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia.

Option D: Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q-fever.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from Uttar Pradesh was rushed to the emergency department with a headache, fever, and blurred vision followed shortly by unresponsiveness to verbal commands. He is suspected to have viral encephalitis. Which of the following transmits this endemic disease?
questions.solution:
Endemic viral encephalitis is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnuii.

It is the leading cause of childhood neurological viral infection in India. In endemic areas such as North India, it typically affects children <15 years of age as by early adulthood, the majority of the population has protective immunity following natural exposure to the virus.

Ardeid birds like herons and egrets are reservoir hosts, while the amplifier hosts are pigs. It is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, and human infection is a tangential dead end.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Which organism has the following cell wall structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria. 

The cell wall of bacteria provides shape and ridigity to the bacterial cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans.

  Gram positive Gram negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulfur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

 

Other options:

Option C: The cell wall of fungi consists of chitin, mannan, and polysaccharides (glucan).

Option D: The cell wall of mycobacteria have mycolic acid, which is responsible for acid fastness.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with new-onset discomfort in his left eye for the last two weeks. He has been using contact lenses for the last three years and recalls two episodes recently when he had showered with his lenses on. He complains of tearing, photophobia, and foreign body sensation in the left eye.  Eye examination findings are given below. Which of the following agents is most useful in the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a ring lesion (stromal infiltrate) of acanthamoeba keratitis and among the above polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB) 0.02% is the is most useful in the treatment for this condition

Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba. It exists as a trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infectious. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia). Human beings acquire by inhalation of cyst or trophozoite, ingestion of cysts, or through traumatized skin or eyes. It presents as two chronic conditions - acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebic encephalitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis

  • Rare protozoal infection of the cornea
  • Occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lens with tap water
  • Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion.
  • Presents as
    • Ring lesion (most common): Ring stromal infiltrates lead to ring stromal abscess
    • Pseudo-dendrites
    • Reticular pattern

Diagnosis:

  • Confocal Microscopy- may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epithelium and double-walled cyst forms
  • Staining: Calcofluor white, acridine orange, lactophenol blue
  • Histopathology- double-walled cysts are seen on H&E. Other stains for Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome or periodic acid-Schiff.
  • Culture: Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. Coli plated on a non-nutrient agar.

 Treatments for this condition include:

  • Polyhexamethyl biguanide (PHMB) 0.02%
  • Chlorhexidine 0.02%
  • Propamidine isothionate (0.1%)
  • Hexamidine
  • Neomycin
  • Paromomycin
  • Clotrimazole
  • Miconazole

All of these treatments are effective if administered by the topical route. Combination therapy can be administered, which includes PHMB with chlorhexidine, or either of these in combination with hexamidine or propamidine. Debridement may be warranted in certain conditions.

Chronic refractory cases may require corneal transplantation and unresponsive cases might need to be managed with enucleation. 

Fluorometholone 0.5% (Option-A) is a treatment option for marginal keratitis which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction against staphylococcal exotoxins which causes subepithelial marginal infiltrates.

Topical cyclosporine 1% (Option-B) is a treatment option for Mooren's ulcer which is an autoimmune disease characterized by peripheral corneal stromal ulceration with subsequent central spread.

Doxycycline (Option-C) is a treatment option for ocular rosacea which may have corneal manifestations that include epithelial erosions, marginal keratitis, corneal thinning and perforation.

The first image shows double-walled cysts of acanthamoeba in normal H&E staining in a patient with advanced brain disease. The second image depicts the cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining. The third image shows the corneal scrapings with multiple cysts wall of acanthamoeba on a plain mount.

questions.text: During your rotation in the forensic medicine and toxicology department, you notice the specimen of a fetus with a  length of 16 cm. What is the age of the fetus likely to be?
questions.solution:
The age of the fetus in months, calculated using the Rule of Haase, is √16 = 4 months. 

Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the fetus in months from its crown-heel length (in cm) in the first 5 months. It is a rough method of calculating the age of the fetus. During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months.

Haase's Modification of Morisson's Law:

During the last five months, the length of the fetus (in cm) divided by five gives the age in months.

Example - A fetus of length 40cm is likely to be 8 months old.

questions.text:
A sample of pleural fluid drawn from a patient with dyspnea is analyzed and the results are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Gross appearance - serosanguineous

White blood cells - 20,000 cells/microlitre

Protein - 6.5 g/dL (serum protein = 6-8g/dL)

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) - 166 U/L (serum LDH = 125-200 U/L)

Triglycerides - 30 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Option 2 - The given pleural fluid analysis satisfies the Light's criteria for an exudative pleural effusion. Of the answer choices given, malignancy is the cause of this patient's pleural effusion (PE).

Light's criteria for the diagnosis of exudative pleural effusion requires the fulfillment of at least one of the following criteria-

  • PE protein/serum protein ratio > 0.5
  • PE LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  • PE LDH > 2/3rds the upper limit of the reference range of serum LDH

These characteristics are specific for exudative etiologies that disrupt the integrity of local pulmonary architecture (parenchyma, interstitium, vasculature, pleura).

 Other options:

Options 1 & 3 - Heart failure and nephrotic syndrome are examples of transudative pleural effusion. These effusions are caused due to the imbalance in hydrostatic and oncotic pressures across a capillary bed and not due to any inflammatory process. They do not satisfy the Light's criteria. 

Option 4 - Chylothorax is an example of exudative pleural effusion. However, the gross appearance of the chylous fluid is usually milky-white (due to the presence of chylomicrons) and the triglyceride content is greater than 100 mg/dL. 

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for:
questions.solution:
The given instrument is Veress Needle. It is used to produce a pneumoperitoneum in direct puncture laparoscopy.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger. Because the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or penetrating a towel clip to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures.

Other options:

Option B: Arthrocentesis or joint aspiration can be done using a simple 18-20 gauge needle attached to a syringe.

Option C: The image below shows the Jamshidi bone marrow biopsy needle.

Option D: The image below shows a cutting-type Vim Silverman liver biopsy needle.

questions.text:
Match the following methods of graphical representations with the appropriate types of data presented using them.
Graphs Type of data
1) Frequency polygons a) Nominal data
2) Histogram b) Interval scale data
3) Bar charts c) Trend of events over time
4) Line diagram d) Continous data
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Graphs Type of data
1) Frequency polygons

b) Interval scale data
2) Histogram

d) Continous data
3) Bar charts

a) Nominal data
4) Line diagram

c) Trend of events over time


Frequency polygons are formed by joining the midpoints of histogram blocks. It is used to represent ratio or interval scale data.

Histogram is a pictorial representation of frequency distribution and is formed by a series of blocks. It is used to represent a continuous group or data. The area under each block is proportional to the frequency.

Bar charts are used to depict nominal scale data. The length of the bar in the diagram is proportional to the magnitude that is represented. It can be simple, multiple, or component bar graphs.

A line diagram is used to depict the trends of events over a period of time.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency room with complaints of fatigue, increased urination, and abdominal pain since the previous night. She was recently treated for severe diarrhea. Fingerstick blood glucose measurement shows a glucose level of 480 mg/dL. The serum potassium level is 4.5 mEq/L. Which of the following statements is true for this condition?
  1. Kussmaul breathing is seen.
  2. ABG analysis shows elevated bicarbonate levels.
  3. Total-body potassium deficit observed.
  4. Serum lipase level is elevated.
  5. Immediate bolus of short-acting regular insulin (0.1 units/kg) IV must be given.

 ABG - Arterial blood gas
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a diabetic patient with fatigue, abdominal pain, and hyperglycemia is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. True statements about diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) are 1, 3, and 5.

This young patient has a medical history significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus and a recent diarrheal illness that acts as a trigger for the hyperglycemic complication of DKA. Other triggers include suboptimal insulin dosing, pregnancy, and use of illicit drugs.

DKA is a complication of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus common in type 1 diabetes mellitus but can also occur in type 2 DM. It occurs in the setting of absolute or relative insulin deficiency along with glucagon excess leading to extreme hyperglycemia.

Clinical features include severe nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and severe volume depletion. Signs include Kussmaul breathing, fruity odor on the patient’s breath, tachycardia, dehydration, and hypotension. 

The diagnosis of DKA is made based on the following parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia >250 mg/dL
  • Ketosis or ketones in the urine
  • Metabolic acidosis with pH <7.4 and HCO3 <15 mEq/L
  • High anion gap due to ketoacids and lactic acidosis

Despite a total body potassium deficit, the serum potassium level at presentation may be mildly elevated (4.5 mEq/L), secondary to acidosis and volume depletion. Due to acidosis and volume depletion, intracellular potassium ions are displaced to the extracellular compartment secondary to the intracellular shift of the hydrogen ions. This results in a total body potassium deficit.

Treatment involves the administration of short-acting regular insulin first as an IV bolus of 0.1 units/kg, followed by 0.1 units/kg/h of continuous IV infusion.  

Note: Since serum amylase levels may be raised in DKA, pancreatitis is a possible differential diagnosis, especially when there is accompanying abdominal pain in the patient. It can be ruled out by measuring serum lipase levels (specific for pancreatitis), which are normal in DKA. 

Criteria for resolution of ketoacidosis:

  • Blood glucose <200 mg/dL, and
  • Two of the following criteria:
    • Serum bicarbonate level ≥15 mEq/L
    • Venous pH >7.3
    • Anion gap ≤12 mEq/L

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with right wrist pain. She says that the pain aggravates while working and improves with rest. On examination, there is local tenderness in the area of the dorsal radial styloid. There is no limitation of motion, but the ulnar deviation is very painful. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of De Quervain's disease.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work.
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid.
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test - The examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons.

Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

Other options:

The site of pain and tenderness can be diagnostic

Condition Site of pain
Kienböck’s disease Over the lunate
Scaphoid fracture Anatomical snuffbox
Carpometacarpal osteoarthritis The base of the first metacarpal


Note: Kienböck’s disease is the traumatic softening of the lunate bone. This condition is characterized by ischemic necrosis which may be due to chronic stress or injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the disinfection of bins that store COVID 19 waste?
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite is used for the disinfection of bins that store COVID 19 waste.

According to the Central pollution control board(CPCB) guidelines, daily disinfection of both the inner and outer surfaces of the containers/ bins/ trolleys used for storage of COVID 19 waste should be done with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution.

Option B: Methyl alcohol is useful in cleaning cabinets and incubators.

Option C: Isopropyl alcohol is used to disinfect clinical thermometers. It is also used as a skin antiseptic at concentrations of 60-90% in water.

Option D: Glutaraldehyde is useful in the sterilization of bronchoscopes, cystoscopes, plastic endotracheal tubes, rubber anesthetic tubes, and polythene tubings.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used
COLOUR OF THE BIN PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT(PPE) OTHER WASTE
Red Bin
  • Goggles
  • Face shield 
  • Splash-proof apron
  • Plastic coverall
  • Hazmat suit
  • Nitrile gloves
  • Used gloves

Laboratory waste

  • Pre-treated viral transport media
  • Plastic vials and cryovials
  • Vacutainers
  • Eppendorf tubes
  • Pipette tips
Yellow Bin
  • Used mask(triple layer mask, N95 mask)
  • Head cover/Cap, Shoe cover
  • Disposable linen gown 
  • Non-plastic/Semi-plastic coverall

 

  • Diapers with feces of immobile COVID 19 patients

questions.text: A patient with prolactinoma has been prescribed bromocriptine. Which of the following would you advise her regarding the use of this drug?

choices.text: It can worsen her glycemic control
Headache and hypertension can occur on initial use.
It should be started at a low dose, orally administered at bedtime with a snack.
Single oral dose in the morning is sufficient as elimination is very slow.

questions.solution:
Bromocriptine is used in the management of prolactinoma. It should be started at a low dose administered at bedtime with a snack to avoid the side effects on initial use.

It is a semisynthetic ergot alkaloid with D2 receptor agonism. The oral absorption of bromocriptine is good but only 7% of the dose reaches the systemic circulation because of extensive first-pass metabolism in the liver. Bromocriptine has a short elimination t 1/2 (between 2 to 8 hours) and thus it should be given in multiple divided doses. A slow-release formulation of bromocriptine is also available now which can be used vaginally (2.5 mg once daily).

Side effects of bromocriptine:

  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Headache
  • Postural hypotension (occurs on initial use)
  • Nasal congestion
  • Digital vasospasm (Should be avoided in peripheral vascular diseases)
  • CNS effects such as psychosis, hallucinations, nightmares, or insomnia  

The adverse effects can be avoided by starting at a low dose (1.25 mg) administered at bedtime with a snack and then slowly increasing the dose as required by monitoring the prolactin levels. Patients often develop tolerance to the adverse effects after a period.

Uses of bromocriptine:

  • Hyperprolactinemia due to macroprolactinomas causing galactorrhoea, amenorrhea, and infertility in women
  • Parkinsonism 
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus (improves glycemic control along with diet and exercise)
  • Supression of lactation

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma?

choices.text: Poor prognosis compared to classical HL

questions.solution:
Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL) has an excellent prognosis.

Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL) is seen in young males <35 years. They present with cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The involved nodes have a nodular infiltrate of mainly small lymphocytes and macrophages, eosinophils, and plasma cells are scanty. It is not associated with EBV. 

L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell that has multilobed nucleus resembling a popcorn kernel (popcorn cell) is seen. Immunophenotyping shows CD20 +, BCL6 +, CD15 -, CD30 -. It has an excellent prognosis. 

The image shows the L&H variant of RS cell (popcorn cell) which is seen in NLPHL type of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding Hashimoto's thyroiditis:
  1. It most commonly causes hyperthyroidism.
  2. Antibodies against thyroid peroxidase are seen. 
  3. Thyroid profile shows low TSH and high T4.
  4. It is associated with thyroid lymphomas.

TSH - Thyroid-stimulating hormone

T4 - Thyroxine
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are correct regarding Hashimoto's thyroiditis. It is characterized by the presence of antibodies against thyroid peroxidase and is associated with thyroid lymphomas.

Statements 1 and 3 are false. Hashimoto's thyroiditis, most commonly causing hypothyroidism (not hyperthyroidism), is associated with high TSH and low T4 levels (not low TSH and high T4). 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.

It occurs most commonly among middle-aged women. It is associated with malignant lymphoma of thyroid.

Patients present with painless diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism. However, initially few patients may present with a transient hyperthyroid state, known as hashitoxicosis, due to the release of thyroid hormones by disruption of the thyroid follicles.

Laboratory investigations:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Presence of autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

Histopathology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres.
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells.

Hürthle cells arise from the follicular epithelium. These oncocytic cells include an eosinophilic granular cytoplasm.

The following image shows a histopathological picture of Hashimoto thyroiditis :

 

Note:

  • Low TSH and high T4 levels can be seen in hyperthyroidism. Causes of hyperthyroidism includes Grave's disease, toxic goitre, and toxic adenoma.
  • Low TSH and normal T4 levels are seen in subclinical hyperthyroidism.
  • High TSH and normal T4 levels are seen in subclinical hypothyroidism.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text: You are assisting on a left partial nephrectomy in a child with Wilms tumor. Intraoperatively, a small mass is noted on the right kidney as well. Frozen section reveals it to be a Wilms tumor. What is the stage of Wilm's tumor in this child?
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor with involvement of both kidneys is stage 5.

Children’s Oncology Group (COG) Staging System

Stage I

Tumor confined to the kidney and completely resected with negative lymph nodes.

Stage II

Tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely resected with negative margins and lymph nodes.

Stage III

Residual tumor present following surgery confined to the abdomen, including gross or microscopic tumor.

Stage IV

Hematogenous metastases (lung, liver, bone, brain, etc.)

or lymph node metastases outside the abdominopelvic region

Stage V

Metastasis to opposite kidney (bilateral renal involvement)

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man files a case against a surgeon who left a cotton swab within him after a hernia repair. Which of the following best describes this scenario of medical negligence?

BNSS- Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita
questions.solution:
Res ipsa loquitur best describes this scenario under medical negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur means the facts of the case speak for themselves.

Normally, in cases of medical negligence, the burden of proof lies on the patient to prove the doctor guilty. However, the patient need not prove any negligence under Res ipsa loquitur.

The conditions to be fulfilled for Res Ipsa Loquitur are:

  • The injury or damage would not have occurred without negligence
  • The doctor is in exclusive control of the instrumentation or circumstances
  • The patient must not contribute to his own injury or damage

Several situations can be used as defences by the doctor against medical negligence. This includes no duty owed to the plaintiff/ patient, the doctor's duty has been discharged according to prevailing standards, a scenario of misadventure that may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental, or an error of judgment.

Other options:

Option A: Res judicata - BNSS Section 337 (CrPC 300) states that if a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option C: Limitation or Res indicata indicates that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a particular contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Option D: Novus Actus Interveniens is a situation where the cause of disability or death passes from the doctor to a later negligent action of some other person. It means a person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. For a plea of Novus actus, an element of negligence is absolutely essential.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD?
  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
In COPD, the functional residual capacity increases. Total lung capacity may be increased or normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct.

  • In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduces, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases.
  • The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while increased in emphysema.
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. In COPD, FRC is increased.
     

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

∼5.8 L

∼4.5 L

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of nausea, muscle weakness, and a sense of extreme fatigue. He is a known case of CKD on treatment with enalapril. His ECG is given below. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows peaked T waves, flattened P waves, and broad QRS complexes, suggesting hyperkalemia. This patient also has chronic kidney disease and is on treatment with an ACE inhibitor, enalapril. Both of these factors are independent risk factors for hyperkalemia. The first step in the management of hyperkalemia is the administration of IV calcium gluconate.

ECG changes seen in hyperkalemia vary with the level of serum K+ (normal serum K+ is 3.5-5.5 mEq/L):

  • 5.5-6.5 mEq/L- tall, peaked T waves
  • 6.5-7.5 mEq/L- flattening of P waves
  • 7.0-8.0 mEq/L - widening of QRS complexes
  • >8.0 mEq/L - sine wave pattern of ECG

The resting membrane potential of excitable cells is close to the resting membrane potential for K+. In the resting state, there is a constant leakage of K+ out of the cell. If the K+ is higher in the extracellular environment (hyperkalemia), less K+ will leak out of the cell because the gradient is unfavorable. This increases the positive charge inside the cell, leading to the membrane potential being pushed more toward the threshold. In other words, the cell is now more excitable. 

Calcium administration counteracts this by reducing the excitability of the cells and maintaining the membrane potential at the actual resting value. Calcium is administered by intravenous infusion over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. The effect of the infusion lasts for up to 60 minutes. During this time, the steps to correct K+ levels can be taken. These steps include:

  • 10 units of IV insulin followed immediately by 50 mL 50% dextrose bolus
  • Inhaled β2 agonists such as albuterol
  • Cation exchange resins such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate and patiromer can be used for the management of both acute and chronic hyperkalemia
  • Hemodialysis is the most effective method to reduce K+ concentration

Note that intravenous bicarbonate administration does not have a role in the management of acute hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
As a part of the pre-operative evaluation of a patient posted for cataract surgery, you are asked to calculate the power of the intraocular lens to be implanted. What investigations would you perform?
  1. Biometry
  2. Pachymetry
  3. Tonometry
  4. Keratometry
  5. Gonioscopy
questions.solution:
The investigations commonly performed for calculating the power of the intraocular lens (IOL) include biometry and keratometry. 

The power of an intraocular lens (IOL) is calculated using a biometer, a procedure called biometry. Keratometry involves determining the curvature of the anterior corneal surface (the steepest and flattest meridians), and it is expressed in dioptres or millimetres of radius of curvature.

Optical coherence biometry is a noncontact method of measuring axial length. Modern biometry devices also perform keratometry, anterior chamber depth, and corneal measurement and can calculate IOL power using a range of formulas. 

 The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called the SRK formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where, 

  • P is the power of IOL
  • A is a constant, which is specific for each lens type
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in millimeters, determined by using the A-scan ultrasonography
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

 The images given below show a biometer and a keratometer, respectively.  

A-scan ultrasonography is used for determining the axial length of the eyeball. It can be acquired by direct contact or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography). Unfortunately, it is a slightly less accurate method of determining the axial dimension.

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor. A-scan ultrasonography is shown in the image below.

Other options: 

Pachymetry measures corneal thickness. It is shown in the image below.

Tonometry measures intraocular pressure. It is shown in the image below.

Gonioscopy is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber. It also aids in the localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle. The given instrument below is an indirect gonioscope.

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text: A newborn baby born to a mother with Grave's disease had aplasia cutis congenita as shown in the image below. Which of the following anti-thyroid drugs is most likely to be associated with causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows aplasia cutis congenita of the newborn depicting the absence of scalp hair and skin along with calvarial defects. This is commonly associated with methimazole.

Methimazole crosses the placenta to a greater degree than propylthiouracil and has been associated with fetal aplasia cutis. It is also associated with methimazole embryopathy, which includes esophageal or choanal atresia. Thus, when available, propylthiouracil should be used in the first trimester followed by the usage of methimazole during the second trimester. 

 

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole  

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, tracheoesophageal fistula and fetal goiter
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: After intubating a patient for the first time, an intern was asked to confirm that the tube was inserted correctly into the trachea. Which of the following is not a sign of correct endotracheal intubation?

choices.text: Detection of end tidal CO2 by capnography
Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube

questions.solution:
Breath sounds in the epigastrium is a sign of esophageal intubation. Endotracheal intubation is characterized by the absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Signs to confirm proper endotracheal intubation are:

  • Symmetrical chest rise
  • Presence of equal bilateral breath sounds over the chest
  • Absent breath sounds over the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volume
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation.
  • Normal capnography

The most important and objective method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is capnography. 

Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2. It is the most reliable indicator of proper placement of the endotracheal tube (ETT) following intubation. Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram represents the CO2 waveform displayed on the capnograph.

The given image shows the normal waveforms in a capnogram.

 

Esophageal intubation: initial end-tidal CO2 may be detected due to swallowed air but later becomes zero. There would be an absence of breath sounds bilaterally over the chest with the presence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Capnography in esophageal intubation:

 

If the ETT is inserted too deep, it can lead to endobronchial intubation. If inserted too shallow, it can lead to accidental extubation. Thus, an adequate-sized tube should be placed with its tip midway between the vocal cords and the carina.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A female child is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea and short stature. An ultrasound was done, and it showed a small uterus and streak ovaries. Which of the following cardiac anomaly is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of primary amenorrhea and short stature along with streak ovaries in the ultrasound is suggestive of Turner syndrome. It is frequently associated with left-sided cardiovascular anomalies like bicuspid aortic valves.

Turner syndrome occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes. It produces hypogonadism in phenotypic females.

Clinical findings include webbing of the neck, protruding ears, and lymphedema of the hands and feet, short stature. The gonads are streaks of fibrous tissue, known as gonadal dysgenesis. There is primary amenorrhea and a lack of secondary sex characteristics. Congenital heart anomalies and structural renal anomalies are common.

Cardiac anomalies in Turner syndrome: Common defects are bicuspid aortic valves, coarctation of the aorta, aortic stenosis, and mitral valve prolapse. Cardiovascular abnormalities are the most important cause of mortality.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

45 X mosaicism

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy complains of being bullied in school for his high-pitched voice. A Gutzmann’s pressure test is done which helps you to diagnose his condition. What condition does he have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a positive Gutzmann’s pressure test is suggestive of puberphonia.

It is a condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males. They continue to speak in the prepubertal high pitched voice.

Gutzmann's pressure test is positive when pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and produces a low tone voice. The treatment is speech therapy.

questions.text:
Abuse of which of the following drugs will lead to the finding as shown in the image below?
  1. Heroin
  2. Cocaine
  3. Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD)
  4. Mescaline
  5. Cannabis
questions.solution:
The given image shows circular depressed skin popping scars in this patient. Among the given options, opioids like heroin and cocaine abuse ( 1 and 2) can lead to this.

Skin popping is a method of injecting illicit drugs into the skin. Illicit drugs like heroin, cocaine, and barbiturates are injected by this method. It has slower absorption, decreased risk of overdose, and easier administration when compared to intravenous drug use. Skin popping scars point to possible drug use.

Opioids can be taken orally, snorted, or injected intravenously. It results in a euphoric high, especially with the intravenous route. The associated features are heaviness of the extremities, dry mouth, itchy face, and facial flushing. It can result in constipation, pupillary constriction, and changes in blood pressure. The clinical triad of coma, pinpoint pupils, and respiratory depression points are suggestive of opioid overdose. Respiratory depression can even lead to death.

Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), mescaline (hallucinogen), and cannabis are not usually taken through injections, but commonly by oral route or through smoking.

Head-to-toe examination in cases of substance abuse becomes important to look for such skin findings. Long-term use of cocaine can result in cocaine nose, with perforation of the nasal septum, as seen in the image below.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Opioids

  • Post thoracotomy pain managed by: IV fentanyl
  • Drug of choice for controlling severe pain in cancer patients: Morphine
  • Drug of choice for OPD analgesia: Alfentanyl
  • Most potent: sufentanyl
  • Shortest acting opioid-remifentanyl
