questions.text:
Match the following slides of the causative organisms with their systemic mycosis.

             I. Valley fever

            II. Darling's disease

           III. Brazilian blastomycosis 

            IV. North American blastomycosis
questions.solution:
The correct answer is a-II, b-IV, c-I, d-III

a- Histoplasma II- Darling's disease
b- Blastomyces IV- North American blastomycosis
c- Coccidioides I- Valley fever
d- Para-coccidioidomycosis III- Brazilian blastomycosis 

Slide-a shows tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response suggestive of Histoplasma capsulatum that causes histoplasmosis/ Darling's disease/ reticuloendotheliosis.

Patients present with fever, cough, anorexia, and lymphadenopathy. X-ray of the chest shows focal infiltrates and patchy opacities. Aspiration from lymph nodes shows the presence of intracellular yeast.

Slide-b showing thick-walled round yeast cells with single broad-based budding depicting the figure of 8 appearance is suggestive of Blastomyces dermatitidis that causes North American blastomycosis. 

It is mostly seen in North America and is contracted through the inhalation of contaminated soil. Primary infection usually presents as pneumonia.  Chest X-ray reveals consolidation. Disseminated disease may lead to multiple abscesses. Cutaneous lesions present as papules and nodules which progress into large ulcerative lesions.

Slide-c showing mature spherules which are large sac-like structures filled with endospores is suggestive of Coccidioides immitis that causes Valley Fever.

Patients present with fever, cough, and severe fatigue. They may complain of night sweats and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal lymphadenopathy. It is most commonly seen in travelers to the southwestern USA.

Slide-d showing round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferentially giving rise to mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance is suggestive of Paracoccidioidomycosis brasiliensis that causes Brazilian blastomycosis/ South American blastomycosis/ Paracoccidioidal granuloma.

Patients present with fever, fatigue, and weight loss. On examination, multiple oral lesions and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. Granulomas are seen on a biopsy of the affected tissues.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following statement best describes a partial agonist?

choices.text: High affinity and high intrinsic activity
High affinity and low intrinsic activity
Low affinity and high intrinsic activity
High affinity and zero intrinsic activity

questions.solution:
Partial agonists have high affinity and low intrinsic activity.

According to the receptor occupation theory, the ability of a drug to bind to a receptor is its affinity, and the ability to induce functional change in the receptor is designated as the intrinsic activity (IA) of the drug. These 2 properties are independent of each other.

  • Full agonists: These agents have both affinity and maximum intrinsic activity. Examples are histamine, adrenaline, etc.
  • Partial agonists: They have affinity but submaximal intrinsic activity. e.g pentazocine on µ opiod receptors.
  • Inverse agonists are drugs that have an affinity for a receptor but the intrinsic activity is opposite to that of an agonist. Eg: chlorpheniramine on H1 receptors.
  • Competitive antagonists: These agents have affinity and no intrinsic activity. Eg:propanolol, atropine etc.

The intrinsic activities of the above groups of drugs are given below:

Type of drugs

Intrinsic activity

Agonists

1

Partial agonists

>0 to <1

Competitive antagonists

0

Inverse agonists

<0 to -1

questions.text: After a recent event of severe floods in a metropolitan city, the local government has planned to implement certain measures which include floodwater diversion and storage, building new underground sewage lines with increased capacity, performing land surveys, and limit the construction of new buildings in flood-impacted areas.  The given measures are part of which of the following phases of disaster management?
questions.solution:
The measures given in the question, are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation includes measures taken to prevent hazards from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures include:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

Other options:

  • Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.
  • Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. Some of these measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, and personal hygiene, and vector control.
  • Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities, which include the development of policies or programs for disaster management, prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is well prepared to face any future disasters, and effectively prevent or manage to reduce the impact.

Disaster management cycle:

questions.text:
A neonate is brought to the hospital with complaints of projectile non-bilious vomiting after feeding. An ultrasound study was done and the image is given below. Which of the following barium study signs can be seen in this condition?
  1. Shoulder sign
  2. Coffee bean sign 
  3. String sign
  4. Double-track sign
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the USG findings are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). The coffee bean sign is not seen in CHPS. It is seen in sigmoid volvulus. The USG image in the question shows the cervix sign and the antral nipple sign.

Contrast studies :

  • String sign - It refers to the string-like appearance produced by the elongated pylorus with a narrow lumen as shown in the image.
  • Double-track sign - The puckering of the mucosa produces a duplicated appearance of the pylorus.
  • Caterpillar sign - Gastric hyperperistaltic waves.
  • Shoulder sign - It is produced due to the indentation of pylorus into the fluid-filled antrum.
  • Mushroom sign - It is produced due to the indentation of pylorus into the base of the duodenal bulb.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) refers to the idiopathic thickening of gastric py­loric musculature which then results in progressive gastric outlet obstruction. It is more common in first-born male babies. The common age of presentation is 2-8 weeks.

The infants present with progressively worsening non-bilious projectile vomiting. The presence of an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen is pathognomonic. Characteristic metabolic abnormality includes hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrent vomiting. 

Ultrasound is the first investigation of choice. A pyloric length greater than 16 mm and the transverse diameter of the pyloric muscle greater than 4 mm is diagnostic. Findings seen in ultrasound of CHPS are:

  • Antral nipple sign - It is produced by the double-layered pyloric mucosa protruding into the gastric antrum.
  • Cervix sign - It refers to the uterine cervix-like appearance produced due to the hypertrophic pyloric mucosa.

The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected preoperatively. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of a road traffic accident. The finding in the axial CT image is as shown below. It is most commonly caused due to bleeding from _________
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, characteristic of an extradural hemorrhage. It is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery.

As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

The thin squamous temporal bone is the common site of injury. The hematoma usually lies beneath a fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone. The underlying brain is displaced but often appears intrinsically normal.

Note:

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Parietal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone

The pterion is an important landmark because it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Identify the area of insertion of the deep fibers of the gluteus maximus muscle in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
The gluteus maximus muscle, which is the chief extensor of the thigh at the hip joint, has superficial and deep fibers. The deep fibers insert into the gluteal tuberosity which is the area labeled as 4 in the given image. The superficial fibers insert into the iliotibial tract. 

The other areas labeled in the image are:

1 - Greater trochanter- Insertion of gluteus medius and gluteus minimus

2 - Intertrochanteric crest 

3 - Lesser trochanter- Insertion of psoas major, iliacus

 

Gluteus maximus muscle is supplied by the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2). It is an antigravity muscle and it plays a key role in standing up from a sitting position and maintaining an erect posture. Its other actions include lateral rotation and abduction of the thigh and knee stabilization in conjunction with tensor fasciae latae muscle. 

In this patient with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), gluteus maximus paralysis impairs his ability to stand up from a sitting position. This leads to a characteristic sign wherein, to stand up, the patient initially takes supports by placing his hands on his legs and then on his thighs, rising up using this support. This is known as the Gower sign. It is seen in conditions causing weakness of the pelvic girdle and/or proximal muscles of the lower limbs such as DMD, Becker muscular dystrophy, spinal muscular dystrophy, polymyositis, etc. 

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

questions.text: Analysis expressing results of health care benefits in terms of results achieved, like the number of lives saved, instead of monetary benefit is called ______________
questions.solution:
Cost-effective analysis: The benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (Eg: the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. But in many cases, it is not possible to use cost-effective analysis.

Other options:

Cost-benefit analysis: Here the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to identify whether it is economically sound and to select the best one from several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits of a particular program in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. Usually, the benefits are expressed in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Input-output analysis: How much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, the term "input" refers to all health-related activities which consume resources, and "output" refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated or lives saved.

Network analysis: A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities that should be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Management Methods in Health Programmes:

Methods based on behavioral sciences

Quantitative methods

Organizational design

Personnel management

Communication

Information systems

Management by objectives(MBO)

Cost–Benefit analysis

Cost-Effective analysis

Cost–Accounting

Input–Output analysis

Model

Systems analysis

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text: According to the modified Duke criteria, a single positive blood culture is included in the major criteria for which organism?
questions.solution:
According to modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800 is included in the major criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A budding athlete who is keen to participate in long races visits his dietician for a discussion on his exercise capacity. When an athlete runs at a speed typical for the marathon race,  the time until complete exhaustion is maximal with which of the following diets?
questions.solution:
When athletes run at speeds typical for the marathon race, the time that they can sustain the race until complete exhaustion (also known as endurance) is maximal with a high-carbohydrate diet.

A person, who consumes a high-carbohydrate diet, stores far more glycogen in muscles than does a person who consumes either a mixed diet or a high-fat diet. Therefore, endurance is enhanced by a high-carbohydrate diet.

When athletes run at speeds typical for the marathon race, their endurance is approximately the following:

Diet Minutes

High-carbohydrate diet 

 240
 Mixed diet 120
 High-fat diet 85

questions.text: Chimeric DNA is associated with:
questions.solution:
Chimeric DNA is associated with organ transplantation, especially bone-marrow transplantation. 

In organ transplantation, chimeric DNA refers to the mixture of donor and recipient genetic material that occurs when donor cells begin functioning within the recipient's body. It is used for long-term monitoring of bone marrow transplant recipients. Detecting changes in the levels of donor-derived cells can provide early warning signs of graft failure, rejection, or relapse of underlying disease. 

Note: The practical applications of recombinant DNA technology include:

  • Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
  • Producing proteins such as:
    • Interferons, tPA (tissue plasminogen activator)
    • Insulin, growth hormone
    • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  • Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)
  • Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  • Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following is the electrocardiograph changes seen in early stages of acute pericarditis?

choices.text: ST-segment depression with flat T waves
ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression

questions.solution:
ECG showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression is seen in early stages of acute pericarditis.

The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolves through four stages:

  • Stage 1- Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. 
  • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
  • Stage 3 - Diffuse T wave inversion
  • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months

Echocardiography findings are usually normal or may show evidence of a pericardial effusion. If abnormal, regular echocardiographic monitoring is recommended.

The ECG below shows acute pericarditis causing diffuse ST-segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V2 to V6, with reciprocal ST depressions in lead aVR.

Other options:

Option A: ST-segment depression with flat T waves are seen in hypokalemia. Prolongation of QT interval is also seen.

ECG given below shows ST depression and broad flat T waves seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Electrical alternans of P, QRS, and T waves are seen in cardiac tamponade.

ECG given below shows electrical alterans seen in cardiac tamponade.

Option D: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.

ECG given below shows tall peaked T waves seen in hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with a small depigmented lesion which has been there for over 2 years now as shown in the image below. General physical examination also revealed an isolated mucosal lesion on one specific site of the oral cavity. What is the most specific diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes an isolated depigmented lesion that is not segmentally distributed and has not progressed in the last 2 years, and it is associated with an isolated mucosal lesion. These features are suggestive of undetermined vitiligo. Focal lesions and isolated mucosal lesions on one site are considered as undetermined /unclassified vitiligo. 

Vitiligo is a localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes in the basal layer of skin. It is classified as

  • Segmental vitiligo- which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern
  • Non-segmental vitiligo- which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body. Non-segmental can either be focal vitiligo or undetermined/unclassified vitiligo.

According to a recent Vitiligo Global Issue Consensus Conference, the term ‘vitiligo’ can be used as an umbrella term for all non‐segmental forms of vitiligo (including several variants: acrofacial, mucosal, generalized, universal, mixed, and rare variants of vitiligo). The classification is shown below.


Vitiligo (Non segmental)
  • Acrofacial
  • Mucosal (>1 one mucosal site)
  • Generalized
  • Universal
  • Mixed (associated with SV)
  • Rare variants
Segmental vitiligo
  • Uni-, bi-, or pleuri-segmental

Undetermined/

unclassified vitiligo
  • Focal
  • Mucosal (one site in isolation)

Clinical features:

The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. 

Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Koebner phenomenon is seen, which is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Vitiligo universalis, which is complete vitiligo, or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, hyperpigmentation, as well as areas of normal skin may be seen rarely.

Several autoimmune conditions can be associated with vitiligo. They are:

  • Thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism)
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Addison disease
  • Diabetes
  • Hypoparathyroidism

Examination:

Under the Wood's lamp examination the depigmented areas emit a bright blue-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated. 

Treatment:

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and the use of sunscreen. The topical application of corticosteroids is the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus, tacrolimus have also shown to be successful. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin, selective ultraviolet B therapy are used as second-line treatment. In patients who do not respond to this treatment, surgical grafting techniques can be used, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non pigmented area. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Other options:

Option-C: Segmental vitiligo: Localized unilateral depigmented macules. This may be associated with a history of leukotrichia.

The image below shows segmental vitiligo:

 

Option-D: Piebaldism: It commonly presents with a white V-shaped forelock. It is caused due to the impaired migration of melanocytes to the skin, resulting in hypopigmented patches.

The image below shows piebaldism:

Related Pearl: Algorithm for the differential diagnosis of Hypomelanosis

questions.text: Gettler’s test is positive in:
questions.solution:
Gettler test is done for drowning. It estimates the chloride content of blood from both sides of the heart.

Normally, chloride content is equal in the right and left chambers of the heart (approx. 600 mg/100 ml). In freshwater drowning, due to hemodilution, the chloride content is decreased on the left side of the heart by 50%. In saltwater drowning due to hemoconcentration, the chloride content is increased in the left side of the heart by 30-40%.

This test is said to be negative in post-mortem drowning. 

Limitations of the test:

No value in atypical drowning, or congenital cardiac defects, if the drowning medium contains the same amount of chloride. There is a progressive loss of chlorine from blood after death. Therefore, the test has to be made within a reasonably short time after death.

Drowning:

Drowning is the process of experiencing respiratory impairment from submersion/immersion in liquid. Accidental drowning is the most common form of drowning, seen among fishermen, bathers, dock workers, intoxicated, and epileptics.

Pathophysiology:

In cases of seawater drowning, hypernatremia and myocardial anoxia are seen. Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing hemoconcentration and a fall in blood pressure.

This hemoconcentration in seawater drowning causes increased viscosity of blood and myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure. Hyperkalemia is not seen in seawater drowning because RBCs get shrunken in contrast to freshwater drowning.

Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma and is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli into the RBCs resulting in hemodilution and hyponatremia. The RBCs finally swell up and lyse resulting in the release of intracellular potassium causing hyperkalemia. Increased intravascular blood volume combined with hyperkalemia causes arrhythmia.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed or when sectioned with a knife. 
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs.
  • Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural hemorrhages due to rupture of alveolar walls
  • Dilation of the right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.
  • Foreign material in the stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed, or sand. 
  • Hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, but it is a non-specific finding.
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - Also not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning.

Thus, the autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

  Freshwater drowning Seawater drowning
Mechanism of death Disruption of surfactant - causes surfactant denaturation Disruption of surfactant - causes dilution of surfactant
Fluid and electrolyte changes

Hypervolemia

Hyponatremia

Hyperkalemia

Hypovolemia

Hypernatremia
Time to death

Lesser (4-5 minutes)

More (8-12 minutes)

 

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs

Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

questions.text: The following graph displays which physiological law of the heart?
questions.solution:
The diagram displays the Length-Tension relationship for a cardiac muscle explaining the Starling law of the heart.

In the body, the initial length of the fibers is determined by the degree of diastolic filling of the heart, and the pressure developed in the ventricle is proportional to the volume of the ventricle at the end of the filling phase (Starling law of the heart).

  • The developed tension increases as the diastolic volume increases until it reaches a maximum, then tends to decrease.
  • The decrease is due to beginning disruption of the myocardial fibers and not due to a decrease in the number of cross-bridges between actin and myosin as seen in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: The medial fragment in a clavicle fracture is held up due to:

choices.text: Force of gravity on ipsilateral arm

questions.solution:
The medial fragment in a clavicle fracture is held up by the action of the sternocleidomastoid.

The lateral fragment in a clavicle fracture is displaced inferiorly due to gravity acting on the ipsilateral arm.

Fracture of the clavicle:

Mechanism of injury:

  • Fall on the point of the shoulder
  • Direct trauma over the clavicle due to road traffic accident
  • Fall on the outstretched hand

The fracture occurs most commonly at the junction of the middle third and outer third of the clavicle

Treatment:

  • Conservative treatment
    • Cuff and collar sling
    • Strapping and sling suspension
    • Figure of 8 bandaging
  • Operative treatment (for open fracture, injury to the neurovascular bundle, non union, floating shoulder etc)
    • Open reduction and internal fixation

questions.text:
A 32-year-old working IT professional came for the mobile cervical cancer screening camp planned in her work firm. Which of the following histories should be elicited in this patient before collecting the sample?

1. Ask about her last menstrual period/ date
2. Ask her when was the last time she had intercourse 
3. Ask her if she had used any douche while taking a bath
4. Ask her for any symptoms or history suggestive of immunosuppression 
5. Ask for a history of any contraceptive use
questions.solution:
The correct statements include 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.

Pap or Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. A positive test requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

Specific history to be elicited in patients prior to collection of sample:

  • The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation. Cervical squamous cells vary in appearance throughout the menstrual cycle. Thus, asking the patient for their last menstrual and any use of contraception is a must. (Statement 1)
  • A pre-requisite for a pap smear is that the patient should avoid intercourse 24 hours prior to the test. Thus, this history should be taken. (Statement 2)
  • The use of lubricants and douches may prevent the detection of organisms and the cell structure. Thus, asking the patient for this history is a must to prevent missing appropriate findings. (Statement 3)
  • History of immunosuppression must be elicited, including a family history of cancer, use of steroids, sexual history for STDs, and HIV/AIDS. In women with such a history, an annual checkup should be advised instead of once every three years. (Statement 4)
  • The use of intravaginal contraceptive creams should be stopped 24-48 hours before the test. The use of exogenous hormones and intrauterine devices may alter the appearance of cervical squamous cells. Hence, this history should be noted for an accurate interpretation of the test. (Statement 5)

Screening guidelines:

  • Time for initiation - 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse
  • Women aged 21-29 years - every 3 years
  • Women who are aged 30-65 years - Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years
  • Women can stop cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years
  • HIV+ve women - annual screening 
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Procedure:

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol and stained with Pap stain or short stain.

The most common fixative used in pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. The instruments used for pap smears are summarized in the image below.

 

The image below sums up the steps of collection of a sample for Pap testing.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
A child is being evaluated for burning sensation and pain in his hands and feet. Head-to-toe examination revealed the following lesions. Urine microscopy of the patient revealed the presence of maltese cross casts. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?
  1. It is an X-linked disorder
  2. It is due to deficiency of beta-glucosidase
  3. Definitive diagnosis is made by renal biopsy
  4. Renin-angiotensin system inhibitors are indicated in the treatment
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, with angiokeratomas and the presence of the maltese cross cast in urine, is suggestive of Fabry's disease and it is due to the deficiency of α-galactosidase A.

The image shows red-purple, non-blanching vascular skin lesions suggestive of angiokeratomas. These are usually distributed on the buttocks, groin, umbilicus (left figure), and upper thighs (bathing trunk distribution), and occasionally on lips and oral mucosa (right figure).

Fabry's disease:

It is an X-linked disorder due to the deficiency of α-galactosidase A. This would lead to increased intracellular storage of globotriaosylceramide. 

The classical presentation is a male child presenting with the following features:

  • Acroparesthesias - It refers to episodic burning pain involving the hands, feet, and peripheral extremities.
  • Angiokeratoma - These are punctate, dark red to blue-black telangiectatic skin lesions and can be flat or slightly raised. It does not blanch with pressure.
  • Hypohidrosis - Decreased sweating 

Nephropathy associated with this disease typically presents as mild to moderate proteinuria in the third decade. Microscopic hematuria or nephrotic syndrome may also be seen.

Investigations:

Urine analysis may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a maltese cross appearance.

A definitive diagnosis is made by renal biopsy. Renal biopsy shows cells with vacuoles containing globotriaosylceramide and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis(FSGS).

Electron microscopy detects these vacuoles having electron-dense materials arranged in parallel arrays(zebra bodies).

Treatment: Renin-angiotensin system inhibitors are indicated in the management. Enzyme replacement therapy with α-galactosidase A is also attempted.

 The image below shows the electron microscopy showing laminated bodies in pericytes about a capillary. 

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and stiffness on opening the mouth. On examination, the parotid gland is enlarged as shown below and tender. How long will this child be considered infectious, considering the most likely diagnosis based on the given features?

choices.text: Until he finishes a course of acyclovir

questions.solution:
The boy in this case is most likely suffering from Mumps. Once the swelling subsides, the boy will no longer be infectious.

Mumps is an infectious disease caused by an RNA virus from the paramyxoviridae family. The period of communicability is usually 4-6 days prior to the appearance of symptoms, but once the swelling subsides, the patient can be regarded as no longer infectious. Infection is caused by air droplets through the respiratory route. The high secondary attack rate of 86%

Clinical features:

  • The incubation period ranges from 12 to 25 days (usually 16-18 days).
  • Prodrome period: fever, headache, vomiting and achiness.
  • Parotitis, subligual and submandibular glands may also be involved.
  • Oedema over sternum as a result of lymphatic obstruction may occur. Morbilliform rash is rarely seen.

Complications of Mumps:

  • Parotitis: Unilateral or Bilateral, non-suppurative.
  • Epididymo-orchitis: Usually unilateral.
  • Meningitis or Meningoencephalitis
  • Other complications include: Arthritis, oophoritis, nephritis, pancreatitis, thyroiditis and myocarditis

questions.text: Which of the following substances inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by blocking the transportation of ADP and ATP?
questions.solution:
Atractyloside is a drug, which inhibits the process of oxidative phosphorylation by preventing the transportation of ADP into, and ATP out of, the mitochondria.

questions.text: Kumar presented with massive proteinuria and peripheral oedema. Which among the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis, based on the slide obtained after renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
The slide shows a normal glomerulus which rules out the other diagnosis. Hence, the most likely diagnosis is minimal change disease as it has a normal appearance on light microscopy.

Minimal change disease shows effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy. This finding can also be seen in membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis shows focal and segmental sclerosis of glomeruli and hyalinosis of the capillary wall.

Option C: Membranous nephropathy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation (A) and irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane best seen with silver stains (B).

Option D: Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease or nodular glomerulosclerosis occurs in diabetics and shows ovoid or spherical PAS positive nodules with diffuse mesangial sclerosis and capillary basement membrane thickening.

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as '2'?
questions.solution:
The given configuration of the segment marked by '2' is due to the vasoactive intestinal peptide being responsible for a state of relaxation of this part of the gut. 

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. The given segment of relaxation is an anterograde segment that moves from an oral to a caudal direction. 

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

The following image shows the events as described.

Note:

In achalasia cardia, there is a defective release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis of myocardial infarction?

choices.text: Chest pain on palpation is suggestive of myocardial infarction
Normal ECG at presentation excludes myocardial infarction
Normal baseline troponin and elevated 6-hour troponin suggests myocardial infarction

questions.solution:
A normal baseline troponin and elevated 6-hour troponin suggests myocardial infarction is the true statement.

Patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of myocardial infarction should undergo measurement of cardiac biomarkers. The preferred biomarker is cardiac troponin T (cTnT) or I (cTnI).

The admission troponin level may be normal if the patient presents early after the onset of symptoms. The troponin levels are assessed at the time of presentation, and 3-6 hrs after the onset of symptoms. If the 6-hour troponin level is normal then acute coronary syndrome is unlikely to explain the patient's chest pain. Patients with diabetes mellitus are more likely to present with painless STEMI.

An elevated troponin level is most likely suggestive of myocardial infarction and should be interpreted along with other investigations such as electrocardiographic changes and cardiac imaging to confirm the diagnosis. Levels of cTnI and cTnT may remain elevated for 7–10 days after STEMI.

Other options:

Option A: Chest pain reproducible on palpation is unlikely due to myocardial infarction. It is usually suggestive of a neuromuscular condition such as costochondritis, or trauma/strain.

Option B: A normal ECG at the time of presentation alone does not exclude myocardial infarction. In the case of normal ECG, other investigations including cardiac biomarkers and imaging are done.

Option D: The likelihood of myocardial infarction based on T-wave inversion is high, if ≥0.2 mV, and intermediate, if >0.1 mV.

questions.text: Apixaban belongs to which of the following class of drugs?
questions.solution:
Apixaban, a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC), is a factor Xa inhibitor that is used in the treatment of VTE (venous thrombo embolism)/DVT and in its prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgeries.

Direct factor Xa inhibitors:

  • Rivaroxaban
  • Apixaban
  • Edoxaban
  • Betrixaban

Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors:

  • Bivalirudin
  • Argatroban
  • Desirudin

Oral direct thrombin inhibitor—Dabigatran is the only oral direct thrombin inhibitor available for clinical use.

The FDA recently approved the drug Apixaban for a new indication. The drug is now used to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: After crowning was established in a patient in labor, the obstetrician uses the instrument shown below to give a liberal episiotomy. By doing so, what grade of perineal injury is the obstetrician iatrogenically inflicting?
questions.solution:
The image shows an episiotomy scissor, which can be identified by its angulation. It is used to perform an episiotomy. During episiotomy, the obstetrician iatrogenically induces a second-degree perineal tear.

Episiotomy refers to the surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. It is an induced second-degree perineal tear that involves the perineal muscles but spares the anal sphincter. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Timely episiotomy prevents third and fourth-degree perineal tears, which affect the anal sphincter.

Structures cut in episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, levator ani muscles
  • Fascia covering the muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and perineal skin

The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears.

Episiotomies are either midline or mediolateral:

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical Repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is lesser Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous or fistula and it's connections. 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities: Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between the yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated. The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct leads to various abnormalities depending on which part of the duct remains patent.

  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near the umbilicus leads to the umbilical polyp or sinus.
  • Persistence of the distal end with mucus retention leads to the cyst, which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by a fibrous band.
  • A fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to an enterocutaneous fistula.

Patent urachus occurs due to the failure of urachus to obliterate, resulting in a connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.

Urachal cyst occurs when the urachus fails to obliterate but there is no connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.

The given image below shows a urachal cyst (UC) attached to Meckel’s diverticulum (MD) on one side and urinary bladder (UB) on the other side with a patent tract- urachus (U).

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with 50% second-degree burns. She weighs 100 kgs. Which of the following is true regarding fluid resuscitation in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, patient weighs 100kgs with burns involving 50% of the total body surface area (TBSA). The resuscitation formula used in thermal burns in adults is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA. Therefore, the total fluid to be administered is = (2 ml x 100 kg) x 50% = 10000 mL = 10 Litres. The patient should be resuscitated with 50% of the total fluid required (i.e. 5 liters) in the first 8 hours.

Fluid resuscitation in burns:

Intravenous fluid resuscitation is done in adults with second degree and third degree burns > 15% TBSA (Total body surface area) and in children with burns > 10% TBSA.

According to ATLS 10th edition, 2018, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns in adults is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA. 50% of the total fluid is given in the first 8 hours after the burns injury and the remaining 50% is given in the subsequent 16 hours. This can be calculated as:

First 8 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)
Next 16 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)

For a patient presenting 8 hours after sustaining thermal burns, the total volume using resuscitation formula should be given in the next 16 hours i.e; 2 mL/kg × % TBSA in the next 16 hours while maintaining a target urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults.

In adults, urine output should be maintained between 30 and 50 cc/hr to minimize potential over-resuscitation.

In case of paediatric burns, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns is 3 mL/kg × % TBSA.

 

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

The total percentage of the burnt area is calculated clinically using the rule of nines.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of epithelial metaplasia?
questions.solution:
The most common type of epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous metaplasia. It is commonly seen in the respiratory tract of smokers. 

The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia
Airways

Squamous metaplasia: It is seen in chronic smoking. The normal ciliated columnar epithelial cells of the trachea and bronchi are replaced by stratified squamous epithelial cells.

Also, a deficiency of retinoic acid may cause squamous metaplasia.

Salivary glands, pancreas, bile ducts

Squamous metaplasia: The presence of stones in the excretory duct may trigger metaplasia, where the normal secretory columnar epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium.
Cervix

Squamous metaplasia: Due to the low pH of the cervix, the normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium.
Esophagus

Columnar metaplasia: In patients with chronic GERD, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus).
Muscle

Connective tissue metaplasia: In some cases, after intramuscular hemorrhage, there may be the formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans.

GERD: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

Image showing squamous metaplasia in endocervical glands of the cervix.

The image below depicts the histopathology of Barret's esophagus, showing the internalized epithelium with goblet cells as opposed to the normal stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus and pseudostratified columnar epithelium of the fundus of the stomach. The submucosa displays an infiltrate including lymphocytes and plasma cells, constituting an underlying chronic inflammation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman often says that her nose is "too fat" and she looks ugly. Because of this, she has stopped going out with friends. She spends almost half a day staring at herself in the mirror despite her husband's reassuring efforts that she is beautiful. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of preoccupation about the appearance of her nose associated with performing compulsive acts, like checking in the mirror, is suggestive of body dysmorphic disorder.

Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) is one of the obsessive-compulsive spectrum disorders as per DSM-5 (diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders). It is characterised by impairing and distressing preoccupations about an imagined defect or overemphasis on a slight defect in one’s appearance. This causes significant emotional distress and impairment in the patient's functioning.

In response to their appearance concerns, individuals with BDD may perform compulsive acts like excessive grooming, and constantly checking in the mirror. Some patients also perform mental acts such as comparing their appearance to that of other people. They may avoid social gatherings which can range up to being housebound. 

Patients with BDD can be treated with serotonin-specific drugs such as clomipramine and fluoxetine. 

Other options:

Option A: Social anxiety disorder or social phobia specifically involves the fear of social situations. Patients with this disorder are usually scared of embarrassing themselves in social situations. 

Option C: Somatic symptom disorder or hypochondriasis is characterized by the presence of general and non-delu­sional preoccupation for ≥6 months with fears of having a serious disease. This is based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. These preoccupied thoughts cause significant distress and impairment in one's life.

Option D: Factitious disorder is an intentional attempt to produce, stimulate or aggravate an illness to gain medical attention. The primary intention is not financial gains or avoidance of duties here. 

Related Pearl: Classification of somatic symptom disorders: DSM-5 vs ICD-10

Factitious disorder

Malingering

Falsification or exaggeration of symptoms to obtain external incentives (secondary gain)

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with lower back pain. He is evaluated and diagnosed to have ankylosing spondylitis. Which among the following is the earliest vertebral change seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The earliest vertebral change in ankylosing spondylitis is the squaring of the vertebra or flattening of the anterior concavity of the vertebral bodies.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease that mainly affects the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is commonly seen in young male adults and has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker

ASAS categorisation criteria for spondyloarthritis in patients <45 years with lower back pain of 3 months duration. The criteria comprise 2 sections, one radiological section and one clinical section:

  • To qualify for the radiological section - sacroiliitis on simple radiography or MRI + at least one of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis 
  • To qualify for the clinical section - a positive HLA B27 + at least two of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis without radiologic sacroiliitis 

Features of spondyloarthritis: 

  • Low inflammatory pain
  • Arthritis
  • Enthesitis
  • Uveítis
  • Dactylitis
  • Psoriasis
  • Crohn/colitis
  • Good response to NSAID
  • Family history of spondyloarthropathy
  • HLA B27
  • High CRP levels

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Sacro-iliac joints - 
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign - erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later - peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes - 
    • Earliest - flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later - ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance - due to bridging at several vertebral levels
    • Long-standing cases are associated with osteoporosis. Wedging of the vertebral bodies produces hyperkyphosis of the spine.
  • Progressive bony ankylosis or erosive arthritis may be seen in peripheral joints.

The most common serious complication of ankylosing spondylitis is a spinal fracture. The lower cervical spine is the most common area for fracture. The other complications include gluteal muscle atrophy, loss of lumbar curvature, kyphosis, etc.

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis
Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dysarthria and impaired sensation over the right side of her face. Further examination shows loss of pain and temperature on the left side of the body. When asked to walk in a straight line, she sways to the right side. Which of the following marked vessels is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the ipsilateral (right-sided, in this case) vertebral artery marked as '4' in the image above.

Lateral medullary syndrome: The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

The lateral medullary syndrome may also occur as a consequence of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) stroke. PICA is a branch of the vertebral artery.

 

Other options:

The other structures marked in the image are as follows - 

1 - Anterior cerebral artery

2 - Middle cerebral artery

3 - Basilar cerebral artery

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient of APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) developing fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates while on medical treatment. This is suggestive of APL differentiation syndrome, an adverse effect of all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA). The management involves glucocorticoids like dexamethasone. 

Along with glucocorticoids, the other management of APL differentiation syndrome includes chemotherapy for cytoreduction and supportive measures. In severe cases, temporary discontinuation of ATRA is necessary.

ATRA is an oral drug that induces the differentiation of leukemic cells bearing the t(15;17) chromosomal translocation. While ATRA reduces the incidence of DIC associated with cytarabine and daunorubicin used earlier in APL, it can cause APL differentiation syndrome due to the adhesion of differentiated neoplastic cells to the pulmonary vasculature endothelium.

In low-risk APL patients with a low leukocyte count at presentation, a combination of ATRA and arsenic trioxide (ATO) has been found to be superior and is the current standard of care.

questions.text: A young school-going boy with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness visits your clinic. While walking towards the reception, he suddenly falls down with no control over his muscle tone. Which part of the brain is affected in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a young boy with excessive daytime sleep and sudden loss of voluntary muscle tone (cataplexy) is suggestive of narcolepsy. It is associated with the loss of orexin from the lateral hypothalamus.

Narcolepsy is a chronic neurological disorder caused by the brain’s inability to regulate sleep-wake cycles normally. The affected individual experiences a sudden loss of voluntary muscle tone (cataplexy), an eventual irresistible urge to sleep during daytime, and possibly brief episodes of total paralysis at the beginning or end of sleep. It is also characterized by a sudden onset of REM sleep, unlike normal sleep that begins with NREM, slow-wave sleep.

It has a familial incidence strongly associated with a class II antigen of the major histocompatibility complex on chromosome 6 at the HLA-DR2 or HLA-DQW1 locus, implying a genetic susceptibility.

Orexins (Previously known as hypocretins) are neuropeptides synthesized by hypothalamic neurons and involved in the regulation of food intake and energy expenditure and also in sleep regulation.

The hypothalamus and several non-specific nuclei in the ascending reticular activating system (ARAS) located in the midbrain are involved in the regulation of the sleep-wake cycle.

Sleep Centres

Stimulation of the midbrain reticular formation (RAS) produces the EEG alerting response and promotes the waking state. 

The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the raphe nuclei of ARAS are rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce wakefulness.

The cholinergic neurons in the pontine reticular formation, on stimulation, induce sleep.

Stimulation of the histaminergic neurons of the posterior hypothalamus produces arousal. 

Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region rapidly induces sleep. This sleep-inducing effect is thought to be mediated by GABA-ergic inhibitory neurons.

Summary of hormones/mediators of the sleep-wakefulness cycle:

Wakeful state  Sleep 
Norepinephrine  Acetylcholine 
Serotonin  GABA 
Histamine

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought with fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) appears clear, with reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased lymphocytes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased lymphocytes levels is a typical presentation of tubercular meningitis.

questions.text: Staging in a 60-year-old female patient with carcinoma endometrium showed involvement of >50% of the myometrium. There was no involvement of other structures and no lymph node involvement. Next line of management should be __________

choices.text: Post op pelvic radiotherapy + vaginal vault radiotherapy
Post op brachytherapy + post op external beam radiotherapy

questions.solution:
This is a case of stage 1B endometrial carcinoma since there is the involvement of >50% of the myometrium, with no involvement of other structures or lymph nodes. Stage 1B carcinoma endometrium is managed with post-op pelvic radiotherapy and vaginal vault radiotherapy.

Management of Ca Endometrium:

Surgical staging of Ca endometrium with total abdominal hysterectomy+bilateral salpingoophorectomy+lymphadenectomy is the cornerstone of treatment. Thus, further management is mainly postoperative. 

  • Stage IB: Postoperative pelvic radiotherapy over 5–6 weeks, along with vaginal vault radiotherapy.
  • Stage II: Brachytherapy followed by surgery and external radiotherapy either 1 week or 6 weeks later, based on histological findings. Alternately, Wertheim’s hysterectomy may be done.
  • Stage III: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, cisplatin, and paclitaxel. Debulking surgery may be attempted.
  • Stage IV: Palliation with radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and progestogen

 

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

Related Pearl: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant
IV
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

*This pearl is in line with the FIGO 2010 guidelines. It will be updated according to the FIGO 2023 guidelines after an official treatment guideline is released.

questions.text:
Given below is a list of equipment used for the cold storage of vaccines. Arrange the cold storage equipment in the correct order of usage, starting from the primary health center level to the national level.
  1. Walk-in-Freezers
  2. Walk-in-coolers
  3. Deep freezer
  4. Ice lined refrigerators
questions.solution:
The cold chain equipments that are used at various healthcare strata starting from the primary health center to the national level are 4-3-2-1 i.e. ice lined refrigerators → deep freezer → walk-in-coolers → walk-in-freezers.

Ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs) are similar to conventional refrigerators and are lined with ice packs or tubes. They are categorized based on the vaccine storage capacity. Smaller ones are supplied to the primary health center (PHC) headquarters, while larger ones are supplied to district headquarters. They maintain a temperature of 2-8° Celsius for the storage of vaccines. They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs.

Deep freezer (DF) is also similar to a conventional refrigerator but has a top-opening lid. It maintains a temperature of -15° to -25° celsius. It is used at the district level and above for the storage of oral polio vaccines for 3 months. At the sub-district level, it is used for freezing icepacks.

Walk-in-coolers (WIC) are insulated cold rooms with two cooling units with an uninterrupted power supply. They maintain a temperature of 2-8° celsius. They are used at government medical store depots, state, regional, and occasionally district level vaccine stores. 

Walk-in-freezers (WIF) are similar to WIC but maintain a temperature of -15° to -25° celsius. They are used at national, state, and regional vaccine stores.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A primigravida underwent a quadruple screening test at 16 weeks of gestation. All the parameters were low except for serum inhibin A level which was normal. Identify the condition in which the findings given above are seen.
questions.solution:
All the parameters like maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP), beta HCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are reduced in trisomy 18/Edwards syndrome. Maternal serum inhibin A level may be normal or reduced.

Quadruple testing is usually done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. This test can additionally help in picking up Smith-Lemli-Optiz syndrome. However, one of the limitations of the test is that it fails to detect trisomy 13. 

In trisomy 21 and neural tube defects, the changes in the screening markers are as follows:

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG  Beta HCG  Beta HCG 
PAPP-A  Unconjugated estriol  Unconjugated estriol 
This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG MSAFP  MSAFP

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in metachromatic leucodystrophy?
questions.solution:
Metachromatic leucodystrophy occurs due to the deficiency of arylsulfatase A enzyme.

Metachromatic leucodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disorder. Deficiency of arylsulfatase A enzyme leads to accumulation of sulfated glycosphingolipids in white matter with subsequent demyelination. Affected infants (infantile form) present with cognitive deterioration, muscle weakness, hypotonia, nystagmus, myoclonic seizures, optic atrophy and progressive paralysis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with fever and malaise for 4 days. On examination, he has rashes over his back as shown in the image.  The causative agent of this disease remains dormant in ________
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of chickenpox caused by the Varicella-zoster virus, which remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglion.

The image depicts the rash of chickenpox, as different stages of the rash can be seen at one time.

Characteristics of the rash of chickenpox:

  • Superficial
  • Pleomorphic
  • Centripetal
  • Unilocular
  • Symmetrical
  • Spares palms and soles, affects flexor surfaces and axilla
  • Rapid evolution
  • Dewdrop on Rose-petal appearance (shown in the image below)

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles).

questions.text: A psychiatrist is conducting the Folstein test as a part of the psychiatric evaluation of a patient. What is the maximum score out of which the patient is scored?
questions.solution:
The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), also known as the Folstein test, is scored out of 30. It consists of a questionnaire from 11 categories. It is used extensively in clinical and research settings to test cognitive functioning.

A patient with a score less than 24 is considered to have impaired cognition.

questions.text: A man is under suspicion of smuggling cocaine in his body at the local airport. He is asymptomatic and an X-ray of the abdomen was done and is shown below. The next best step in the management of this case would be:
questions.solution:
The given scenario with an X-ray showing multiple cylindrical capsules (marked as *) in the stomach and intestine is consistent with body packing. The next best step in the management of this case would be to initiate whole-bowel irrigation.

 

The X-ray reveals that the packs are largely intact and unruptured. Since he is asymptomatic, the next step in management would be to give single-dose activated charcoal and institute whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution to hasten packet elimination gently.

Body packing involves swallowing packets of illegal drugs like heroin, cannabis, morphine, and cocaine to smuggle the same. Usually, the drugs are packed by first carefully wrapping them in latex or plastic. These are swallowed and later excreted with the help of laxatives.

Similarly, a person who smuggles these drugs by consuming or stuffing drugs in the rectum or the vagina is referred to as a body stuffer. This generally occurs due to the non-availability of time. Radiography is not as helpful in these cases. Drug toxicity may be seen in body stuffers due to systemic absorption of the drug.

Other options:

Option A: Sometimes, drugs like heroin or cocaine that have the same radiodensity as feces, may be difficult to detect on X-rays. A CT scan helps to identify the same in this scenario.

Option B: Endoscopy or colonoscopy to remove the drugs is not done because any manipulation can rupture the packets, leading to their toxicity. 

Option D: Surgery is indicated in those patients who exhibit the symptoms of toxicity due to the rupture of packets.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the psychiatry OPD with low mood for the past 2 weeks, reduced socialization, decreased appetite and inability to sleep for the past 3 months. She complains of frequent backache and headache, with early morning awakening. Which of the following is increased in this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low mood along with reduced appetite, reduced interest in socialization, somatic symptoms, and disturbed sleep, points towards a diagnosis of depression (major depressive disorder). Cortisol levels are increased in depression.  

The diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are as follows:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2 week period. At least one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  3. Significant weight loss (loss of more than 5% of body weight in a month) when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite 
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by:

  • Schizoaf­fective disorder
  • Schizophrenia
  • Schizophreniform disorder
  • Delusional disorder
  • Another specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum, or other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Note: The levels of norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine are decreased in depression
