questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of WHO's major criteria for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with panmyelosis

questions.solution:
Subnormal serum erythropoietin level is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera. The other three options are included as major criteria for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera.

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which there is an accumulation of phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets in the absence of a recognizable physiologic stimulus. It is the most common myeloproliferative neoplasm. The increase in the red cells is predominantly responsible for the clinical symptoms in this condition.

In 15% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years, there is increased myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients.

The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. 

Clinical features of PCV:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Thrombocytosis - leads to venous arterial thrombosis, hepatic venous thrombosis. Erythromelalgia is the erythema, burning, and pain in the extremities. It also occurs due to thrombocytosis.
  • Erythrocytosis - leads to hyperviscosity, leading to neurologic symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances, transient ischemic attacks (TIA), and systolic hypertension. 
  • Aquagenic pruritis
  • Hyperuricemia and gout - It may occur due to the large turnover of the hematopoietic stem cells

Diagnosis: Criteria for diagnosis is given below:

Major criteria:

  1. Hb more than 16.5g/dL in males and 16g/dL in females or hematocrit of >49% in men and >48% in women
  2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis) including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation.
  3. Presence of JAK-2 mutation

Minor criteria:

  • Subnormal erythropoietin levels.

Diagnosis requires all three major criteria or the first 2 major and 1 minor criterion.

Management:

  • Target Hb levels are < 14g/dL in males and < 12g/dL in females.
  • Periodic phlebotomy can be done to reduce hyperviscosity and to maintain the red cell mass. It is usually done at 3-month intervals.
  • Anticoagulants are given when there is thrombosis.
  • Allopurinol can be given to control hyperuricemia.
  • Ruxolitinib which is a nonspecific JAK2 inhibitor, pegylated IFN-α, or PUVA therapy can be used for intractable pruritis.
  • Ruxolitinib or pegylated IFN-α can be used to manage symptomatic splenomegaly.
  • Anagrelide which is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor is used to reduce platelet count in these patients.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of primary hemostasis after the exposure of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and collagen in sequence.
  1. Platelet recruitment
  2. Platelet aggregation
  3. Shape change
  4. Release of secretory granules
  5. Platelet adhesion and activation
questions.solution:
The option showing the correct sequence of primary hemostasis is 5, 3, 4, 1, 2

Primary hemostasis:

Primary hemostasis is the stage in the process of normal hemostasis where the platelet plug is formed. The exposure of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and collagen following the disruption of the endothelium, promotes platelet adherence and activation. These platelets undergo a change in shape in order to increase the surface area as a result of the activation. They turn from small discs to flat plate-like structures with spiky projections. This is followed by the secretion of granules such as adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thrombocane A2 (TxA2) which aid in the recruitment of additional platelets. These undergo aggregation to form a primary platelet plug.

The process of hemostasis is arteriolar vasoconstriction → platelet plug → tissue factor release → fibrin deposit.

Normal hemostasis:

  1. Arteriolar vasoconstriction: After vascular injury, local neurohumoral factors induce transient vasoconstriction.
  2. Primary hemostasis: Platelets bind via glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptors to von Willebrand factor (vWF) on exposed extracellular matrix (ECM) and are activated, undergoing a shape change and granule release. Released adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thromboxane A2 (TxA2) induce additional platelet aggregation through platelet GpIIb-IIIa receptor binding to fibrinogen and form the primary hemostatic plug.
  3. Secondary hemostasis: Local activation of the coagulation cascade (involving tissue factor and platelet phospholipids) results in fibrin polymerization, “cementing” the platelets into a definitive secondary hemostatic plug.
  4. Clot stabilization and resorption: Counter-regulatory mechanisms, mediated by tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA, a fibrinolytic product) and thrombomodulin, confine the hemostatic process to the site of injury.

The following image shows the steps of normal hemostasis:

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

questions.text:
Match the following
Name of the fracture Site of the fracture
1) Galeazzi fracture A) Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement of the distal bone fragment.
2) Smith’s fracture B) Fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius
3) Colles’ fracture C) Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.
4) Monteggia fracture D) Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C,2-D,3-A,4-B.

  • Galeazzi fracture - Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.
  • Smith's fracture - Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.
  • Colles' fracture - Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement of the distal bone fragment.
  • Monteggia fracture - Fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation:

It is a fracture of the lower third of the radius with subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint. It is caused by a fall on the hand usually associated with a superimposed rotation force. On clinical examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

Smith's fracture:

It is also known as reverse Colles' fracture. It is the fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement. The characteristic deformity seen is the 'garden-spade deformity'. 

Colles' fracture:

It is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment. The patient presents with pain, swelling, and dinner fork deformity of the wrist. The 'dinner fork deformity ' is the prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. 

Undisplaced fractures are managed by immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for 6 weeks. Closed manipulative reduction and immobilization in Colles' cast is the treatment of choice for displaced fractures.

Monteggia fracture:

It is the fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. It can be an extension or flexion type. In extension type, there is anterior angulation of the ulna fracture and anterior dislocation of the head of the radius. In flexion type, there is posterior angulation of the ulna fracture and posterior dislocation of the head of the radius. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with right-sided large acoustic neuroma. On examination, there is hypoesthesia along the posterior meatal wall of the right ear. This is likely to be due to the involvement of _______.
questions.solution:
Hypoesthesia of the posterosuperior meatal wall is known as Hitzelberger's sign. It is seen in acoustic neuroma as sensory fibers of the facial nerve (VII nerve) will be affected. The posterior wall of the auditory canal receives sensory fibers of CN VII (through the auricular branch of the vagus) which is the reason for the manifestation.

Cranial nerve involvement in acoustic neuroma:

Cranial nerve involved Clinical features
Vth nerve Reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of face
VIIth nerve Hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall (Hitzelberger’s sign), loss of taste, delayed blink reflex, and reduced lacrimation
IXth and Xth nerves Dysphagia and hoarseness

Nerve supply of External auditory canal:

  • Anterior wall and roof - the auriculotemporal branch of the mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V3).
  • Posterior wall and floor - the auricular branch of Vagus (Arnold's nerve). Cough response while cleaning the ear canal is mediated by the vagus which also supplies the larynx.
  • Posterior wall also receives sensory supply by the facial nerve (CN VII).

questions.text: You are assessing the developmental milestones of a child. On detailed history and examination, you find that the child hops on one foot, copies a square, tells stories, and goes to the toilet alone.  What is the probable age of this child, assuming that there is no developmental delay?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the child hops on one foot, copies a square, tells stories, and goes to the toilet alone. The probable age of the child is 4 years if there is no developmental delay. 

Milestones in a 4-year-old child:

  • Gross motor - 
    • Hops on one foot
    • Walks downstairs with alternate foot
    • Throws ball overhand
  • Adaptive - 
    • Copies square and cross
    • Constructs bridge from blocks
    • Draws a man with 2 parts other than head
  • Language - 
    • Tells stories
    • Sings songs or poem
  • Social - 
    • Goes to the toilet alone
    • Plays cooperatively in a group

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: A middle-aged woman was started on heparin postoperatively for thromboprophylaxis. A few days later, she presented with deep vein thrombosis. Her platelet count was found to be 60,000/microliter. Which of the following anticoagulants should be avoided in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above scenario has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Warfarin can decrease protein C levels and may precipitate venous limb gangrene or skin necrosis in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Therefore, it should not be used until the platelet count returns to normal.

HIT is caused due to the development of IgG antibodies against complexes of heparin with platelet factor 4 (or other chemokines).

HIT usually starts 5-10 days after starting heparin. The patients will have platelet count <1,50,000/mL or reduced by 50% or more from the pre-treatment value. These are more common with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMWH) and also more common in women.

Venous thrombosis (in the form of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism) is more common than arterial thrombosis. Arterial thrombosis can cause limb ischemia, myocardial infarction, or stroke. Bilateral adrenal hemorrhage and skin lesions at the site of subcutaneous heparin injection can also be seen.

The diagnosis of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia can be confirmed by enzyme-linked immunoassays to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes, platelet activation assays, and serotonin release assay.

Management of HIT includes:

  • Stop heparin/LMWH.
  • Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban. LMWH should be avoided because it cross-reacts with heparin antibodies.
  • Do not give warfarin until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal.

Related Pearl: Heparin vs. LMWH vs. Fondaparinux

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about COVID 19?
  1. It is caused by an enveloped RNA virus with club-shaped spikes
  2. Biosafety level 2 is the minimum required for the culture of this virus
  3. FELUDA based on CRISPR gene-editing technology is a strip test that could detect the SARS COV-2 genes
  4. KAVACH ELISA is used for antigen detection
  5. SARS COV 2 belongs to the family called Orthomyxoviridae
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 3 are true about COVID-19. SARS - COV2 is an enveloped RNA virus with club-shaped spikes and FELUDA based on the CRISPR gene-editing technology is a strip test that can detect SARS COV 2 genes.

A biosafety level cabinet BSL of level 3 is required for culturing the virus while a level 2 would suffice for specimen handling or molecular testing of the virus. KAVACH ELISA is for antibody detection of COVID-19. Coronavirus belongs to the family of Coronaviridae.

Coronaviruses are enveloped positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses with an unsegmented genome, and they exhibit helical symmetry. 

The coronaviridiae have a single unsegmented ss (+) RNA which is, in fact, the largest genome among RNA viruses. They are about 120 - 160 nm in size and contain a helical nucleocapsid. It also has spike proteins - S1 and S2. They are responsible for the host specificty, faster spread of the disease and it is highly suscpetible to mutations. While S1 protein is involved in the attachment of the virus with ACE-2 receptor, S2 protein is involved in virus-host cell fusion. 

The virus responsible for the recent pandemic that started in 2019 is named SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome- coronavirus-2) and the disease it causes has been named coronavirus disease 2019 (abbreviated COVID-19). 

SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the order Nidovirales, family Coronaviridae, subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, genera Betacoronavirus, and sub-genus Sarbecovirus.

Related Pearl: Laboratory Biosafety Levels (BSL)

 

Biosafety level Lab practices Safety Equipment Facility
BSL 1

Work on open lab benches or tables.

Good microbiological techniques followed

 PPE (lab coats, gloves, eye protection) are worn as needed.

Sink for hand washing.

Separate doors from the rest of the facility.
BSL 2 Access restricted to the laboratory

Appropriate PPE (lab coats, gloves, eye protection, and face shields).

Biological safety cabinets (BSC) to prevent potential aerosols.

Autoclave or alternative method for decontamination

Sink and eyewash easily available.

Self-closing doors. 
BSL 3

Access restricted and controlled at all times.

Medical surveillance of laboratory workers.

Appropriate PPE must be worn, and respirators might be required.

BSC for all activities.

Hands-free sink and eyewash.

Directional airflow from clean areas towards potentially contaminated areas.

Entrance to the lab is through 2 self-closing and interlocked doors.
BSL 4

Change clothing before entering and shower upon exiting.

Decontaminate all materials before exiting.

BSC and full-body, air-supplied, positive pressure suit.

Double-ended autoclave (through the wall).

Laboratory in a separate building or isolated in a restricted zone.

Dedicated supply and exhaust air, as well as vacuum lines and decontamination systems.

questions.text:
Match the following disorders with their investigation of choice.
 Disorders  Investigations
  1. Achalasia cardia
  2. Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis
  3. Gastroesophageal reflux disease
  4. Intussusception
  1.  CT abdomen
  2. Ultrasound abdomen
  3. Esophageal pH monitoring
  4. Esophageal manometry
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

 Disorders

 Investigations
1

Achalasia cardia

Esophageal manometry
2

Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis

Ultrasound abdomen
3

Gastroesophageal reflux disease

Esophageal pH monitoring
4

Intussusception

CT abdomen

(Option 1) Achalasia cardia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing.

It presents with a characteristic triad of

  • Dysphagia,
  • Regurgitation, and
  • Weight loss.

On barium swallow, bird beak appearance of the esophagus is seen in achalasia. Esophageal manometry is the "gold standard" investigation for achalasia. The manometry findings seen in achalasia are impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and absent peristalsis with elevated LES pressure. 

The image below shows the bird beak appearance of the esophagus on barium swallow.

 

(Option 2) Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS) occurs due to the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus resulting in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. 

Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. The recurrent vomiting secondary to the gastric outlet obstruction leads to dehydration and hypochloremic hypokalemic alkalosis.

Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of > 3-4 mm and a pyloric length of > 15-18 mm. USG also shows an antral nipple sign and cervix sign in this condition.

  • The antral nipple sign refers to redundant pyloric mucosa protruding into the gastric antrum.
  • The cervix sign is the indentation of the pylorus into the fluid-filled antrum.
  • The hypertrophied hypoechoic muscle surrounding echogenic mucosa looks like a "target" in the USG. This is called a target sign of pyloric stenosis.

USG given below shows antral nipple sign seen in CHPS.

 

(Option 3) Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is the retrograde flow of gastric contents through the lower esophageal sphincter. It presents with a characteristic triad of retrosternal burning pain (heartburns), epigastric pain, and regurgitation.

24 hours pH monitoring is the "gold standard" investigation in the diagnosis of GERD. An oesophageal pH < 4 is considered as cut-off value. Patterns of reflux and the correlation between symptoms and oesophageal pH are calculated. In normal patients, the total time when pH < 4 in a 24-hour period does not exceed 4%.

 

(Option 4) Intussusception is a condition where one segment of the intestine becomes drawn into the lumen of the proximal segment of the bowel. CT scan is the investigation of choice for diagnosing intussusception. The characteristic "target sign" is seen in CT.

USG findings in intussusception include: 

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)- The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Barium enema shows the characteristic coiled spring appearance.

USG image showing the target sign-

Note: There is a small risk of intussusception from rotavirus vaccination, usually within a week after the first or second dose.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition
Disorders of EGJ obstruction
Type I achalasia
(classic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Type II
(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Panesophageal pressurization
Type III
(spastic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Spastic contractions
Panesophageal pressurization or normal presurization
DCI > 450mmHg
Disorders of peristalsis 
DES (Diffuse esophageal spasm) Normal IRPN
Non-peristaltic (spastic) contractions or premature contractions.
DCI>450mmHg
Nutcracker’s esophagus Normal IRP
Increased duration of peristalsis
Normal peristalsis

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 23-year-old in the postnatal period after her first delivery developed a uterine prolapse of the level given below. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ring pessaries are the preferred management in the case of prolapse in the postnatal period.

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for 3-4 months, with abdominal exercises, massage, and perineal exercises.  Young women rapidly improve if appropriate conservative methods are employed. If surgery is performed within 6 months of delivery, there is a high chance of recurrence of the prolapse.

The image below shows the various degrees of uterovaginal prolapse.

Various surgeries were performed for the management of uterovaginal prolapse:

  1. Anterior colporrhaphy: This is done for cystocele or cystourethrocele.
  2. Posterior colporrhaphy/ colpoperineorrhaphy: This is done for posterior defects like rectocele or rectal defects with perineal laxity.
  3. Le Forte's repair: This is preferred only in elderly women with advanced prolapse, or those unfit for surgery. Women wanting an active sexual life are poor candidates for this procedure as it creates an adhesive area in the midline.
  4. Abdominal sling surgeries: Young women desirous of retaining menstrual and reproductive functions are ideal candidates. These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. These include:
    1. Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre) - sling attached to cervix posteriorly near uterosacral ligaments. 
    2. Shirodkar's sling surgery - the sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
    3. Khanna's sling surgery - sling fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament. 
  5. Fothergill surgery (Manchester operation): An anterior colporrhaphy is combined with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are then sutured in front of the cervix followed by a colpoperineorrhaphy. It is suitable for women <40 years desiring reproductive function, but fertility may be reduced.
  6. Ward-Mayo surgery: This is a combination of vaginal hysterectomy + pelvic floor repair. It is done in women >40 years, not desiring reproductive function.
  7. Moschowitz surgery: This is performed for enterocele repair where the pouch of Douglas is obliterated.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not applicable to rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis?

choices.text: Hyperglycemia is a major risk factor
CT scan is used for definitive diagnosis
Cavernous sinus thrombosis is seen in advanced cases
Liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
CT scan is not used for the definitive diagnosis of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. The investigation of choice, in this case, is an endoscopic biopsy followed by histopathological examination.

The most accurate site for such biopsies is the middle turbinate. Histopathological analysis of the biopsy sample will reveal characteristic hyphal findings of the fungus causing mucormycosis. Rhizopus is the most commonly implicated organism in mucormycosis. 

CT scans of the head and sinuses do not yield findings that are specific for mucormycosis (indistinguishable from those seen in bacterial sinusitis). This makes it an ineffective investigation of choice. 

Other options

Option A - Hyperglycemia is a major risk factor in mucormycosis. It disrupts normal iron sequestration and phagocytic action and promotes tissue penetration of the fungus. This effect is compounded in states of diabetic ketoacidosis. 

Option C - Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is characterised by complications such as cavernous sinus thrombosis when advanced cases are encountered. Clinical features suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis are bilateral proptosis, chemosis, vision loss, and impairment of extraocular muscle function (ophthalmoplegia). 

Option D - Mucormycosis is primarily managed by the administration of a polyene antifungal drug. The liposomal formulation of amphotericin B (LAmB) is the drug of choice in CNS infections. It has proven efficacy due to good penetration. The initial dosage is 5 mg/kg per day, and it can be escalated to 7.5-10 mg/kg per day.

questions.text: In a 48-year-old patient with type-2 diabetes mellitus, fundus examination revealed the presence of hard exudates. In which of the below-marked layers of the retina would you appreciate this finding?
questions.solution:
Hard exudates mostly occur in the outer plexiform layer - layer 3. It can be identified as it lies between two nuclear layers. 

In the given image:

  1. Inner plexiform layer
  2. Inner nuclear layer
  3. Outer plexiform layer
  4. Outer nuclear layer

Hard exudates are the extravasation of fluid rich in fibrin and protein around the area of leaking micro-aneurysms. They mostly occur in the outer plexiform layer. They appear as well-defined small, bright yellow deposits with crenated margins.

Common eye findings seen in retinal vascular diseases and the layers involved:

Microaneurysms are seen as a result of focal dilation of the capillary wall following loss of pericytes. They are commonly observed in the inner nuclear layer. 

Soft exudates, also known as ‘cotton wool spots’, occur due to the accumulation of cellular debris that occurs as a result of ischemia. They are seen in the nerve fiber layer. They appear as ill-defined, cloud-like soft aggregates with feathery margins.

Flame hemorrhages are due to the rupture of blood vessels in the nerve fiber layer. They assume flame shape because of the collection of blood in between the parallel running nerve fibers.

Drusen are extracellular deposits seen in age-related macular degeneration. These are located in the interface between the retinal pigmentary epithelium and Bruch membrane.

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina  (inner to outer)

  1. Internal limiting membrane
  2. Nerve fibre layer
  3. Ganglion cell layer           
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Inner nuclear layer
  6. Outer plexiform layer 
  7. Outer nuclear layer
  8. External limiting membrane
  9. Rods and cones
  10. Retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: A new screening test for detecting cervical cancer is being studied in a group of 100 women.  60 women tested negative and 40 tested positive.  Among the women who tested positive by the new test, 30 were positive and among the women who tested negative, 10 were having the disease. What is the positive predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value is 75%

The data given in the question is tabulated as follows:

  Diseased Not diseased Total
Test positive 30 (TP) 10 (FP) 40
Test negative 10 (FN) 50 (TN) 60
Total 40 60 100

TP - True positive, FP - False positive, FN - False negative, TN - True negative.

Positive predictive value (PPV) = TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

Here PPV = 30/(30+10) x 100 = 30/40 x 100 = 75%

Predictive value of a positive test:

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease. Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. It is highly related to the prevalence of a disease. The predictive value of a positive test will be more accurate if the disease is more prevalent and vice-versa.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A patient with HIV presented complaining of cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest X-ray showed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The Gomori methamine silver-stained smear of his bronchoalveolar lavage is given below. What is the most probable causative organism and the typical CD4+ count this infection occurs at?
questions.solution:
Cough, progressive dyspnea, bilateral interstitial infiltrates and the Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stained smear showing black-colored cysts resembling crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii and occurs at a CD4+ count <200/µl.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus causing pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. It has three morphological forms: trophozoite, pre-cyst and cyst. The infection is transmitted through respiratory droplets. Patients present with fever, non-productive cough and progressive dyspnea. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

It can be diagnosed by demonstration of the organism in broncho-alveolar lavage or lung biopsy specimens. PCR can also be done. Treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate. Cotrimoxazole can also be used for prophylaxis in patients with AIDS.

The following X-ray image shows a cyst (arrow) and bilateral lung infiltrates in a patient with PCP:

Note: Toxoplasma gondii is an opportunistic infection causing encephalitis. On GMS staining of infected tissue, tachyzoites appear as crescent-shaped structures with blue cytoplasm and dark nucleus. Toxoplasmosis typically occurs in AIDS patients with a CD4+ count <100/µl. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Which is the only rotator cuff muscle innervated by the axillary nerve?
questions.solution:
The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles that have common features regarding their origin (from the scapula) and insertion (into lesser and greater tubercles of the humerus). Of the four muscles, the teres minor, marked as '4', is the only rotator cuff muscle innervated by the axillary nerve.

Teres minor originates from the upper two-thirds of the lateral border of the scapula on the dorsal surface. It inserts into the lowermost impression of the greater tubercle on the humerus. 

Rotator cuff muscles:

The rotator cuff is a group of 4 muscles (SITS) that stabilizes the shoulder joint:

Muscle Insertion Innervation
S: Supraspinatus Greater tubercle Suprascapular nerve
I: Infraspinatus Greater tubercle Suprascapular nerve 
T: Teres Minor Greater tubercle Axillary nerve
S: Subscapularis Lesser tubercle Upper and Lower subscapular nerve 

 

Clinical correlate - Shoulder impingement syndrome, also called subacromial impingement syndrome, is a clinical condition that occurs when the upper surface of the rotator cuff tendons becomes impinged under the coracoacromial arch.

 

The other marked structures in the cadaveric specimen shown are muscles that do not belong to the rotator cuff:

1 - Deltoid (supplied by the axillary nerve)

2 - Long head of triceps brachii (supplied by the radial nerve)

3 - Teres major (supplied by the lower subscapular nerve)

questions.text:
Match the given patients with the intermediate host of the most likely organism causing their symptoms.
Patient Intermediate host

1. A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly

A. Pig

2. A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema

 B. Sandfly

3. A man with a new-onset seizure and a cyst with a dot sign in MRI brain

 C. Human

4. A woman with fever and Maltese cross appearance in peripheral smear

 D. Culex mosquito
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C (option B).

Patient Intermediate host
1. A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly B. Sandfly
2. A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema D. Culex mosquito
3. A man with a new-onset seizure and a cyst with a dot sign in MRI brain A. Pig
4. A woman with fever and Maltese cross appearance in peripheral smear C. Human

 

A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly is likely suffering from Kala-azar caused by Leishmania donovani. Its intermediate host is sandfly.

 

A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema is likely suffering from lymphatic filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. Its intermediate host is the culex mosquito.

 

A man presenting with new-onset seizures and MRI brain showing cyst with a dot sign is likely suffering from neurocysticercosis caused by ingestion of Taenia solium eggs (Cysticercus cellulose). The intermediate host of Taenia solium is the pig.

 

A woman having fever with her peripheral smear showing Maltese cross appearance is likely suffering from babesiosis caused by Babesia microti. Its intermediate host is human.

questions.text: Which of the following salivary gland neoplasm is responsible for the given appearance in the Tc-99m radionuclide scan?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Warthin's tumor is the salivary gland tumor that appears as a hot spot on the technetium-99m scan as shown in the image.

Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich Warthin's tumor and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans.

Warthins tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum is the second most common benign tumor of the parotid gland. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a slow-growing, benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor and involves the lower pole of the parotid gland. It usually occurs unilaterally.

Treatment is superficial parotidectomy.

Grossly, they appear as round to oval encapsulated masses, 2-5 cm in diameter, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

The image below shows the gross appearance of Warthin's tumor. Note the well-encapsulated mass.

Histologically, Warthin's tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with a columnar luminal layer and a cuboidal layer. 


Other options:

Only a minority of salivary gland tumors show uptake on 99Tc scintigraphy. They include:

  • Warthins tumor
  • Oncocytoma of salivary glands

Tc-99m radionuclide scan is not done for pleomorphic adenoma, mucoepidermoid carcinoma, and adenoid cystic carcinoma as they show variable uptake. 

Option A: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and it most commonly involves the parotid gland (in about 60% of the cases). These are benign and mixed tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. They present in the buccal cavity, parotid, or submandibular area as a painless, slow-growing, mobile mass.

Histopathology:

Grossly, the tumor is rounded and well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in the greatest dimension. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma (image given below).

Microscopic features include the epithelial elements which resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells and these are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells. They are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles are seen in histopathology. The image is shown below.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells resemble swiss cheese due to an organized cribriform growth pattern. The image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of the atorvastatin drug. She measures the initial cholesterol levels of 50 patients. After a month's treatment, she measures the cholesterol level again. Which of the following tests will she use to test the statistical significance of the change in the cholesterol level?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the variable (cholesterol level) is quantitative. Moreover, the comparison is being done before and after the treatment (dependent). Hence, a paired t test will be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following can be used to assess his cerebral perfusion?
questions.solution:
Tc-HMPAO (technetium-99m hexamethyl propylenamine oxime) SPECT is used for the assessment of cerebral perfusion. In Alzheimer's disease, it shows reduced perfusion of the temporoparietal region.

Other options:

Option B: In-111 (Indium) DTPA is injected intrathecally to assess CSF flow.

Option C: Tc-99m (Technetium) MIBI is used for parathyroid scintigraphy.

Option D: Tl-201 (Thallium) is used in myocardial perfusion scanning.

questions.text: Match the following images of genital tract infections to their microscopic images.
questions.solution:
Image (i) is of a strawberry cervix, which matches image C for Trichomas vaginalis. Trichomonas vaginalis can be identified by the presence of racquet shaped protozoan with four anterior flagella and one posterior flagellum. 

 

Image (ii) is of white curdy discharge in the vagina, which matches image A for Candida albicans. On a KOH wet mount, hyphae and spores of candida are seen. On culture, they appear as discrete creamy rounded budding yeast with a specific yeast-like odor.  

 

Image (iii) is of a homogenous white discharge, which matches image B for Bacterial vaginosis usually associated with Gardanella vaginalis. It can be identified by the presence of motile pear-shaped flagellate organisms. 

One can also appreciate the presence of clue cells- epithelial cells having a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.

The image below shows the findings in bacterial vaginosis and the clue cells in the stained and wet mount preparation respectively.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking over a peanut. The child suddenly becomes unresponsive. What would you do as the next step of management?
questions.solution:
If a choking victim becomes unresponsive, call for help and immediately start CPR, beginning with chest compressions.

For pediatric CPR, if a single rescuer is present, then chest compression to ventilation is performed in a ratio of 30:2. If there are 2 or more rescuers, then the ratio is 15:2.

While giving rescue breaths, the airway is checked for a foreign body. If it is accessible, then the object can be removed. If not, then CPR is continued. Blind finger sweeping may be hazardous as it can push the object further down the airway.

If the child is responsive, then abdominal thrusts are performed to help relieve airway obstruction.

In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

The given pin index of 3, 5 is specific for nitrous oxide.

questions.text: The synovial fluid analysis in a 45-year-old patient with pain and swelling over his ankle and metatarsophalangeal joints revealed the following finding as given below. Which of the following is true about the crystals shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic long, slender, needle-shaped urate crystals found in Gout. They are negatively birefringent under polarized light. 

Precipitation of monosodium urate crystals (MSU) is the hallmark of Gout. The lower temperature of the peripheral joints promotes their precipitation. MSU crystals are frequently found in the cytoplasm of the neutrophils and are arranged in small clusters in the synovium.

One of the factors leading to the precipitation of these crystals is Lead toxicity (not copper). The condition is then known as Saturnine Gout.

In contrast, Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are deposited in pseudo-gout (also known as Chondrocalcinosis). Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are rhomboid and positively birefringent.

questions.text: You are about to administer neostigmine to a patient for reversal of neuromuscular blockade. Your senior asks you to add atropine to it. This is because atropine _______.

choices.text: Facilitates earlier recovery from neuromuscular blockade

questions.solution:
Atropine, a tertiary amine, is an anticholinergic drug that is used along with anticholinesterases like neostigmine in order to minimize the muscarinic adverse effects of anticholinesterases. It has no effect on the reversal of neuromuscular blockade produced by the nicotinic effect of anticholinesterases.

Atropine counteracts the cardiovascular effects of anticholinesterases like bradycardia and other bradyarrhythmias.

Glycopyrrolate, a quaternary amine, is another anticholinergic that can be used with anticholinesterases. It has a slower onset than atropine but does not cause central effects as it does not cross the blood-brain barrier, unlike atropine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable sign to clinically differentiate between a case of papillitis and papilledema?
questions.solution:
The most reliable sign to differentiate between papillitis and papilledema is pupillary reaction.  

Pupillary light reflex is normal in papilledema whereas it is sluggish in papillitis. Visual acuity and colour vision are also relatively more preserved in papilledema compared to papillitis.

The other three disc signs seen on ophthalmoscopy are present in both papillitis and papilledema.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is being treated for severe COVID with dexamethasone. Which of the following mechanisms best explain the rationale for starting steroids in this patient?
questions.solution:
Inhibition of phospholipase A2 is an anti-inflammatory effect of steroids, thus being the rationale for starting steroids in this patient.

Patients with severe COVID are at high risk of developing a systemic inflammatory response. Steroids help in mitigating these deleterious effects. 

Phospholipase A2 is a precursor of arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid is the precursor for prostaglandins and leukotrienes, which are involved in inflammation. Steroids induce the synthesis of lipocortin, which inhibits phospholipase A2. 

Other anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects of steroids are: 

  • Inhibit the production of interleukin-2 (IL-2) and proliferation of T lymphocytes
  • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin from mast cells and platelets

questions.text:
Match the following physical methods of torture to their respective descriptions.
Type of torture Description
1. Bastinado A. Tying the thighs and legs and compressing against bamboo sticks
2. Telefono B. Striking the abdomen while lying on a table with the head unsupported
3. Chepuwa C. Repeatedly striking the soles of the feet with an iron rod
4. Quirofano D. Suspending head down from a horizontal pole placed under the knees with the wrists bound to the ankles
5. Parrot's perch E. Repeated slapping on the ears
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-E, 3-A, 4-B, 5-D

Eponymous methods of physical torture commonly employed:

  • Falanga: Also known as Falaka or Bastinado, it is a method of torture that involves repeatedly striking the soles of the feet with an object such as a truncheon, iron rod, cable, bamboo cane, wooden pole, or rifle butt.
  • Telefono: This form of torture involves repeated slapping of the sides of the head (over the ears).
  • Chepuwa: This form of torture involves tying the thighs and legs very tightly with bamboo sticks to induce severe pain.
  • El quirofano: Beating on the abdomen while the victim is lying on a table with the upper half of the body unsupported
  • Jack/Parrot's perch: Head down from a horizontal pole placed under the knees with the wrists bound to the ankle.
  • Black slave: Inserting heated metal skewers inside the victim's anal canal.
  • Cattleprod: Passing a high voltage current through a pointed object (cattle prod)
  • Sawhorse: Forcing the victim to straddle on a bar
  • Wet-submarine: Forcefully immersing the victim's head into water, sewage, or any other fluid
  • Dry submarine: Tying of a plastic bag over the head up to the point of suffocation
  • Ghotna: This form of torture involves rolling a wooden log or an iron rod up and down the thigh, while the log is being weighted by one or two individuals standing on it.

questions.text: An obese patient with hypertension was started on nebivolol. In addition to the beta-receptor blockade, this also causes
questions.solution:
Nebivolol causes NO-mediated vasodilation in addition to the beta-receptor blockade.

Nebivolol is a third-generation beta-blocker with highly selective β1 receptor antagonism. In addition to its beta-blockade, it stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation through β2 receptor agonism.

It has no intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, membrane-stabilizing effect, or α1 blocking properties.

Nebivolol decreases blood pressure by reducing peripheral vascular resistance. It also increases the stroke volume with the preservation of cardiac output. 

Uses of nebivolol:

  • Hypertension
  • Heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction

Beta-blockers are classified into three generations:

  1. First-generation - Non-subtype selective drugs. Eg: Timolol, propanolol, pindolol
  2. Second-generation -  β1 selective drugs. Eg: Metoprolol, atenolol, acebutolol
  3. Third generation - Non-subtype or subtype-selective drugs with additional cardiovascular actions(especially vasodilation)

Third generation β blockers have additional mechanisms for vasodilation which include:

  • Nitric oxide production - Nebivolol, celiprolol, carteolol
  • β2 receptor agonism - Celiprolol,carteolol
  • α1 receptor antagonism - Carvedilol, labetolol
  • Calcium entry blockade - Carvedilol, betaxolol
  • K+ channel opening - Tilisolol
  • Antioxidant activity - Carvedilol

Beta-blockers and their specific properties:

  • Atenolol
  • Acebutolol
  • Bisoprolol
  • Nebivolol
Partial agonistic (intrinsic sympathomimetic) action
  • Pindolol
  • Celiprolol
  • Acebutolol
Membrane stabilizing activity
  • Propranolol
  • Oxprenolol
  • Acebutolol

questions.text: Arrange the following formulations of amphotericin B (AMB) according to the increasing order of nephrotoxicity.

choices.text: Conventional-AMB < Amphotericin B lipid complex < Liposomal amphotericin B
Liposomal amphotericin B < Conventional-AMB < Amphotericin B lipid complex
Conventional-AMB < Liposomal amphotericin B < Amphotericin B lipid complex
Liposomal amphotericin B < Amphotericin B lipid complex < Conventional-AMB

questions.solution:
The correct order of nephrotoxicity with amphotericin B formulations is liposomal amphotericin B < amphotericin B lipid complex < conventional-amphotericin B.

Nephrotoxicity with amphotericin B:

All lipid formulations of amphotericin B are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B. Liposomal amphotericin B is less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B lipid complex, especially in patients with a higher risk of nephrotoxicity. Azotemia is seen in 80% of cases with C-AMB. Renal tubular acidosis and renal wasting of potassium and magnesium are seen. Nephrotoxicity can be reduced by saline loading. 

Other adverse effects:

Infusion-related reactions - It is most prominent with amphotericin B colloidal dispersion. Fever and chills following IV injection is a major acute reactions. Tachypnea, hypotension, or respiratory stridor may be also seen. Meperidine is used to shorten the reaction.

Hypochromic normocytic anemia may be seen due to decreased erythropoietin.

Headache, nausea, malaise, vomiting, and phlebitis at the site of injection is also seen.

Arachnoiditis may be seen with intrathecal injections.

Formulations of amphotericin B:

C-AMB(Conventional amphotericin B): It is formulated with bile salt deoxycholate and is given as an intravenous infusion.

ABCD(Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion): It is formed by equimolar concentrations of amphotericin B and cholesteryl sulfate.

L-AMB(Liposomal amphotericin B): Here amphotericin B is incorporated within a small liposomal vesicle.

ABLC(Amphotericin B lipid complex): It is a complex of amphotericin B with two phospholipids.

Related Pearl: Nephrotoxicity risk with Amphotericin-B formulations (decreasing order)

Nephrotoxicity Risk with Amphotericin B formulations:
  • Conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) has the highest risk of nephrotoxicity.
  • C-AMB > Amphotericin B lipid complex > Liposomal amphotericin B.
Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion has not been compared with other lipid-based formulations. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy accidentally ate the fruit shown in the image below. He presents with blurred vision, slurred speech, urinary retention, and confusion. On examination, the pupils are dilated, the mouth is dry, and the face appears flushed. What is the antidote of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image of a cherry-like, highly toxic fruit are suggestive of Atropa belladonna poisoning. It is a deliriant poison. The appropriate antidote of choice is physostigmine.

Atropa belladonna acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

The signs and symptoms, treatment, and postmortem appearances are similar to those associated with Datura poisoning. Clinical manifestations can be remembered with 9D's: dryness of mouth, dysarthria, dysphagia, dilation of cutaneous blood vessels, diplopia, dry hot skin, drunken gait, delirium, and drowsiness. On examination, dilation of the pupils, flushing of the face, and congestion of the cornea can be seen.

Note:

Deliriant poisons are poisons that produce a well-marked deliriant or confusional stage, like Datura, Belladonna, Hyoscyamus, Cannabis, and cocaine.

Other options

Options A and B- Atropine and pralidoxime are antidotes used in organophosphorus poisoning.

Option C- Sodium amytal is used as an antidote for strychnine which is a spinal poison.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

Related Pearl: Toxic manifestations of Datura

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura
    • Dry hot skin (Temp rises upto 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
    • Diplopia
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
    • Dysphagia
    • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
    • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium
    • Drowsiness
    • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

questions.text: An elderly female presents with recurrent chalazion. The curettage specimen should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of _____.
questions.solution:
A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of sebaceous cell carcinoma.

A chalazion is a chronic and non-infective lipogranulamatous lesion that arises from the Meibomian glands (otherwise known as a tarsal/meibomian cyst). It is the most common lid swelling seen.

Patients present with painless swelling away from the lid margin. The upper eyelid is more commonly involved.

The image given below shows the chalazion.

Treatment of chalazion includes:

  • Conservative management for a very small, soft, and recent chalazion.
  • Incision and curettage is the more conventional method of managing a chalazion. The contents are curetted out using a chalazion scoop. 
  • Intralesional steroids for chalazion located near puncta to avoid the risk of surgical damage.

A chalazion may become infected and form a hordeolum internum. Also, a recurrently forming chalazion should be biopsied to rule out meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (a form of sebaceous cell carcinoma).

The image given below shows the Lambert’s chalazion clamp and Meyerhoefer chalazion scoop used in chalazion surgery.

Other options:

Note:

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common carcinoma of the lacrimal gland.
  • Basal cell carcinoma constitutes 85–90% of all malignant epithelial eyelid tumors. It is locally malignant and most commonly involves the lower lid, followed by the medial canthus, upper lid, and outer canthus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mono-oxygenase?
questions.solution:
Tryptophan pyrrolase is not a mono-oxygenase. Its a di-oxygenase.

Oxygenases catalyzes the incorporation of oxygen into a substrate. Oxygenases are of two types:

1) Mono-oxygenases (Hydroxylases/ Mixed-function oxidases): Incorporate one atom of oxygen into the substrate.

Examples:

  • Tryptophan hydroxylase 
  • Tyrosine hydroxylase
  • Cytochrome p450
  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase
  • 7-alpha hydroxylases

2) Di-oxygenases: Incorporate two atoms of oxygen into a substrate.

Examples:

  • Tryptophan pyrrolase
  • Homogentisate di-oxygenase (previously known as homogentisate oxidase)

Related Pearl: Enzyme classification

There are seven groups of enzymes according to IUBMB.

E.C. NO. Enzyme class Type of reaction catalyzed with examples
1 Oxidoreductases

Catalyze redox reactions

  • Dehydrogenase
  • Oxygenase
  • Oxidase
  • Catalase
  • Peroxidase
2 Transferases

Catalyze the transfer of functional groups from one substrate to another.

  • Kinases
  • Transaminases
  • Transmethylases
3 Hydrolases

Catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.

  • Lipase
  • Arginase
  • Pepsin
  • Esterase
4 Lyases

Catalyze the cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, thereby generating double bonds.

  • Aldolase
  • Fumarase
  • HMG-CoA lyase
  • Arginosuccinase
5 Isomerases

Catalyze structural changes within a molecule.

  • Phosphohexoisomerase
  • Mutase
  • Racemase
6 Ligases

Catalyze the joining together of two molecules in reactions.

  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • PRPP synthetase
  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase
  • Glutamine synthetase
7 Translocases Catalyze the movement of molecules or ions across membranes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old female child with polyneuropathy, sensorineural deafness, and cerebellar ataxia has the following finding on fundus examination. Lab reveals increased blood levels of phytanic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows fundoscopy findings of retinitis pigmentosa. This along with the given clinical scenario is suggestive of Refsum’s disease. 

Refsum's disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood. 

In this condition, the enzyme phytanoyl CoA hydroxylase is defective and causes the accumulation of phytanic acid. Clinically, patients present with dysmorphic facies and severe neurological symptoms such as polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, ichthyosis, and cerebellar ataxia. Regression of symptoms is observed with restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid. Therefore, management includes avoiding sources of phytanic acid such as dairy products, meat, nuts, and green leafy vegetables.

Note: The Zellweger spectrum is a continuum of diseases of persoxisome defects with Zellweger syndrome (most severe) at one end, neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy in the middle (intermediate severity) and infantile Refsum's disease (least severe) at the other end.

Option B- Usher syndrome is characterized by sensorineural deafness and retinitis pigmentosa (but symptoms are not affected by restricting phytanic acid)

Option C- Zellweger Syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX/Peroxin family of genes involved in peroxisome biogenesis /peroxisomal enzymes. There is severe neurologic symptoms and patients usually die in the 1st year of life.

Option D- Adrenoleukodystrophy is a disorder of β-oxidation of fatty acids. There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and testes.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are suggestive of an artificial bruise?

1. Location at a site accessible to the patient
2. Location at a site not accessible to the patient
3. Presence of blisters
4. Absence of blisters
5. Presence of itching
questions.solution:
Location at a site that is accessible to the patient, the presence of blisters, and itching are features suggestive of an artificial bruise. 

Artificial bruises are caused by the application of certain irritant substances such as the juice of marking nut and roots or twigs of Plumbago rosea to simulate true bruises. However, the following features can be used to distinguish between the two entities.

Trait Artificial bruise True bruise
Site Accessible to the patient Anywhere
Color Dark brown Typical color progression over time
Shape Irregular Regular
Margins Well defined and regular Ill-defined and irregular
Vesicles/Blisters Present Absent
Redness/Inflammation Present in the surrounding skin Present over bruise
Itching Present Absent
Ecchymosis Absent Present
Chemical tests Positive Negative

Bruises cannot be produced after 2 minutes of death. However, small bruises can be developed by violent forces even up to 3 hours after death. Antemortem bruises can be differentiated from postmortem bruises by the following features:

Features Antemortem bruise Postmortem bruise
Swelling Present Absent
Damage to epithelium Present Absent
Extravastion of blood Present Absent
Inflammation in tissues Present Absent

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration

Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text: In a patient with a head injury who presents with fixed dilated pupils and rapidly deteriorating neurological signs, where is the burr hole made?

choices.text: Temporal region contralateral to the side of pupillary dilatation
Midline as it is not known which side of pupil dilated first
Left temporal region if no localising sign found
Right temporal region if no localising sign found

questions.solution:
In the given situation, the best choice would be to do a burr hole in the left temporal region since no localizing sign was found and it is not known which pupil dilated first.

When making the initial burr hole, the temporal region is entered first. The side chosen for this initial temporal burr hole depends on the following:

  • In > 85% of cases starting ipsilateral to a dilated pupil will be the correct side 
  • If both pupils are dilated, use the side of the first dilating pupil, if known
  • If pupils are equal, or it is not known which side dilated first, place the burr hole on the side of obvious external trauma
  • If there are no localization clues, hole is placed on the left side – to evaluate and decompress the dominant hemisphere.

questions.text: In which of the following organisms will the following phenomenon not be observed in?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Quellung reaction (halo around the bacteria) and is seen in capsulated bacteria. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not capsulated, therefore Quellung reaction will not be observed in it. 

In Quellung reaction, a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope. The anticapsular antibodies bind to the capsule and thus the capsule becomes very prominent and appears swollen. Capsulated organisms can be remembered with the following mnemonic: 

Some - Streptococcus pneumoniae

Killers - Klebsiella pneumoniae

Have - Haemophilus influenzae

Nice - Neisseria meningitidis

Capsules - Cryptococcus neoformans

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with body pain and easy fatigability. Investigations revealed a hemoglobin level of 7 gm/dL.  The peripheral smear revealed macrocytic hypochromic cells and hypersegmented neutrophils. Further investigations revealed elevated serum levels of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid. This condition may also lead to?

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency may lead to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. 

Megaloblastic anemia can be due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. In vitamin B12 deficiency, serum levels of both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid are elevated whereas, in folate deficiency, only homocysteine levels are elevated.

Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord occurs due to defective myelin synthesis which leads to degeneration of the ascending and descending spinal tracts. It presents with symmetrical paraesthesia and progresses to weakness, ataxia, and spasticity. Complications include complete paraplegia. It can be treated by the administration of vitamin B12. 

Other options:

Option A- Syringomyelia is characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled cavity in the spinal cord. It is associated with Chiari I malformation. It leads to progressive myelopathy and presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper limbs.

Option B- Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is an encephalitis caused when JC polyomavirus infects the oligodendrocytes and leads to demyelination. It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. The patients develop focal and progressive neurological symptoms.

Option D- Central pontine myelinolysis occurs due to the loss of myelin in the base of the pons. It occurs after rapid correction of hyponatremia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism
