questions.text: A biochemist is studying the process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBCs, back to glucose inside the liver and kidney cells. This conversion cycle is called as _________
questions.solution:
The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBCs, back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle. It links gluconeogenesis and anaerobic glycolysis.

Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and RBCs. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. This entire process is called Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle.

Significance: The cycle's importance is based on the prevention of lactic acidosis in the muscle under anaerobic conditions. However, normally before this happens the lactic acid is moved out of the muscles and into the liver.

Other options

Option A- Cahill cycle is also called the glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from skeletal muscle obtained from glycolysis of muscle glycogen. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Option C- Kreb's cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins because glucose, fatty acids, and most amino acids are metabolized to acetyl-CoA or intermediates of the cycle.

Option D- Urea cycle is also known as the Krebs–Henseleit cycle. It forms urea by detoxifying ammonia in the liver.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be seen in a patient with nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech), not rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal speech).

The patients present with progressive nasal obstruction and hyponasal speech due to mass in the postnasal space. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation. The patients may be markedly anemic due to repeated blood loss.

Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion occur due to obstruction of the eustachian tube.

It can spread to the orbit giving rise to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to frog face deformity. Other features include swelling of the cheek and cranial nerve palsies (II, III, IV, and VI).

questions.text:
Read the pedigree chart and identify the disorder which follows this pattern.

G6PD- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

MELAS- mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the image is an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance, which is seen in G-6-PD deficiency.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. Its deficiency commonly manifests as neonatal jaundice and episodic acute hemolytic anemia. The common provoking agents are infections, some drugs like sulfa drugs/ quinine group, and fava beans.

Other options:

Option A: Gaucher's disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder that arises due to the deficiency of β-glucosidase. It is characterized by hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, bone pain, and pathological fractures.

Option B: Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive condition due to the deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This leads to the accumulation of galactose and subsequent tissue damage.

The following image depicts autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

Option D: MELAS (mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) follows a mitochondrial inheritance pattern.

questions.text:
While administering an axillary nerve block for a patient, the resident accidentally injects the anesthetic agent into the axillary artery. Which of the following co-morbidities if present can accentuate the condition?
  1. Increased age
  2. Hypercapnia
  3. Renal failure
  4. Metabolic alkalosis
  5. Cardiac failure
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). Increased age, hypercapnia, renal failure, and cardiac failure can accentuate LAST. Acidosis (respiratory or metabolic), and not alkalosis, can also increase LAST.

LAST can occur due to inadvertent injection of a local anesthetic (LA), intravascular migration of a catheter used for continuous LA infusion, and absorption from the mucus membranes and the GI tract when swallowed (used during bronchoscopy).

The risk factors for LAST are:

  • Extremes of age: Infants and the elderly
  • End organ dysfunction: Cardiac disease, renal insufficiency, hepatic disease
  • Metabolic disturbances: Acidosis, hypoxia, hypercarbia
  • Pregnancy

LAST affects the following systems:

  • Central nervous system (CNS): LAs predominantly block the cortical inhibitory pathways, thereby causing excitatory symptoms and signs like a metallic taste, perioral numbness, mental status changes, visual changes, muscle twitching, and seizures. Further increase in blood levels causes CNS depression, leading to respiratory depression and coma. 
  • Cardiovascular system (CVS): Bradycardia and hypotension are usually seen. Cardiovascular toxicity may progress to ventricular arrhythmias, asystole, conduction disturbances, impaired cardiac contractility, and loss of vascular tone.

Management includes:

  • Stop administration of the agent
  • Arrange for cardiopulmonary bypass
  • Manage airway to prevent hypoxia and acidosis
  • Suppress seizures with appropriate medication (benzodiazepine is preferred) to improve oxygenation
  • Provide cardiovascular support with appropriate medication (amiodarone for arrhythmia) to maintain coronary perfusion
  • Administer 20% lipid emulsion:
    • Rapid administration of bolus lipid emulsion over 2-3 min
    • Begin infusion based on patient's body weight
    • Repeat bolus and double the infusion rate for persistent cardiovascular toxicity
    • Continue infusion for at least 10 min after hemodynamic stability is achieved

Related Pearl: Systemic Absorbtion of Local Anaesthetic in the Order of Occurrence

Systemic absorption of a local anesthetic depends on vascularity.

The highest blood concentrations are seen following:

  1. Intravenous (intraarterial) injection (maximum)
  2. Intercostal nerve blockade
  3. Paracervical block
  4. Caudal epidural block
  5. Lumbar epidural block
  6. Brachial plexus block
  7. Sciatic block
  8. Subcutaneous injection (minimum)

questions.text: A 63 year old male patient is admitted with atrial fibrillation. He is a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. What will you prescribe for long term management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Patients with atrial fibrillation are scored according to the CHA2DS2-VASc scoring, to assess the risk of stroke. This patient has a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 (1-hypertension, 1-diabetes mellitus) and hence, oral anticoagulants (like warfarin) should be prescribed for long term management of this patient.

Treatment based on CHA2DS2-VASc scoring is as follows: 

CHADS2 score Antithrombotics
0 Aspirin or no antithrombotics
1 Aspirin or oral anticoagulant
2 or more Oral anticoagulant

Anticoagulants that can be used include:

  • Vitamin K antagonist-Warfarin
  • Antithrombin inhibitor- Dabigatran
  • Factor Xa inhibitors - Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, and Edoxaban

Note :

A newer scoring system used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with non-valvular AF is the CHA2DS2-VASc scoring.

Following risk factors are considered during the calculation of the score:

Risk factors Score
Congestive heart failure 1
Hypertension 1
Age ≥75years 2
Diabetes mellitus 1
Stroke or Transient ischemic attack or embolus 2
Vascular disease 1
Age 65-75years 1
Sex- female 1

questions.text: A young man comes to you with hair loss as shown in the image given below. You prescribe finasteride to prevent his condition from worsening. Which isoform (s) of 5-alpha reductase does this drug inhibit?
questions.solution:
This man has male-pattern hair loss. Finasteride selectively inhibits type 2 5α‐reductase within the hair follicle. Hence, it is used in the treatment of male-pattern hair loss.

The 5α‐reductase enzyme converts testosterone to the more potent form of dihydrotestosterone (DHT). 5α‐Reductase exists in 3 isoforms. Type 1 and 3 are widely distributed in the skin and not involved in hair growth.

Type 2 is present in androgen-responsive tissues such as the dermal papillae of the hair follicle, prostate, epididymides, and seminal vesicles. Type 2 5α‐reductase also plays a key role in regulating androgen-dependent hair growth.

Hair growth in the following areas is androgen dependent:

  • Beard, chest, and extremity hair in males
  • Scalp, pubic, and axillary hair in both sexes 

Male-pattern hair loss: 

Male-pattern hair loss causes thinning of the vertex and an M-shaped receding hairline, as shown below. High levels of circulating androgens stimulate hair loss in certain sites by a process called miniaturization. Finasteride reverses this process.

questions.text: A throat swab taken from a patient who presented with fever, dysphagia and cervical lymphadenopathy was sent for culture on potassium tellurite agar. The resultant colonies had a poached egg appearance. Which among the following is the most likely organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Poached egg colonies on potassium tellurite agar indicate Corynebacterium diphtheriae mitis.

Macleod classified diphtheria bacilli based on colony morphology on tellurite blood agar into the following three types:

  • Gravis: They form daisy head colonies and are variably hemolytic. They ferment glycogen and starch. 
  • Intermedius: They form frog’s egg colonies and are non-hemolytic. They do not ferment glycogen and starch.
  • Mitis: They form poached egg colonies and are hemolytic. They do not ferment glycogen and starch.

The following image shows the various colony morphologies of C. diphtheriae.

questions.text:
Which of the following amino acids cannot be used for the synthesis of glucose through gluconeogenesis?
  1. Isoleucine
  2. Alanine
  3. Leucine
  4. Tryptophan
  5. Lysine
questions.solution:
Leucine and lysine yield only acetyl-CoA on oxidation (ketogenesis), and hence, they cannot be used for gluconeogenesis.

Most of the amino acids in excess yield pyruvate or the intermediates of the citric acid cycle. Pyruvate can be carboxylated to oxaloacetate, which is the primary substrate for gluconeogenesis. Thus, these amino acids that yield pyruvate or oxaloacetate are classified as glucogenic. The actions of transaminases, alanine, cysteine, glycine, hydroxyproline, serine, threonine, and tryptophan yield pyruvate. 

Lysine and leucine yield only acetyl-CoA on oxidation, and hence cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Since these yield only acetyl-CoA, these are classified as ketogenic. 

Four other amino acids, namely, phenylalanine, tyrosine, tryptophan, and isoleucine, give rise to both acetyl-CoA and intermediates; therefore, they can be used for both ketogenesis and gluconeogenesis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with bilateral flank pain and blood in the urine. His daily medications include lisinopril for hypertension. His father passed away from a cerebrovascular accident at the age of 50. The physician diagnoses him with polycystic kidney disease. Which of the following statements are true regarding this disease?
  1. It is an autosomal dominant condition.
  2. Mutated Polycystin-1 & 2 proteins seen.
  3. Associated with cysts in DCT and collecting duct.
  4. It is generally diagnosed in-utero.
  5. Associated with mitral valve prolapse and colonic diverticula.

DCT - Distal convoluted tubule
questions.solution:
Option D - The true statements regarding autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) are 1, 2, and 5.

This patient presenting with flank pain, hematuria, and hypertension is most likely suffering from autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Mutations in the genes PKD1 (chromosome 16 - coding for Polycystin-1) or PKD2 (chromosome 4 - coding for Polycystin-2) form the genetic basis for this condition. 

ADPDK is characterized by the progressive formation of epithelial-lined cysts in the bilateral kidneys that ultimately leads to loss of normal functioning renal tissue. Many patients do not have any symptoms until they are 40-50 years of age. The clinical manifestations include flank pain, hematuria (from cyst rupture), and hypertension due to increased Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS) activation. 

Abdominal ultrasound imaging is the investigation of choice. It reveals bilateral cortical and medullary cysts in about 95% of the patients.

Extrarenal manifestations of the disease include benign hepatic cysts, intracranial aneurysms, mitral valve prolapse, and colonic diverticula.

Here is an ultrasound image depicting a case of advanced ADPKD with multiple cysts.

 

Other statements- 

Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD) is another inherited condition associated with the mutation of a single gene PKHD1 that codes for the protein fibrocystin. It differs from ADPKD in the sense that it is usually diagnosed in-utero (as opposed to the adult patient in the question stem).

Affected neonates already have enlarged echogenic kidneys that cause decreased urine production, oligohydramnios, and subsequently, pulmonary hypoplasia. Neonates affected by the classic form of ARPKD already have renal insufficiency and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) at birth. Abdominal ultrasound imaging shows cysts in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

Extrarenal manifestations of ARPKD include congenital hepatic fibrosis and dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts (Caroli disease).

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips. Chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped heart due to an upturned cardiac apex. The finding seen on the chest X-ray is due to:
questions.solution:
The clinical description of shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips, along with boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, suggests tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The findings of a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex is due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition. The four cardinal features of the tetralogy of Fallot are as follows:

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract (subpulmonary stenosis)
  • An aorta that overrides the ventricular septum
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

The image given below shows cardinal features seen in TOF:

 

Children with TOF usually present with dyspnea on exertion, they characteristically assume a squatting position for relief of dyspnea. During anoxic spells, children start crying, become dyspneic and cyanotic, and may eventually lose consciousness. 

A chest x-ray of a child with TOF typically shows a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex. This is mainly because of right ventricular hypertrophy. Other chest x-ray features in tetralogy of Fallot are:

  • Pulmonary oligaemia (due to pulmonary stenosis)
  • Normal size heart (heart failure is not a feature in TOF)
  • Right-sided aortic arch (25%)

Medical management with oral propranolol prevents cyanotic spells, surgical correction is the definitive treatment of choice. The intravenous administration of prostaglandin E1 can be tried to keep ductus arteriosus open while awaiting surgery.

Given below is a chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped heart (cœur en sabot in French).

questions.text:
Which of the following pharmacological agents are approved for use in the management of COVID19?
  1. Tocilizumab
  2. Baricitnib
  3. Crizanlizumab
  4. Remdesivir
  5. Ublituximab
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option b.

The drugs that have been approved for use in the management of COVID19 are tocilizumab, baricitnib, and remdesivir. Recent updates regarding these drugs are mentioned below. 

Tocilizumab an IL-6 inhibitor in combination with dexamethasone is approved for emergency usage and is recommended in the management of hospitalized patients with rapid respiratory decompensation due to covid. Tocilizumab is also used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and juvenile idiopathic arthritis. 

Baricitnib is a Janus kinase inhibitor approved for emergency usage in the management of hospitalized COVID patients requiring supplemental oxygen, invasive mechanical ventilation, or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

Remdesivir, the FDA-approved antiviral drug works by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. The guidelines panel of the WHO recently issued a conditional recommendation against the use of remdesivir in hospitalized COVID patients, regardless of disease severity, as there is currently no evidence that remdesivir improves survival. As per the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare guidelines, in India, remdesivir is considered in moderate and severe hospitalized COVID patients requiring supplemental oxygen/oxygen delivery. Contraindications of remdesivir are as follows:

  • AST/ALT > 5 times upper limit of normal
  • Severe renal impairment (i.e., eGFR < 30ml/min/m2 or need for hemodialysis) 
  • Pregnancy or lactating females 
  • Children <12 years of age

Other options:

Ublituximab (TG-1101) is an investigational glycoengineered monoclonal antibody that is under development for Non-Hodgkin lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis.

Crizanlizumab is a monoclonal antibody that is FDA approved to reduce the frequency of vaso-occlusive crises in adults and pediatric patients aged 16 years and older with sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. What is the appropriate medical management?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of a catatonic disorder. Benzodiazepines such as lorazepam are effective in the treatment of catatonia.

Catatonia is a syndrome characterized by striking behav­ioral abnormalities such as motoric immobility or excite­ment, negativism, or echolalia (mimicry of speech), or echopraxia (mimicry of movement).

The clinical picture may include three or more of the following features:

  1. Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  2. Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  3. Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  4. Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  5. Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  6. Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  7. Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  8. Automatic obedience: Commands are followed automatically, irrespective of their nature.
  9. Grimacing
  10. Ambitendency: Due to ambivalence, opposing actions are carried out.
  11. Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  12. Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.
  13. Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.
  14. Verbigeration: Incomprehensible speech.

Catatonic disorder may occur due to:

  • Advanced mood or psychotic illnesses
  • Neurologi­cal disorders (e.g., nonconvulsive status epilepticus, and head trauma)
  • Infections (e.g., encephalitis)
  • Metabolic disturbances (e.g., hepatic encephalopathy, hyponatremia, and hypercalcemia)
  • Drugs induced- like corticoste­roids, immunosuppressants, and antipsychotics (i.e., neurolep­tic) agents.

Management: The primary treatment includes:

  • Identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed.
  • Benzodiazepines, especially, lorazepam, are effective in improving the symptoms.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy is the definitive treatment in cases of life-threatening catatonia (if the patient is unable to eat) or if the patient has developed malignant catatonia.

questions.text: A patient in the postoperative ward was under opioid medication for pain relief. His respiratory rate was 7 cycles/min. Which of the following acid-base abnormality will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of decreased respiratory rate in a patient receiving opioids is suggestive of opioid overdose. The acid-base abnormality seen in this condition is respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Opioid overdose causes respiratory depression and hypoventilation. Hypoventilation results in the accumulation of carbon dioxide, thereby increasing PaCO2 levels (hypercapnia). The increase in PaCO2, in turn, decreases the bicarbonate (HCO3–)/PaCO2 ratio, thereby decreasing the pH. This is called respiratory acidosis (low pH, high PaCO2).

Physiological compensation takes place to bring the pH back to normal. In acute respiratory acidosis, the body’s compensation occurs in 2 steps. The initial response is cellular buffering that takes place over minutes to hours. Cellular buffering causes a slight elevation in plasma bicarbonate values. The second step is renal compensation that occurs over 3-5 days. With renal compensation, renal excretion of carbonic acid is increased, and bicarbonate reabsorption is increased.

Respiratory changes (changes in PCO2) promote a corresponding change in metabolic response (changes in HCO3-) and vice versa as a compensatory mechanism. In general, PCO2 and HCO3- move in the same direction for compensation in metabolic and respiratory acid-base disorders, respectively. A change in the two parameters in opposite directions points to a mixed acid-base disturbance. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Ethylene glycol intoxication

Diarrhoea

Renal tubular acidosis

Vomiting

Hyperaldosteronism

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

Guillain- Barre syndrome, Polio, ALS, multiple sclerosis

Airway obstruction

Adult respiratory distress syndrome, COPD

Pneumonia, pulmonary embolism

High altitude

Psychogenic

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: An elderly primigravida presented at 26 weeks of gestation. A 75 gram two-hour oral glucose tolerance test revealed a blood sugar level of 175 mg/dL. A diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus was made. Which of the following hormones is not responsible for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of an elderly primigravida in her second trimester with a 75 gram 2-hour plasma glucose level of >153 mg/dL is diagnostic of gestational diabetes mellitus. The reason for developing gestational diabetes mellitus is insulin resistance, in which hCG has no role.

Maternal blood glucose levels increase in the second half of pregnancy to facilitate increased glucose transfer from the mother to the fetus. As feedback, there is hyperplasia and hypertrophy of the beta cells of islets of Langerhans in the maternal pancreas, causing hyperinsulinemia (especially in the third trimester) and a decrease in the levels of glucose available to the fetus. To ensure a continuous supply of glucose to the fetus, the placenta secretes certain hormones that increase insulin resistance in the mother.

Pregnancy being a state of low-grade inflammation is marked by factors like IL-6 and C-reactive proteins that also contribute to insulin resistance. Insulin resistance is seen maximally between 24 to 28 weeks. The hormones responsible for insulin resistance in pregnancy include,

  • Human placental lactogen 
  • Progesterone and estrogen
  • Placental growth hormone 
  • Cortisol
  • Prolactin

The screening method for GDM recommended in India is a 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) irrespective of the last meal timing. A value of ≥140 mg/dL after 2 hours is considered a positive test, indicating GDM. Universal screening is done for all pregnant women. The first testing should be done during the first antenatal contact as early as possible in pregnancy. The second testing should be done during 24-28 weeks of pregnancy if the first test is negative (as in this case). 

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes

  • Preeclampsia

    • Posterior valve

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is being evaluated for a lesion in the skull for the past few months. The mother gives a history that there is an increase in the size of the swelling. There is no history of trauma. There are no other significant examination findings. The X-ray skull of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements are true regarding the most likely diagnosis for this presentation?

1) It is associated with vertebra plana

2) It produces lesions with a hole within a hole appearance.

3) Birbeck granules are seen in electron microscopy.

4) Cells show positive staining for S-100 protein.
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the X-ray showing the punched-out lesion in the skull are suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. All the statements are true regarding this condition.

Clinical features:

The child can be asymptomatic or can present with pain and local swelling. Skeletal involvement is seen in the majority(80%) of the cases. It may be the only affected site especially in children of more than 5 years. Skull is the commonest site of involvement. Lymphadenopathy is seen in about one-third of the cases and can be localized or disseminated. Skin involvement can be in the form of scaly, seborrheic dermatitis affecting the scalp, diaper, or axillary regions.

Other manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, exophthalmos, otitis media, pituitary dysfunction, hypothyroidism, and diabetes insipidus. Systemic manifestations like fever, weight loss, irritability, malaise, and failure to thrive are seen in patients with multisystemic disease.

Radiographic findings:

  • Vertebra plana or marked flattening of the vertebral body. It is the most common cause of vertebra plana.
  • Punched-out lesions in flat bones like the skull.
  • Different involvement of the two tables can produce a hole within a hole appearance.

Microscopic findings:

The presence of Langerhans cells is diagnostic. It is a histiocytic cell and has an indented nucleus, abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a crisp nuclear membrane. Birbeck granules are characteristic organelles in the cytoplasm of Langerhans cells that is seen in electron microscopic examination. Cells show positive staining for S-100 protein.

Management:

Diagnosis is confirmed by a biopsy of the lesion. Spontaneous regression is seen in asymptomatic lesions. Symptomatic cases are managed with intralesional steroid injection, low-dose radiotherapy, and curettage of the lesion. Multiagent chemotherapy is indicated for multisystemic disease.

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: A patient was administered rocuronium as a muscle relaxant during surgery. However, the surgeon was able to finish the procedure sooner than expected. What specific reversal agent will you use?
questions.solution:
The specific reversal agent that can terminate the action of rocuronium is sugammadex.

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It acts by forming complexes with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium, vecuronium).

Rocuronium at higher doses can be used in rapid sequence intubation. However, the only downside is its long duration of action. This obstacle can be overcome by sugammadex, which will reverse its effects.

Other options-

Option (A): Neostigmine reversal requires a baseline twitch response. Sugammadex, on the other hand, can be administered at any depth muscle blockade, thereby making it more useful.

Option (C) and Option (D): Atropine and glycopyrrolate are administered along with anticholinesterases pre-operatively to reduce muscarinic side effects like bradycardia. They are not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fever and joint pain develops the following lesion on her nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of fever and joint pain along with centrofacial hyperpigmentation shown in the image point towards a diagnosis of chikungunya. Hyperpigmentation associated with chikungunya fever is macular and most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. 

Nose pigmentation is striking in cases of Chikungunya fever and is termed as Chik sign. It appears as the fever subsides and persists for about 3-6 months.

Hyperpigmentation of the centrofacial face (nose and cheeks) mimics melasma and may be misdiagnosed if proper history is not taken. 

Another close differential is fixed drug eruptions (FDE). FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by well-defined brown, hyperpigmented plaques that may follow vesiculobullous lesions. They occur on lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation. They usually present 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure and recur at the same location on re-exposure. NSAIDs, Paracetamol and Co‐trimoxazole are the most common drugs causing FDE.

The image below shows FDE on upper lip area:

questions.text: Which of the following ophthalmic conditions can cause staphyloma at point X in the given image?
questions.solution:
Developmental glaucoma is one of the most common causes of ciliary staphyloma (Point X). Ciliary staphyloma is located in the ciliary zone, up to 8mm behind the limbus.

Staphyloma is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

Types of Staphyloma:

  • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which commonly occurs after the total sloughing of a corneal ulcer. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
  • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
  • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. Developmental glaucoma, endstage primary or secondary glaucoma are the most common causes of ciliary staphyloma
  • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
  • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye. This condition is usually associated with degenerative high axial myopia. Posterior scleritis may also lead to the development of this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with an unsteady gait, forgetfulness, and labile moods.  Physical examination is remarkable for the ocular Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring and examination findings as shown below. Which of the following options correctly indicate the gene most likely mutated in this condition and its location?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Wilson's disease. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by a mutation in the ATP7B gene located on chromosome 13.

The ATP7B gene encodes a transmembrane copper-transporting ATPase, expressed on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane. In Wilson disease, there is a deficiency in the ATP7B protein. This causes a decrease in copper excretion into the bile, impairs its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and inhibits ceruloplasmin secretion into the blood, leading to the accumulation of toxic levels of copper in the liver, brain, and eye.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor(shown in the gif in question)- It is a low‐frequency, high‐amplitude, tremor, elicited by sustained abduction of the arms, with flexed elbows and palms facing downwards.
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring - It is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea

The image below shows the ocular KF ring.

 

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and zinc are the first choice of drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Note: 

Menkes disease is an X-linked metabolic disturbance of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the copper-transporting ATP7A gene.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: In a pregnant woman, on performing Leopold's 1st grip, you are able to palpate a freely mobile, hard and globular mass. Which of the following fetal parts is the denominator in this case?
questions.solution:
If a freely mobile, hard and globular mass is found on the 1st Leopold's grip, the fetus is in a longitudinal lie, in podalic/ breech presentation, and hence will have sacrum as the denominator.

The fetal denominator refers to the bony fixed point of reference on the presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis. The denominators for various presentations are as follows:

Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

 Note: The question refers to a breech pregnancy hence the part felt on the 1st Leopold's grip would be a smooth, hard globular mass indicative of head. The image provided is that of a fetus in a normal longitudinal lie, vertex presentation.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers:

Leopold grip Also known as Importance
First Fundal grip To know which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.
Second Lateral/ Umbilical grip To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlick grip

To know the presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis
Fourth Pelvic grip

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head

 

Interpretation of various fetal parts felt in Leopold's grips:

  • Large, soft, nodular mass - indicates breech 
  • Hard, round, mobile mass - indicates head  
  • Uniform curved hard resistance- indicates back
  • Small, irregular, mobile parts- indicate fetal extremities 

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

  • Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine.
  • Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis.
  • Presenting part: Part of the presentation which overlies the internal os.
  • Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another.
  • Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old multipara presents with a blood picture showing hypersegmented neutrophils and typical pencil cells. MCV is normal. This condition is managed by supplementing:

1- Folic acid
2- Iron
3- Vitamin B12
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation most likely indicates a case of dimorphic anemia, and such cases are managed by supplementation with iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12. 

From the given description of the histopathological picture:

  • Pencil cells indicate iron-deficiency anemia
  • Hyper-segmented neutrophils indicate folic acid/vitamin B12–deficiency anemia.

MCV is generally low in iron-deficiency anemia, while it is high in cases of megaloblastic anemia secondary to folate and cyanocobalamine deficiency. Thus, a normal MCV excludes both these conditions individually and is more likely to favor a combination of both. This patient most likely has dimorphic anemia due to coexisting iron and folic acid deficiency. 

Nutritional anemia, which is an important cause of dimorphic anemia, is a significant problem worldwide.

Blood pictures in dimorphic anemia will have features of both iron-deficiency anemia and folic acid–deficiency anemia.

Blood picture in iron-deficiency anemia:

  • Microcytic hypochromic RBCs
  • Presence of poikilocytosis in the form of characteristic pencil cells

Blood picture in folic acid/Vit B12–deficiency anemia:

  • Hypersegmented neutrophils
  • Macrocytic RBCs

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with palpitations.  ECG shows a short PR interval and slurred QRS complexes as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome based on the clinical features and ECG showing the characteristic delta-wave. 

Short PR intervals and wide QRS complexes with delta waves (slurred and slow initial upstroke) are diagnostic ECG features of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

 

In this syndrome, there is an abnormal conduction pathway between the atria and ventricles called the bundle of Kent. Compared to the atrioventricular (AV) node, electrical conduction is faster through the accessory pathway. This setup facilitates the circus movement of electrical impulses. 

 

Treatment for WPW includes:

  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs from classes Ia (procainamide)and class III (ibutilide).
  • Electrical cardioversion if the patient is hemodynamically unstable
  • Radiofrequency ablation of the aberrant pathway (definitive treatment)

Other options:

Option A: AV nodal re-entry tachycardia (AVNRT) is due to a reentrant mechanism through multiple pathways connecting the atrium and AV node. The P wave is usually not seen, but sometimes appears as a pseudo-r' in lead V1 (black arrow) and pseudo-S waves in leads II, III, and aVF (blue arrows). Narrow QRS complexes (green arrows) are seen. It is the most common paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia for which vagal maneuvers such as the Valsalva maneuver and carotid sinus massage can be tried.

 

Option B: Junctional tachycardia, commonly seen in children with congenital heart diseases. It arises due to automaticity in the AV node. ECG shows narrow QRS complexes. 

Option D: In atrial flutter, sawtooth flutter waves are seen in leads II, III, and aVF with an atrial rate of 240-300 beats per minute. The condition is often associated with a 2:1 AV block and narrow QRS complexes.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: The following hemorrhoids in a patient prolapse through the anus on straining but reduces spontaneously. It belongs to which grade?
questions.solution:
Grade 2 hemorrhoids prolapse on straining and reduce spontaneously afterward.

Grading of hemorrhoids:

Grades of internal haemorrhoids           Description
Grade 1 Bleeding only
Grade 2 Bleeding and protrusion, with spontaneous reduction
Grade 3 Bleeding and protrusion that require manual reduction
Grade 4 Bleeding and prolapse that cannot be reduced.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibers that are located in the anal canal. They can be classified into external and internal hemorrhoids according to their location.

Image below shows the endoscopic picture and diagrammatic representation of the first-degree hemorrhoids.

 

Image below shows the second-degree hemorrhoids.

 

Image below shows the third-degree hemorrhoids.

 

Image below shows the fourth-degree hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Grading of hemorrhoids

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done

questions.text:
Match the following.
1) Verocay bodies A) Granulosa cell tumor
2) Cowdry type-A bodies B) Asbestosis
3) Call-Exner bodies C) Herpes simplex infection
4) Ferruginous bodies D) Schwannoma
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, and 4-B.

  • Verocay bodies - Schwannoma
  • Cowdry type-A bodies - Herpes simplex infection
  • Call-Exner bodies - Granulosa cell tumor
  • Ferruginous bodies - Asbestosis

Verocay bodies: It is seen in microscopic examination of schwannoma.

Schwannoma consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The Antoni A areas contain densely arranged spindle-shaped cells. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain loosely arranged spindle-shaped cells. These cells are separated by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

Cowdry type-A bodies

The Cowdry type-A bodies are large eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions seen in Herpes simplex virus infection. They appear as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo.

Call-Exner bodies :

It is occasionally seen in cases of granulosa cell tumors. These are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles.

Ferruginous bodies

They are formed by inorganic particulates like asbestos coated with iron-protein complexes. It is seen in asbestosis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old lady who underwent suction evacuation for molar pregnancy visits you on postoperative week 8 for her follow-up. Which of the following is not done during the follow-up of this patient?
  1. Ask her for a history of any irregular vaginal bleeding, cough, or breathlessness.
  2. Perform an abdominal examination to look for the size of the uterus and the ovaries.
  3. Perform a pelvic examination to look for sub-urethral nodules
  4. Request for a serum hCG value, a pelvic ultrasound, and chest X-ray PA view 
  5. Insert a copper-T device to avoid pregnancy
questions.solution:
Insertion of a copper-T device to avoid pregnancy is not done during follow-up of this patient.

Intrauterine devices are contraindicated post-evacuation of molar pregnancy due to the increased risk of perforation. Intrauterine devices and progestogen-only pills cause irregular bleeding and are best avoided as they lead to suspicion of malignancy. Safer contraceptive choices for such patients include combined oral pills, injectable DMPA(depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate), progestin implant, barrier methods, and sterilization.

Contraception has to be adopted by all patients who underwent suction curettage until HCG levels become undetectable and remain the same for a period of 6 months. This serves to avoid pregnancy and confusion regarding the source of HCG if there is a subsequent rise. After beta HCG levels have become normal, subsequent conception must be avoided for one year(preferably 2 years). Pregnancy should also be avoided for 1 year after the stoppage of chemotherapy because of the teratogenic effect of drugs.

All patients should be followed-up for 2 years because choriocarcinoma if it occurs, develops within this period of the evacuation of the mole. Commonly, the circulating levels of βhCG decrease or becomes negative within 4 to 8 weeks post evacuation. Once negative, the patient is usually followed up monthly for 6 months, then 3 monthly in the first year, and 6 monthly in the second year.

During follow-up visits, history should be taken about symptoms like irregular bleeding (choriocarcinoma), presence of nodules, cough, breathlessness, and hemoptysis (metastasis). An abdominal examination should be done to check for involution of the uterus and ovarian size. A pelvic examination is done to look for sub-urethral nodules (anterior vaginal wall).

Lab investigations must include routine investigations like haemogram, renal function, liver function test, and urine routine. Specific investigations include thyroid function tests and serum βhCG (by radio-immunoassay). Persistently high values indicate pregnancy or invasive mole.

Radiological investigations should include a chest X-ray PA view to look for lung metastases (classic cannon-ball appearance can be seen). Pelvic ultrasound is also done for surveillance. Myometrial or suburethral nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia. 

The given image shows the classical cannon-ball appearance on the chest X-ray.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: An intern uses the following instrument to catheterize the patient during his surgery postings. What is the size of the catheter used by the intern?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Foley's catheter. The presence of a red coloured ring in the balloon port indicates its size as 18 F.

Catheter size is measured in the Charrière or French scale. The French scale refers to the external diameter of the catheter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter. As a general rule, catheter size should be the smallest size that can accomplish the desired drainage (i.e., 12 to 14 Fr for clear urine and 20 to 24 for thick pus or blood-filled urine).

Other options:

Option A: 14 F foley's catheter has a green ring in the balloon port.

Option B: 12 F foley's catheter has an white ring in the balloon port. 

Option D: 20 F foley's catheter has a yellow ring in the balloon port.

The image below shows Foley catheters with different coloured rings in the balloon ports.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: Which of the following viruses causes tropical spastic paraparesis?
questions.solution:
Human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV) is the causative agent of the neurodegenerative disorder HTLV-1-associated myelopathy or tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP).

TSP resembles multiple sclerosis and is associated with progressive weakness of the legs and lower body. The patients develop spastic paraparesis or paraplegia, hyperreflexia, ankle clonus, and extensor plantar response. The disease progresses slowly and takes the form of thoracic myelopathy. MRI reveals lesions in the white matter and the paraventricular regions of the brain and spinal cord. The spinal cord shows symmetric degeneration of the lateral columns. 

HTLV-1 is a retrovirus with an affinity for mature T lymphocytes. It is transmitted via blood transfusions, contaminated needles, sexual intercourse and breastfeeding (mother-to-child transmission). HTLV-1 also causes adult T-cell leukemias and lymphomas (ATL), uveitis, infective dermatitis, arthritis and Sjögren’s syndrome.

questions.text: A newborn with persistent cyanosis was evaluated. He was found to have a congenital heart disease that is schematically represented below. What is the most likely embryological defect causing this?

choices.text: Failure in formation of conotruncal ridges

questions.solution:
The given image shows persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) and the embryological defect causing this is a failure in the formation of the conotruncal ridges.

This leads to the absence of a conotruncal or aorticopulmonary septum which normally divides the outflow tract into the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.

Deoxygenated blood goes into the right heart and back into systemic circulation via the aorta. Oxygenated blood goes into the left heart and then back into pulmonary circulation via the pulmonary artery. This parallel circulation gives rise to persistent cyanosis as seen in this patient. 

Since the conotruncal ridges also participate in the formation of the interventricular septum, an accompanying ventricular septal defect (VSD) may also be seen. The persistent truncus overrides both the ventricles and receives mixed blood from both sides. 

 

Other options -

Option A - Abnormal spiraling of the conotruncal septum leads to the transposition of the great arteries (TGA). This leads to the aorta originating from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

 

Option B - Anterior displacement of the conotruncal septum gives rise to the Tetralogy of Fallot. It is characterized by 4 cardinal features - pulmonary infundibular stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is represented by the schematic image given below. 

 

Option D - Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection causes the drainage of oxygenated blood (brought in by pulmonary veins) into the systemic venous circulation. It is represented by the schematic image given below.

questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing trisodium citrate.

Cap color Additive present

questions.text: A person is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was placed in a surgical position as shown in the image below. Identify the position.
questions.solution:
The above image shows the reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient's head is elevated 15-30 degrees higher than the feet.  

It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level. In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the patient is placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position slightly turned to the left. This exposes the fundus of the gallbladder which is retracted towards the diaphragm.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

The below image shows the various surgical positions and the procedure they are used in:

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the infarct shown in the image?

choices.text: This is an example of coagulative necrosis
Seen in organs which lack an end-arterial circulation
Sepsis is usually absent in this type

questions.solution:
The image shows a splenic infarct that appears white, wedge-shaped, and bland in nature. It is seen in organs with an end-arterial circulation (i.e. organs that lack collateral circulation)

An infarct is an area of localized coagulative necrosis. They may be red (hemorrhagic) or white (anemic) based on color. Based on the presence or absence of infection, they may be septic or bland, respectively. Splenic infarcts are usually white, bland, wedge-shaped, and subcapsular in location.

The spleen is an organ with end-arterial circulation. The occlusion of a major splenic artery or any of its branches causes the infarct. Vascular occlusion leads to an infarct due to the lack of collateral blood supply. Common sites where emboli lodges are the kidney, brain, and spleen.

Splenic infarcts are usually bland unless it occurs in a patient with infectious endocarditis. In such cases, septic infarcts are common. There is suppurative necrosis due to the presence of microbes in the necrotic tissue. The infarct gets converted to an abscess.

Red infarcts are seen

  • with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  • in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  • in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
  • in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  • when the flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction)

questions.text: A patient was treated with an intravenous antimalarial drug following which he developed tinnitus, headache, nausea, and visual disturbances. Examination revealed hypotension and lab reports revealed hypoglycemia. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of the adverse effects of quinine. It is an antimalarial used to treat severe malaria.

Quinine is used in the treatment of drug-resistant and severe P. falciparum malaria. It acts against asexual erythrocytic forms of malarial parasites. 

Quinine is most commonly associated with a triad of adverse effects which includes:

  • Cinchonism - headache, tinnitus, high-tone deafness, visual disturbances, vomiting, and postural hypotension.
  • Hypoglycemia - results due to hyperinsulinemia secondary to stimulation of pancreatic beta cells by quinine.
  • Hypotension.

Other adverse effects of quinine include gastrointestinal disturbance, skin manifestations (sweating, flushing, rash, and angioedema), QTc prolongation, and blackwater fever.

Blackwater fever is a hypersensitivity reaction associated with the use of quinine. It presents with a triad of severe hemolysis, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria.

Other options:

Options A and B: Artemether and artesunate cause gastrointestinal disturbances, itching, drug fever, and hypersensitivity reactions. Minor adverse effects include headache, dizziness, and dark urine.

Option D: Atovaquone can cause gastrointestinal side effects like abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. It can also cause transient elevation of serum amylase or transaminase.

questions.text:
Identify the correct pair i- Mummification, ii- Adipocere, iii- Marbling, iv- Lividity of death
i  Mummification
ii  Adipocere
iii Marbling
iv Lividity of death
questions.solution:
Image 1. Marbling: It is the discoloration of superficial veins due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours. 

Image 2. Lividity of death: Postmortem lividity (suggillation, postmortem hypostasis/postmortem staining/livor mortis/suggillation/vibices) develops in the dependent portions of the body due to engorged vessels showing through the skin.

Image 3. Mummification: It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air. 

Image 4. Adipocere: It forms under warm and humid weather due to hydrolysis of lipids.

questions.text: A 25-year-old sportsperson presents with pain in the left knee after sustaining an injury while playing football. You observe the resident performing the following test on this patient. The test which is being done is_____
questions.solution:
The test done in the image is Apley's test, it is used to detect injuries to the menisci and it is done with the patient lying in the prone position.

Apley's test: This test is done with the patient prone, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. This reproduces symptoms if a meniscus is torn. Rotation is then repeated while the leg is pulled upwards by the doctor, holding the thigh down, which is called the distraction test. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

Other options:

McMurray's test: This test is used to detect injuries to the menisci. The patient is positioned in a supine posture with the knee fully flexed. The knee joint is stabilized and palpated using one hand, while the other hand is utilized to internally and externally rotate the leg. Gradual extension of the leg is performed during this examination. If there is any detectable clicking sensation or sound, it may indicate a meniscal injury.

Option C: Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. In this examination, the patient's knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle. The examiner uses one hand to hold the lower thigh and the other to grasp the upper part of the leg. The joint surfaces are then shifted backward and forwards upon each other. Any abnormal movement observed during this test may indicate a potential anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.

 

Option D: The Thessaly test is done to detect meniscal tears. In this test, the affected knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle, and the patient places the foot flat on the ground. While being supported by the examiner, the patient bears their full weight on that leg. They are then instructed to twist their body to one side and then the other, repeating this movement three times, while maintaining the knee flexed at 20 degrees. Individuals with meniscal tears may feel pain along the medial or lateral joint line and may also sense a locking sensation in the knee.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of injury and tests for knee injuries

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents to the outpatient for the first time. He was born by vaginal delivery at home and has not received any vaccines. Which of the following vaccines would be indicated at this visit, as per the National Immunization Schedule?
questions.solution:
BCG (Bacille Calmette-Guerin) vaccine would be indicated in this 3-week-old neonate at this visit as per the national immunization schedule. 

BCG is a live attenuated vaccine that can be given soon after birth until 1 year of age. It is given intradermally at the left upper arm. It provides protection against the central nervous system and disseminated tuberculosis. The liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine are the types available. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine.

After 2-3 weeks of correct vaccine administration a papule develops at the site. Its size increases slowly and breaks into a shallow ulcer covered with a crust. Healing occurs within 6-12 weeks and will leave a permanent tiny round scar, which is a normal reaction. Adverse reactions seen with BCG vaccine administration are pain, swelling, redness, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, etc. 

The image below shows the BCG scar: 

Mission Indradhanush was launched to fully immunize children up to two years of age against seven vaccine-preventable diseases and pregnant women. The vaccines against the following diseases are included in this program diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, tuberculosis, polio, hepatitis B, and measles. It was later modified to the intensified mission indradhanush to further strengthen the immunization coverage.

Other Options:

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine given at birth until the first 24 hours. It is given intramuscularly on the anterolateral side of the mid-thigh. 

Option C: Oral polio vaccine-0 (OPV-0)  is a live attenuated vaccine given at birth until the first 15 days.

Option D: Injectable polio vaccine (IPV) is a killed whole organism vaccine given at 6 and 14 weeks of age.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: A young girl after a school camp develops fever with rashes involving her palms and soles, without eschar. On probing further, she remembers suffering a tick bite during the camp. A blood test reveals antibodies that react with Proteus antigens. Which of the following is the causative organism of the condition?
questions.solution:
Fever and rash involving the palms and soles after a tick bite, with a positive Weil-Felix reaction is suggestive of rocky mountain spotted fever (RMSF). RMSF is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii.

RMSF occurs secondary to the bite of a dermacentor tick (hard tick). Patients present with fever, headache, myalgia, and centripetally distributed rashes over palms and soles.  The most common serologic test for the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. Weil-Felix reaction is usually positive in RMSF because the antibodies against Rickettsia react with Proteus antigens. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline. 

The following 3 diseases typically present with rash on palms and soles:

  1. Rocky mountain spotted fever
  2. Secondary syphilis
  3. Hand, foot and mouth disease.

Other options: 

Option A: Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox. Clinical features are fever, headache, lymphadenopathy, and eschar. Weil-Felix reaction is negative. 

Option C: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis. It is a sexually transmitted disease. Clinical features are hard chancre, condyloma latum, scaly papular eruptions, and constitutional symptoms.

Option D: Coxiella burnetti causes Q fever. Symptoms are fever, headache, photophobia, etc. Weil-Felix reaction is negative.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Which is the most common cardiac valvular lesion seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common cardiac valvular lesion seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 days. On examination, there was local rise of temperature, and the swelling was mobile over the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestive of inflammatory carcinoma of the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It mimics acute mastitis. The hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin, often without a discrete underlying tumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling of the breast, warmth, erythema and edema. A breast lump may or may not be present. 

A diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidly progressive swelling with inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imaging features with ultrasound and a mammograph is non-specific due to the underlying erythema and edema. A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis. 

Treatment includes combined-modality treatment:

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy- for ER-positive tumors
  • Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors

Option B: Giant fibroadenomas occasionally occur during puberty. These are benign solid encapsulated slow-growing tumors over 5 cm in diameter. It presents as a painless lump in the breast. They are managed by excision via a submammary incision.

Option C: Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes. It presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition. Benign lesions can be treated with enucleation or wide local excision. Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant lesions are treated with a mastectomy.

Option D: Galactocele are the most common benign breast lesions in lactating women. It is a cystic enlargement of the mammary gland containing milk. They are mostly detected during lactation or in the third trimester of pregnancy but rarely, may also present after stopping breastfeeding. Clinically, the mass is usually firm and non-tender and presents as a solid tumour-like lesion on physical examination. The patient usually notes the lesion during lactation or some period after lactation. Needle aspiration, followed by excision should it recur, is the standard method of treating galactocele.

questions.text:
The actions of the muscle attached to the area marked by the red arrow are:
  1. Depression of the mandible
  2. Protrusion of the mandible
  3. Side-to-side movement
  4. Elevation of the mandible
  5. Retraction of the mandible
questions.solution:
The marked area is the pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the jaw. In addition to the pterygoid fovea, the lateral pterygoid muscle is also inserted into the articular disc and capsule of the temporomandibular joint. 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has 2 heads. The upper head originates from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head originates from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate.

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive patient was brought to the medicine OPD with spontaneous and often continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, and the face suggestive of athetosis. Infarction in which of the following structures would be responsible for this movement disorder?
questions.solution:
The movement disorder described in this patient is athetosis. It results from infarction in globus pallidus, marked as 3 in the given image.

Lesions in the globus pallidus frequently lead to spontaneous and often continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face. These movements are called athetosis.

The internal capsule separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the putamen and the globus pallidus (which is placed more medially than the putamen).

Other marked structures include:

  • Caudate nucleus - 1
  • Thalamus - 2
  • Putamen - 4

The true statement is that heterochromatin stains densely.
