questions.text: Which of the following is not a new chapter in ICD- 11 compared to ICD-10?
questions.solution:
The chapter on Mental and behavioral disorders was already present in ICD-10, the other options are new chapters added to ICD-11.

The ICD 11 was released by the WHO in June 2018 and was presented at the World Health Assembly in May 2019 for adoption by the Member States, and will come into effect on 1 January 2022.

New chapters on:

  • Traditional medicine
  • Sleep-Wake disorders
  • Extension codes
  • Disorders of the Immune system
  • Conditions related to sexual health
  • Diseases of the blood and blood-forming organs

questions.text: A patient with an established diagnosis of peptic ulcer disease is started on omeprazole. Which type of cell membrane transport is inhibited by this drug?
questions.solution:
Primary active transport type of cell membrane transport is inhibited by this drug. Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that blocks the H+-K+ ATPase. The proton pump is an example of primary active transport. 

Primary active transport is an active transport mechanism that obtains energy from the hydrolysis of ATP to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient. The transportation of the molecules mainly depends on the carrier proteins.

Important examples of primary active transport: 

  • Sodium-potassium ATPase
  • Proton pump
  • Calcium ATPase

Proton pumps: These are essential for the primary active transport of hydrogen ions. These pumps are mainly present in gastric glands of the stomach and late distal tubules and cortical collecting ducts of the kidney. 

The main function of proton pumps in the parietal cells of the stomach is to secrete gastric acid. The gastric mucosa has abundant mitochondria and this provides the ATPase that is required for the primary active transport of hydrogen ions. 

At rest, the proton pumps lie within the cells in stacks of membrane compartments called tubulovesicles. During the active phase secretion, these tubulovesicles fuse to form canaliculi. This fusion increases the apical membrane of the cells and positions the proton pumps to begin the acid secretion. 

Proton-pump inhibitors like omeprazole form thiophilic sulfenamide cation that irreversibly binds and inactivates the enzyme H+-K+ ATPase. 

Other options: 

Option A: In simple diffusion, the molecules pass directly through the cell membrane along the concentration gradient. It does not require energy and is not carrier-mediated. Examples include the movement of water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen across the cell membrane. 

Option B: In secondary active transport, the transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances against the concentration gradient. Examples include sodium co-transport of glucose and amino acids with sodium and sodium counter-transport of calcium and hydrogen ions. 

Option C: In facilitated diffusion, the molecules are transported via carrier-mediated proteins along the concentration gradient. This transport does not require energy. Examples include the transport of glucose through GLUT (insulin-mediated transport of glucose via GLUT 4). 

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

questions.text:
A newborn is being evaluated for yellowish discoloration of the sclera and elevated bilirubin levels. Which of the following are indications to further evaluate the child to identify the cause of jaundice?
  1. Serum bilirubin of 16 mg/dL in a full-term infant 
  2. Jaundice appearing on the first day of birth
  3. Jaundice persisting after 14 days
  4. Direct bilirubin fraction < 2mg/dL on the 3rd day
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 3 are suggestive of a pathological cause of jaundice and need to be further evaluated for the cause of jaundice. 

Physiological jaundice occurs due to increased bilirubin production due to the destruction of the fetal RBCs along with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks between 2nd and 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.

Risk factors for physiological jaundice include maternal age, maternal diabetes, prematurity, drugs(Vitamin K3, novobiocin), polycythemia, male sex, trisomy 21, cutaneous bruising, blood extravasation as in cephalhematoma, breastfeeding, weight loss, and a family history of physiological jaundice.

Jaundice in the newborn is not always physiological and in some cases, there can be an underlying pathology. Given below are the indications to evaluate a newborn to identify the cause of pathological jaundice:

  • Jaundice that appears in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  • A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dL/24hr
  • Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  • Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  • Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  • Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

Other features suggestive of a nonphysiological cause of jaundice are a positive family history of any hemolytic disease, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, poor feeding, apnea, bradycardia, hypothermia, light-colored stools, failure of phototherapy to lower the bilirubin levels, and signs of kernicterus.

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for abnormal renal function tests. He was given a substance 'x' whose clearance is 20mL/min and the urinary concentration is 100mg/mL. If the urine flow is 2mL/min, calculate the plasma concentration of the substance 'x'.
questions.solution:
The calculated plasma concentration of the substance 'x' in the above patient is 10mg/mL.

It is calculated using the formula -

C = [U]x x V / [P]x 

Where,

  • C is the clearance (mL/min) = 20mL/min
  • [U]x is the urine concentration of substance x (mg/mL) = 100mg/mL
  • V is the urine flow rate (mL/min) = 2mL/min
  • [P]x is the plasma concentration of substance x (mg/ml)

The steps of calculation are shown in the image below -

questions.text:
An outbreak of food poisoning in a coastal city is determined to be due to contaminated seafood. The causative bacteria formed the following colonies on TCBS agar and showed hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar. Which of the following statements regarding the organism implicated here is false?

TCBS - Thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose agar

choices.text: It produces peritrichous flagella on solid medium
It gives a positive string test

questions.solution:
The given case scenario of an organism that caused food poisoning due to contaminated seafood in addition to the cultural characteristics is suggestive of food contamination by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. It is a capsulated organism.

V. parahaemolyticus is an enteropathogenic halophilic vibrio that is an important cause of food poisoning throughout the world. It inhabits the coastal seas, where it is found in shrimps, crabs, and oysters.

It forms opaque green colonies with a raised centre and flat translucent periphery on TCBS agar unlike V. cholera which forms yellow colonies. Pathogenic strains show hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar which is known as Kanagawa phenomenon. This can be used as a test for pathogenecity.

Other options:

Option B: It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency for pleomorphism, especially when grown on 3% salt agar.

Option C: Unlike other vibrios, it produces peritrichous flagella when grown on solid media. Polar flagella are formed in liquid cultures.

Option D: String test is positive like with V. cholera.

questions.text: A newborn is being assessed at 5 minutes after birth. He is found to have a heart rate of 110bpm, coughs on stimulation, and has a strong cry. His limbs are well flexed, the body is pink, but extremities appear blue. The Apgar score for this newborn is ______
questions.solution:
The Apgar score for this newborn is 9.

In this baby:

  • Body pink, extremities blue: score 1
  • Heart rate, >100 beats/min: score 2
  • Coughs on stimulation, score 2
  • Well flexed of the extremities: score 2
  • Strong cry: score 2

Thus the total score is 9.

  • At 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth of the infant, the 5 objective signs listed here are evaluated and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2.
  • A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition.
  • An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: What is the GCS score of a road traffic accident victim who opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, makes some incomprehensible sounds, and has the following posture?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of this patient is 6.

The given findings contributed to the score as follows:

  • Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • Incomprehensible sounds - 2
  • Decerebrate posturing/abnormal extension - 2

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Decorticate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain.
  • The upper limbs are flexed, lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons.
  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response in the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.
